questions.text: A 28-year-old obese patient presented with colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea and no history of fever. What could be the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba histolytica

 

  • Infective form – Quadrinucleate cyst (ingested with contaminated food and water)
  • Amoebiasis or amoebic dysentery is an infection caused mainly by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba Histolytica. Symptoms may include lethargy, loss of weight, colonic ulcerations, abdominal pain, diarrhea and Dysentery.
  • In the liver most common site → posterior superior portion of right lobe of liver damage to hepatocytes leads to anchovy sauce pus/ chocolate pus.
  • IOC: EIA / ELISA

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coli: E. coli infections can present with diarrhea, but they are often associated with different clinical features, such as fever, especially in cases of enteroinvasive strains.

 

Option C. Shigella: Shigella infections typically present with fever, bloody diarrhea, and severe abdominal cramping, which does not fit the patient's presentation of no fever.

 

Option D. Giardia lamblia: Giardiasis often presents with foul-smelling diarrhea, flatulence, and abdominal distension. The absence of fever and the specific symptom of colicky abdominal pain make it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica is the causative organism for amoebiasis, presenting with colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea without fever. The infective form is the quadrinucleate cyst, and the liver can be a significant site of infection, producing characteristic abscesses.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and also unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is this sign known as? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Holman Miller sign

 

The given case involves a young male experiencing repeated, unprovoked nosebleeds and a blocked nostril on one side, indicating a possible diagnosis of juvenile angiofibroma. The provided CT image illustrates the presence of the antral or Holman Miller sign.

 

JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block
  • Pink/purple mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

Investigation:

 

  1. CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  2. MRI is complementary to CT scan
  3. Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aquino sign is seen in Glomus Tumour. There is blanching of the mass with manual compression of ipsilateral carotid artery.

 

Option C. Teardrop sign is seen in fracture of the inferior orbital wall. Typically follows a Blowout fracture.

 

 

Option D. Hanging drop sign is another name for Tear drop sign

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Holman Miller sign on a CT scan is a diagnostic indicator of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a benign tumor that causes significant morbidity due to its vascularity and location. It primarily affects adolescent males and presents with symptoms like recurrent nosebleeds and nasal obstruction. The preferred treatment is surgical excision, often preceded by embolization of feeding vessels to minimize intraoperative bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a gynecologist, troubled by greenish, frothy vaginal discharge and burning discomfort for the past month. After examination, which treatment kit should be prescribed based on her symptoms? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Green

 

The symptoms described are characteristic of Trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. The green kit, which typically contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, is specifically tailored for treating vaginal discharge and vaginitis associated with this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grey Kit: Targets urethral and cervical discharge related to bacterial infections, not suitable for protozoan infections.

 

Option C. White Kit: Used for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, irrelevant to the patient’s symptoms of discharge.

 

Option D. Blue Kit: Also for genital ulcers but for patients allergic to penicillin, which does not align with the current clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Based on the following image, which is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lepromatous leprosy

 

The given image shows symmetrical and bilateral, consisting of ill-defined macules, Papulonodules, diffuse infiltration and thickening of skin, which are features of Lepromatous leprosy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy: Typically presents with one to a few well-defined, hypopigmented, and dry skin lesions. Nerve involvement is common, causing numbness or loss of sensation in the affected areas, which is not consistent with the extensive skin involvement seen in the image.

 

Option B. Borderline tuberculoid leprosy: Features a small number of skin lesions that are more defined than in lepromatous leprosy, with some nerve involvement, which does not match the extensive, diffuse characteristics shown.

 

Option C. Leishmaniasis: Although it can cause skin lesions, these are usually ulcers or nodules at the site of the sandfly bite, not the diffuse skin thickening and multiple nodules typical of lepromatous leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepromatous leprosy is a severe form of leprosy with extensive skin and nerve involvement. Recognizing its presentation is crucial for timely and appropriate treatment to manage symptoms and prevent progression.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who was a chronic smoker started noticing blackening of his fingertips and cold sensation of his fingers. Identify the condition from the picture given below. (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buerger’s disease

 

Young male smoker with blackening of finger tips (Raynaud phenomenon) is pointing towards the diagnosis of Buerger’s disease.

 

Buerger’s disease is a recurring progressive inflammation and thrombosis of small and medium arteries and veins of the hands and feet.

 

It is strongly associated with use of tobacco products.

The main symptom is pain in the lower limb while walking (claudication).

 

Symptoms –

 

  • Typically seen in 20 - 40 years old male.
  • Current (or recent) history of tobacco use.
  • Presence of distal extremity ischemia (indicated by claudication, pain at rest, ischemic ulcers or gangrene) documented by noninvasive vascular testing such as ultrasound.
  • Exclusion of other autoimmune diseases, hypercoagulable states, and diabetes mellitus by laboratory tests.
  • Exclusion of a proximal source of emboli by echocardiography and arteriography.
  • Consistent arteriographic findings in the clinically involved and noninvolved limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kawasaki disease is an autoimmune condition seen in children of around 5 years of age. It is characterized by high grade of fever for around 5 days, bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash with unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy and strawberry tongue. Treatment involves IVIG and Aspirin. It doesn’t present with Raynaud phenomenon.

 

Option C. Scleroderma is more common in females and it is an autoimmune condition. Clinically, the patient presents with thickening hardening and sclerosis of the skin. It can be localized or systemic sclerosis. It is associated with skin thickening, Raynaud’s phenomenon, interstitial lung diseases, pericarditis etc.

 

Option D. APLA syndrome is also common in females and the patient usually comes with a history of recurrent second trimester abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Buerger’s disease should be considered in young male smokers presenting with symptoms of distal extremity ischemia, such as claudication, ischemic ulcers, or gangrene, and Raynaud's phenomenon. The condition is closely linked to tobacco use and requires a thorough clinical evaluation to exclude other causes.

questions.text: A public health resident is reviewing intersectoral coordination between various national health initiatives in India. Which national program is known to work in collaboration with the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) to support holistic child development? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. NRHM

 

The national rural health mission (NRHM) now under national health mission is an initiative undertaken by the government of India to address the health needs of under-served rural areas.

 

ICDS or Integrated Child Development Services under the Ministry of Women and Child Development with the objectives of holistic development of the social, physical and nutritional component of the child and safe motherhood.

 

It helps in providing supplementary nutrition to children aged upto 6 yrs and pregnant and lactating mothers, gives non formal education, facilitates in immunization, helps in growth monitoring and looks after adolescent girl health. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREGA: This program focuses on employment and does not directly coordinate with child development services.

 

Option C. NLEP: The National Leprosy Eradication Programme, which is specific to leprosy, does not align directly with the objectives of ICDS.

 

Option D. NACP: The National AIDS Control Program primarily addresses HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment and does not have a direct collaboration with ICDS in the context of child development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intersectoral collaboration between ICDS and NRHM is crucial for effectively addressing the holistic needs of child development, highlighting how health services can be integrated to enhance public health outcomes in rural areas.

questions.text: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman on US shows a unilocular cyst in the ovary of 6cm with negative serology. Treatment involves:(FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs

 

Explanation:

 

  • Follow up after 1-2 cycles of oral combined pills (conservative management) is the best treatment modality in the given scenario as it is most likely to be a functional cyst.
  • Simple cysts < 5 -6cm can be managed conservatively

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy: As it is a simple cyst and < 8 cm, laparotomy is not required. If surgery is necessary, laparoscopy is preferred for a simple cyst.

 

Option D. Follow-up with CA-125: CA-125 is considered if there are suspicious features on ultrasound. In this case, the cyst appears simple and the serology is negative.

 

Option C. Ovariotomy: Ovariotomy is not indicated as it appears to be a simple cyst, and the patient is young, warranting conservative management first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional ovarian cysts less than 8 cm in premenopausal women can be managed conservatively with follow-up after 1-2 cycles of oral contraceptive pills.

 

Ref: Adnexal mass, Berek and Novak Textbook of Gynecology, 16th edition

choices.text: It can be used for screening of hearing loss
It cannot be used for assessing sensorineural hearing loss

questions.text: Which of the following is true about BERA? (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It can be used for screening of hearing loss

 

BERA

 

  • BERA tests the integrity of auditory nerve (auditory pathway from cochlea to brain)
  • It is an objective test
  • A sound stimulus is given and electrical potentials arising along the auditory pathway from cochlear nerve to brain are checked.
  • Wave V is most prominent in BERA that corresponds to lateral lemniscus
  • Normal BERA means the cochlear nerve is intact and conducting sound impulses from cochlea to brain.
  • So, normal OAE and BERA indicates almost normal hearing pathway, hence are used in newborn screening
  • BERA is also used to check malingerers (people those who pretend to be deaf)

 

APPLICATIONS OF BERA:

 

  1. As a screening procedure for infants.
  2. To determine the threshold of hearing in infants, children and adults who do not cooperate and in malingerers.
  3. To diagnose retro cochlear pathology particularly acoustic neuroma.
  4. To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g., multiple sclerosis or pontine tumors.
  5. To monitor CN VIII intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuromas to preserve the function of cochlear nerve

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is an invasive procedure: This is false. BERA is a non-invasive test that involves placing electrodes on the scalp to measure electrical activity in response to sound.

 

Option C. It cannot be used for assessing sensorineural hearing loss: This is incorrect. BERA is specifically useful for assessing types of hearing loss, including sensorineural, by evaluating the function of the auditory nerve and brainstem pathways.

 

Option D. It is a subjective investigation: This is false. BERA is an objective test because it does not rely on the subject's response or perception; it directly measures electrical activity in the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BERA is an effective, non-invasive, and objective method for screening hearing loss, particularly in newborns and uncooperative individuals. It assesses the integrity of the auditory pathway, providing crucial information on both hearing function and neurological status related to the auditory system.

questions.text: The man present with a case of cervical rib has tingling sensation and paresthesia on the medial side of arm. Which of the marked structure is most likely affected? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

Choice A - upper trunk of brachial plexus (C5 & C6 roots)

 

Choice B - middle trunk of the brachial plexus (C7)

 

Choice C - lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 & T1)

 

Choice D –Phrenic nerve (C3, C4 & C5)

 

This condition known as thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), specifically the type caused by the presence of a cervical rib. In this condition, a cervical rib is an extra rib that develops above the first rib in the neck area. This can compress or impinge upon nerves and blood vessels in the neck and shoulder region, leading to symptoms such as tingling sensations, paresthesia, and weakness in the affected arm.

 

Given the description of tingling sensations and paresthesia on the medial side of the arm, it is likely that the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and the ulnar nerve may be affected. The brachial plexus is a network of nerves that controls the muscles of the arm and hand, while the ulnar nerve specifically innervates the medial side of the forearm and hand. Compression or irritation of these nerves due to the cervical rib can result in the described symptoms.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper Trunk of Brachial Plexus (C5 & C6 roots):

 

Effects of Injury: An injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus can result in a condition known as Erb's palsy or Erb-Duchenne palsy. This type of injury often occurs during childbirth or as a result of trauma to the shoulder area. Common effects include:

 

Loss of sensation: Reduced sensation in the shoulder, upper arm, and lower neck regions.

 

Motor deficits: Weakness or paralysis of the muscles that control the shoulder and elbow. This typically results in a characteristic posture known as the "waiter's tip position," where the arm hangs by the side with the wrist extended and the hand turned inward.

 

Muscle atrophy: Over time, muscle wasting may occur in the affected areas.

 

 

Option B. Middle Trunk of the Brachial Plexus (C7):

 

Effects of Injury: Isolated injury to the middle trunk of the brachial plexus is relatively rare. Typically, injuries involve more proximal portions of the plexus. However, if the middle trunk is affected, it may result in:

 

Loss of sensation: Reduced sensation in the middle of the arm.

 

Motor deficits: Weakness or paralysis of the muscles that control the elbow and wrist movements, depending on the severity of the injury.

 

Option D. Phrenic Nerve (C3, C4 & C5):

 

Effects of Injury: Injury to the phrenic nerve can result in paralysis or weakness of the diaphragm, the primary muscle responsible for breathing. Common effects include:

 

Breathing difficulties: Paralysis of the diaphragm leads to impaired lung ventilation, causing difficulty in breathing and the need for respiratory support.

 

Hypoxia: Reduced oxygen intake can lead to low oxygen levels in the blood (hypoxia), which can affect various organs and bodily functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 & T1 roots) by a cervical rib can lead to symptoms like tingling and paresthesia in the medial side of the arm, consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome. Awareness of the anatomical relationship between cervical ribs and the brachial plexus is critical in diagnosing and managing TOS.

 

Injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus can result in a condition known as Klumpke's palsy. Common effects include the reduced / loss of sensation in the hand and fingers. The most severe form of Klumpke's palsy, known as a total palsy, can result in a claw-like deformity of the hand.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents within 8 hours of having sexual intercourse and asking for emergency contraception. She says she doesn't want multiple pills and wants just one pill. What would be your advice? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg

 

Explanation:

 

  • LNG: Given within 72 hours of unprotected sexual activity. One tablet of 0.75 mg can be taken, followed by another 12 hours later. As an alternative, two tablets can be consumed at once. Failure rate is 1.1%. LNG inhibits ovulation and causes endometrial desynchronization (luteal phase deficiency).
  • Methods of emergency contraception are as described in the table

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg: This regimen requires two doses, 12 hours apart, which does not align with the patient's preference for a single pill.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol + levonorgestrel: This is the Yuzpe regimen, which involves taking multiple pills and is not suitable for a patient seeking a single-pill solution.

 

Option D. Desogestrel 3 mg: Desogestrel is not commonly used for emergency contraception. The preferred progesterone for emergency contraception is levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For emergency contraception within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, a single 1.5 mg dose of levonorgestrel is recommended, providing a convenient and effective solution.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with difficulty in foot eversion and sensory loss on the lateral leg & dorsum of foot. Which nerve lesion will lead to the following condition: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Superficial peroneal nerve

 

Explanation

 

The superficial peroneal nerve is a branch of the common peroneal nerve (a division of the sciatic nerve). It innervates the muscles that control foot eversion, specifically the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis muscles. It also provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot.

 

Effect of Lesion: If the superficial peroneal nerve is damaged or compressed, it can lead to weakness in the muscles responsible for foot eversion. Additionally, it can result in sensory loss on the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. This condition is known as superficial peroneal nerve entrapment or injury.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A.  Deep Peroneal Nerve: The deep peroneal nerve innervates the muscles that control foot dorsiflexion and toe extension. It also provides sensory innervation to the space between the first and second toes. Damage to this nerve would result in difficulty in dorsiflexion and toe extension, along with sensory loss in that specific area.

 

Option B. Sural Nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve that provides innervation to the lateral aspect of the leg and the lateral foot. Damage to the sural nerve would primarily result in sensory loss in these areas. It would not directly affect foot eversion or motor function.

 

Option D. Saphenous Nerve: The saphenous nerve is a sensory nerve that innervates the medial aspect of the leg and the foot. Damage to the saphenous nerve would primarily result in sensory loss in these areas. It would not directly affect foot eversion or motor function.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to pediatric OPD with incoordination of movements and abdominal pain. On further examination, a ring is seen around the cornea of the child as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wilson’s disease

 

The presentation of the child is suggestive of a diagnosis of Wilson’s disease.

  • It is also called hepatolenticular degeneration.
  • Autosomal recessive mutations in hepatocyte copper-transporting ATPase (ATP7B gene; chromosome 13) lead to reduced copper incorporation into apoceruloplasmin and excretion into bile leading to reduced serum ceruloplasmin.
  • Copper accumulates, especially in liver, brain (eg, basal ganglia), cornea, kidneys.
  • Urine copper increases.
  • It presents before 40 years of age with: 
    • Liver disease (eg, hepatitis, acute liver failure, cirrhosis)
    • Neurologic disease (eg, dysarthria, dystonia, tremor, parkinsonism)
    • Psychiatric disease
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings 
      • Brownish or gray-green pigmented granular deposits in Descemet membrane of cornea.
      • Sometimes seen with the naked eye; readily detected by slit-lamp examination.
      • May be absent in patients with hepatic manifestations only but is usually present in those with neuropsychiatric disease.
    • Haemolytic anemia
    • Renal disease (eg, Fanconi syndrome)
  • Treatment: 
    • Chelation with penicillamine or trientine, Oral zinc.
    • Liver transplant in acute liver failure related to Wilson disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratitis: Inflammation of the cornea, typically presenting with pain, redness, and visual disturbances, but not associated with corneal rings like the Kayser-Fleischer ring.

 

Option B. Keratoconus: A progressive thinning of the cornea leading to a cone-shaped protrusion. It does not present with corneal rings as seen in Wilson’s disease.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: A type of cancer that arises from nerve tissue, typically in the adrenal glands or sympathetic nervous system. It does not cause corneal rings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson’s disease should be suspected in young patients presenting with a combination of liver, neurological, and psychiatric symptoms, along with characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to managing this disorder effectively.

questions.text: A public health graduate student is exploring how age-specific mortality rates impact fertility indicators. Which fertility indicator is influenced by variations in these mortality rates? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Net reproduction rate (NRR)

 

The Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) assesses the ability of a population to replace itself while considering mortality rates before the end of the reproductive age. It's unique among fertility indicators because it integrates both the fertility rate and the survival rate of women up to and during their childbearing years, making it sensitive to changes in mortality rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gross Reproductive Rate (GRR): This rate counts the number of daughters a woman would bear disregarding mortality rates, focusing only on fertility rates.

 

Option C. Total Fertility Rate (TFR): The TFR calculates the total number of children a woman would have based solely on current fertility rates, without factoring in mortality.

 

Option D. General Fertility Rate (GFR): This metric indicates live births per 1000 women of childbearing age annually, without adjusting for mortality risk among those born or their mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRR is dependent on change in age specific fertility and mortality rate.

 

Net reproduction rate (NRR) = Expected number of daughters, per newborn prospective mother, who may or may not survive to and through the ages of childbearing.

questions.text: Identify the Anomaly shown in the picture below. (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Annular pancreas

 

The given anatomical site marked is the second part of the duodenum around which pancreas is making a loop. This is called as Annular Pancreas.

 

  • Annular pancreas is an abnormal ring or collar of pancreatic tissue that encircles the duodenum
  • This portion of pancreas can constrict the duodenum leading to intestinal obstruction
  • It is due to the failure of rotation of Ventral bud of pancreas.
  • Surgery of choice is Duodenoduodenostomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyloric stenosis: it is most commonly observed in infants and is characterized by obstruction at the pylorus due to hypertrophy of the circular muscles. The patient presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting, visible peristalsis, palpable olive-shaped mass, weight loss and dehydration.

 

Option B. Pancreas Divisum: it occurs when two main pancreatic ducts that normally fuse during embryonic development fail to merge completely, resulting in the separation of the ducts. It leads to recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. It is diagnosed mainly in the adulthood through imaging like MRCP or ERCP.

 

Option D. Duodenal Atresia: it is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in a newborn characterized by projectile bilious vomiting, polyhydramnios. It is frequently associated with Down syndrome and on X-ray, it is characterized by Double Bubble Sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annular pancreas is an abnormal ring of pancreatic tissue encircling the duodenum, leading to symptoms of intestinal obstruction. It is due to the failure of the rotation of the ventral bud of the pancreas. The definitive treatment is duodenoduodenostomy.

questions.text: A 74-year-old female suffered with heart disease and with cardiac atrophy. On H/E stain perinuclear, brown colored deposits were seen. Which pigment responsible for this? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lipofuscin

 

Lipofuscin: Injury of free radical, wear and tear pigmentation, also seen in cachexia, cancers. Lipofuscin is a Golden-brown pigment and called as pigment of aging. Sudan black B stain used.

 

 

 

Lipofuschin is also known as Wear & Tear pigment associated with aging, Perinuclear arrangements and Golden-brown color are characteristic of Lipofuscin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemosiderin: This is an iron-storage complex found within cells, typically resulting from the breakdown of hemoglobin. It stains blue with Prussian blue stain (Pearl's reaction). Iron is usually stored in the form of Ferritin which then converts to Hemosiderin.

 

Option B. Stellate Cell: These are not pigments but specific cell types. In the liver, hepatic stellate cells are involved in fibrosis.

 

Option D. Calcium: Calcifications appear as dark purple or basophilic deposits on H&E staining, often indicating dystrophic or metastatic calcification.

 

Note - Melanin: black in color, identified with masson/ fontana stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lipofuscin, identified by its golden-brown perinuclear deposits, is a marker of aging and cellular wear and tear, especially in long-lived cells like cardiac myocytes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with rash over her lips as shown in image below, 1 hour after she had taken NSAIDs for her joint pain. She had reported that she developed the same rash in the same location 5 months ago when she took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge, its short latency and benign nature, hence their site on the skin is fixed.

 

  • FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.
  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and oedematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • It is a classical delayed‐type hypersensitivity reaction
  • Key mediators - Skin resident T cells
  • Long after clinical resolution, ‘resting’ FDE lesions contain CD8+ T cells with an effector/memory phenotype. These cells (at the dermal–epidermal junction) remain quiescent until drug re-exposure.
  • On re‐exposure to the drug, there is activation and expansion of these CD8+ lymphocytes with the release of interferon (IFN)‐γ and cytotoxic granules resulting in keratinocyte apoptosis.
  • Regulatory T cells are recruited into the lesions and limit further damage by inhibiting the cytotoxic T- cells at the end of response.

 

Most common causes:

 

• NSAIDs - On Lips

• Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

  • Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.
  • The majority of FDE is self-limiting with an excellent prognosis.
  • Note: The generalized bullous form of FDE should be differentiated from toxic epidermal necrolysis by prior similar history, absence of target lesions, and no involvement of mucosal surfaces.
  • The image below shows hyperpigmentation on the Lips & Glans penis developing simultaneously & healing at the same time frame.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chikungunya fever:

  • The nose and cheeks show signs of post-chikungunya hyperpigmentation on the Centro-facial face (so-called "chik sign" as shown in the below image).

 

  • After the fever has subsided, the pigmentary changes appear and could last for three to six months. However, the question stem describes how pigmentary changes start to manifest after a few days. Additionally, during the acute febrile phase, these patients will not experience any preceding erythema or eruption over the affected areas.

 

 

Option B. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) is an acquired form of hypermelanosis that develops as a result of cutaneous injury or inflammation, such as impetigo, atopic dermatitis, or acne vulgaris.

 

Option D. Drug hypersensitivity is an immune-mediated reaction to a drug of which symptoms ranging from mild to severe include rash, anaphylaxis, and serum sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

     

The recurrence of a rash at the same site upon re-exposure to a drug, particularly with a rapid onset following drug intake, is characteristic of Fixed Drug Eruption. This should be distinguished from other causes of drug reactions and hyperpigmentation due to its localized nature and recurrence pattern.

 

References: Rooks text book of dermatology, 9th edition, page no 88.28, 118.12

questions.text: Identify the active principle of the plant shown below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyoscine

 

The image shows white, large trumpet shaped flowers, characteristic of Datura. Datura Flowers are large trumpet-shaped which may be white or purple. Hyoscine is one of the active principle of Datura.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names: thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle: Atropine, Scopolamine (Hyoscine), and Hyoscyamine.
  • Datura Flowers: Flowers are large trumpet-shaped which may be white or purple
  • Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains about 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which resemble chilly seeds

 

The below image shows datura flower and datura fruit capsule:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by following features:

 

  • Leaves: Characteristic of the leaf is an areolated portion bounded by two longitudinal curved lines, one line on each side of the midrib
  • Flowers are small, and disposed in little clusters on short stalks
  • Red Berries: The flowers mature into red berries.

 

The below image shows flowers, berries and leaves of cocaine:

 

 

 

 

Option C. Tobacco:  Nicotiana tabacum (tobacco) flowers are typically tubular in shape. These flowers have a long, slender tube-like structure that little bit flares out at the end but doesn't have the wide, flaring shape associated with traditional "trumpet-shaped" flowers seen in Datura. Also Nicotiana tabacum (tobacco) flowers are pinkish white, whereas datra flowers are either white or purple. Below image shows nicotiana tabacum flower:

 

 

Option D. Tetrahydro-cannabinol:  It is obtained from Cannabis plant. Flowers are Small, tightly packed, and usually clustered at the top of the plant in a dense, conical shape. Below image shows cannabis flower with trichomes:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active Principles of Datura: Hyoscine (Scopolamine); Atropine and Hyoscyamine

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient complaint of frequent perianal pruritus. On microscopic examination, following Image was Seen. Find out the most probable causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, also called pinworm, is one of the most common nematode infections in the World. Humans are the only natural host for this infection. Enterobius vermicularis is an organism that Primarily lives in the ileum and cecum. Once E. vermicularis eggs are ingested, they take about 1 to 2 months to develop into adult worms which happens in the small intestine. These do not usually cause any symptoms.

 

When confined to the ileocecal area. The female adult worms and ova migrate to the anal area mostly at night time and deposit thousands of eggs in the perianal area. This migration causes pruritus. Eggs hatch near the anal area causing perianal pruritus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs of Ascaris are bile-stained and have a rough surface. They are not typically associated with perianal pruritus.

 

Option C. Trichuris trichiura: Also known as whipworm, it has characteristic eggs that are barrel-shaped with mucous plugs at both ends.

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale: This hookworm has typical bile-stained eggs that contain 4-5 blastomeres but does not cause perianal pruritus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) is characterized by its eggs, which are responsible for causing perianal pruritus due to nocturnal migration of the female worms to lay eggs.
  • Trichuria has dumb-bell shaped eggs with mucous plugs on both the sides.
  • Ankylostoma has typical bile-stained eggs which look like 4-5 blastomeres.
  • Ascaris also has bile-stained eggs.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her mother with complaints of mouth breathing. She has a flat, expressionless long face with an open mouth. On examination, a high-arched palate and crowded upper teeth are noted. The X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Adenoid hypertrophy

 

The clinical situation and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids, point to an adenoid hypertrophy diagnosis with adenoid facies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual tonsils can be visualized on CT scan as follows.

 

 

Option B. Quinsy patients presents with severe pain in throat, odynophagia, Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice”, Ipsilateral earache (referred pain via CN IX) and trismus. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent.

 

 

Option C. Tonsillar hypertrophy – Following Xray denotes A as Adenoid hypertrophy and T as Tonsillar hypertrophy.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid hypertrophy should be considered in children presenting with mouth breathing, characteristic facial features, and crowded dental arches. A combination of clinical examination and imaging typically confirms the diagnosis, guiding appropriate management to alleviate symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic present with visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the last alcohol intake. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium

 

The patient's presentation of visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the cessation of alcohol intake is indicative of alcohol withdrawal delirium (often called "delirium tremens" or DTs).

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal seizures: Typically occur within 24-48 hours after the last drink and are characterized by generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hallucination: While it can cause hallucinations, it usually does not present with the marked confusion or disorientation seen in DTs.

 

Option D. Dementia: Chronic alcoholism can lead to dementia. However, it would not typically present acutely after cessation of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is having progressive anemia. On examination spleno-hepatomegaly is noted with malar eminence prominence. Peripheral smear is shown here. The clinical Diagnosis is? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thalassemia

 

Thalassemia → Image shows Target cells

 

  • There is presence of hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.
  • Presence of microcytic hypochromic cells
  • Target cells
  • Crew cut/ hair on end appearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: This condition is characterized by microcytic hypochromic anemia but does not typically present with target cells, hepatomegaly, or splenomegaly. Instead, it features pallor, fatigue, and possibly pica.

 

Option C. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia involves the presence of ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow and may present with microcytic anemia, but it does not typically show target cells or the systemic findings seen in thalassemia.

 

Option D. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia and basophilic stippling of erythrocytes but does not usually present with target cells or significant hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalassemia is characterized by the presence of target cells, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and hepatosplenomegaly, with a clinical presentation that includes malar eminence prominence.

choices.text: Vocal cord palsy

questions.text: The flow volume curve of a patient after spirometry is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

The flow volume curve provided shows a characteristic "scooping" or "coving" pattern on the expiratory limb, which is indicative of an obstructive lung disease such as Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). This pattern is due to the decreased flow rates during exhalation caused by airway obstruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Asbestosis causes a restrictive lung disease pattern, which is characterized by a decreased total lung capacity (TLC) and reduced forced vital capacity (FVC). The flow volume curve would typically show a reduced volume without the scooping pattern seen in COPD.

 

Option C. Vocal cord palsy: Vocal cord palsy causes extrathoracic airway obstruction, leading to flattening of the inspiratory curve on the flow volume loop. The expiratory curve would not show the characteristic scooping seen in COPD.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: Myasthenia gravis can cause restrictive lung disease due to reduced respiratory muscle strength. The flow volume curve would show reduced lung volumes without the scooping pattern indicative of obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic scooping or coving pattern on the expiratory limb of the flow volume curve is indicative of COPD, an obstructive lung disease. Other conditions like asbestosis, vocal cord palsy, and myasthenia gravis would present with different patterns on the flow volume curve.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child from a poor family is brought with complaints of fever, convulsions, and abnormal behavior for the last 2 months and has not been responding to the parents for the past 2 days. On examination, neck rigidity is seen with CSF showing increased lymphocytes, glucose-30mg% and proteins 300mg%. The diagnosis is: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Based on the clinical history of mild fever convulsions, and abnormal behaviour with neck rigidity for a period of 2 months is classically seen in case of Tubercular meningitis.
  • The CT scan with contrast can be an excellent clue for diagnosing tuberculous meningitis. Exudate in the basal cisterns that shows enhancement by contrast material is typical
  • The CSF findings includes, of Raised lymphocytes, raised protein and decreased CSF glucose is seen.
  • The physical examination of CSF will show the Cob web coagulum.
  • The treatment is starting with ATT and Steroids.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral meningitis: Viral meningitis typically presents with a more acute onset of symptoms and less severe CSF abnormalities. CSF glucose levels are usually normal or mildly reduced, and protein levels are not as elevated as in tubercular meningitis.

 

Option B. Bacterial meningitis: Bacterial meningitis usually presents acutely with a more aggressive course, including fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. CSF in bacterial meningitis shows neutrophilic predominance, markedly low glucose, and elevated proteins, but the history in this case suggests a more chronic condition, ruling out bacterial meningitis.

 

Option D. Partially treated bacterial meningitis: Partially treated bacterial meningitis could alter the CSF profile by reducing neutrophil counts and making glucose levels less abnormal, but the history of 2 months of symptoms with lymphocyte predominance in CSF makes TB meningitis more likely.

 

Educational Objective:


Tubercular meningitis presents with chronic neurological symptoms, and CSF analysis shows high lymphocytes, low glucose, and high protein, along with cobweb coagulum formation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man visits a clinic with concerns about ano-rectal discharge but no pain, itching, or risky sexual behaviors. Based on the finding, which treatment kit should the physician prescribe? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Grey

 

The Grey kit is specifically formulated for conditions involving ano-rectal discharge, among other types of discharges. It contains Azithromycin and Cefixime, which are effective against the pathogens typically responsible for these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green Kit: Intended for vaginal discharge or vaginitis, not suitable for ano-rectal issues.

 

Option C. White Kit: Used for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, which does not align with the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Blue Kit: Aimed at patients with non-herpetic genital ulcers who are allergic to penicillin, also irrelevant for ano-rectal discharge without ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A health worker nurse experiences a needle stick injury with a needle known to be from HIV positive patient. She immediately seeks a confirmatory test for HIV. Which diagnostic test is considered the gold standard for confirming HIV status after such exposure? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Western Blot assay

 

The Western blot assay remains the definitive confirmatory test for HIV infection following an initial reactive screening test. It detects antibodies to multiple HIV proteins (e.g., gp41, p24, gp120) and provides band patterns that distinguish true positives from false positives. In the setting of occupational exposure, a positive or indeterminate Western blot after a reactive ELISA establishes the diagnosis and guides further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Though highly sensitive and used for initial screenings, ELISA is not specific enough alone for confirmatory testing.

 

Option B. p24 antigen assay: The p24 antigen can be detected earlier than antibodies, making it useful in acute infection. However, it is not the confirmatory gold standard—it is used primarily to shorten the diagnostic window when combined with antibody tests.

 

Option D. PCR: Although PCR is sensitive and can detect viral RNA early, the Western Blot is preferred for its protein-based confirmation in exposure cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Western blot assay is the gold standard confirmatory test for HIV infection following a reactive screening test.

questions.text: Dohlman's procedure is for: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker’s diverticulum

 

Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker's diverticulum.

 

ZENKER’S DIVERTICULUM

 

  • Symptoms of dysphagia after few swallows, gurgling sound while swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food is suggestive of Zenker’s diverticulum or hypopharyngeal pouch.
  • Most common site is Killian’s dehiscence which lies between the horizontal fibers cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of thyropharyngeus.
  • It is a pseudo-diverticulum (pulsion diverticulum)
  • It occurs due to the incoordination between Thyropharyngeus (supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)) and Cricopharyngeus (supplied by External laryngeal nerve (X)).
  • Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum

 

 

 

Dohlman’s Procedure:

 

  • This surgical procedure involves the excision or suspension of the diverticulum sac, typically using a minimally invasive approach. It aims to alleviate the obstructive symptoms by removing the diverticular sac, thus improving the passage of food from the pharynx to the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: An ileal diverticulum, not related to the pharyngoesophageal area.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: A congenital diaphragmatic hernia, unrelated to diverticula in the digestive or respiratory tracts.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: A rare, hyperplastic gastropathy involving the stomach lining, unrelated to pharyngeal or esophageal diverticula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum is managed surgically, primarily through procedures like Dohlman's, which address the underlying mechanical dysfunction causing the diverticulum. This treatment is focused on improving symptoms and preventing complications like aspiration or chronic inflammation from retained food.

questions.text: At a public health conference, a researcher emphasizes the importance of using robust datasets for health policy planning in India. Which agency is known for conducting extensive, ongoing surveys that collect health-related data? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. National Sample Survey

 

The National Sample Survey, operated by the National Sample Survey Organization (NSSO), is renowned for its extensive and systematic collection of data through large-scale surveys, which include health, family planning, and other vital statistics. This agency’s surveys provide valuable insights that are critical for understanding health trends and shaping public health policies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIIMS: Primarily focused on medical education and patient care rather than national data collection.

 

Option B. Central Bureau of Health: This entity does not exist as a recognized agency for data collection in India.

 

Option D. Sample Registration System: While important for demographic data, it is not as comprehensive as the National Sample Survey in terms of the breadth of health-related data collected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

National Sample Survey taken up by NSSO (National Sample Survey Organization).

 

It carries out large scale sample surveys that too in diverse fields, mainly based on household.

questions.text: A boy develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood report shows raised ketones, lactic acid and triglycerides. On examination, liver and kidney were found to be enlarged and patient is diagnosed with Von Gierke’s disease. which enzyme deficiency he has? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the final step of both glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen into glucose) and gluconeogenesis (formation of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources). In individuals with Von Gierke's disease, the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase results in impaired glucose release from glycogen, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acid maltase: Acid maltase, also known as alpha-glucosidase, is associated with Pompe's disease, which is a different glycogen storage disease. Pompe's disease is characterized by the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase.

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase: Glycogen synthase is not deficient in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Option D. G-6-PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase): G-6-PD deficiency is a different condition that primarily affects red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type Ia, is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

The clinical manifestations includes hypoglycemia after moderate activity, raised ketones, lactic acid, and triglycerides, along with hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) and nephromegaly (enlarged kidneys).

questions.text: Dead Body of fetus was found submerged in water by a local fisherman. The crown heel length was found to be 25 cm. Few hairs were present on his body and ossification center was present on the skull. Approximate age of the fetus is? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 months

 

At exactly 25 cm any of the Hasse’s rule can be used, and will give same result, that is 5 months (25/ 5 or Square root of 25 cm)

 

Rule of Hasse- a rough method of calculating approximate age of the fetus by measuring the crown to heel length of the fetus.

 

  1. Formula to be used if crown heel length is <25 cm (During the first 5 months of pregnancy):

 

Age (months)= square root of crown-heel length in centimeters

 

  1.  Formula to be used if crown heel length is >25 cm (During the last 5 months of pregnancy):

 

Age (months)= crown-heel length in centimeters divided by 5

 

Educational objective

 

The approximate age of the fetus can be calculated using Hasse's rule.

 

  • Formula for Crown Heel Length <25 cm (First 5 months of pregnancy)
  • Formula for Crown Heel Length >25 cm (Last 5 months of pregnancy)

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of sensorineural hearing loss? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Labyrinthitis

 

Labyrinthitis is a cause of sensorineural hearing loss while all others are causes of conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: This is primarily a cause of conductive hearing loss. It involves abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that can immobilize the stapes (stirrup bone), preventing sound waves from being transmitted effectively to the cochlea.

 

Option C. Ear wax: While excessive ear wax can cause hearing loss, it leads to conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural. This type of loss occurs when sound waves are physically blocked from reaching the inner ear.

 

Option D. CSOM (Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media): This condition also primarily causes conductive hearing loss. It is characterized by persistent ear infections that can lead to damage in the middle ear and eardrum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF ACQUIRED SNHL:

 

  1. Infections of labyrinth—viral, bacterial or spirochetal
  2. Trauma to labyrinth or VIIIth nerve, e.g., fractures of temporal bone or concussion of the labyrinth or the ear surgery
  3. Noise-induced hearing loss
  4. Ototoxic drugs
  5. Presbycusis
  6. Meniere’s disease
  7. Acoustic neuroma
  8. Sudden hearing loss
  9. Familial progressive SNHL
  10. Systemic disorders, e.g., diabetes, hypothyroidism, kidney disease, autoimmune disorders, multiple sclerosis, blood dyscrasias.

questions.text: 32-year-old woman is having progressive dysphagia. On examination she has thickening of oral mucosa and leather like skin. She is also hypertensive and has immense exercise capacity due to lung fibrosis. Which of the following is the possible diagnosis: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scleroderma

 

  • Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) a multisystem disorder characterized by

 

  1. Functional and structural abnormalities of blood Vessels
  2. Fibrosis of the skin and internal organs
  3. Immune system activation
  4. Autoimmunity

 

 

  • Prevalence: 4-12 new cases per million per year
  • Susceptibility: host factor

 

  1. Age – peak occurrence: age 35-65 years
  2. Gender- female male = 3-12:1
  3. Genetic background

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome: This is an inherited condition characterized by gastrointestinal polyps and pigmented spots on the skin and mucous membranes, not associated with skin thickening or lung fibrosis.

 

Option B. Post cricoid dysphagia: This condition refers to difficulty in swallowing due to structural abnormalities or obstructions in the post-cricoid region, not typically associated with systemic symptoms like skin thickening or lung fibrosis.

 

Option C. Achalasia cardia: Achalasia involves the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to progressive dysphagia. It does not involve skin or systemic symptoms like those seen in scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) involves skin thickening, internal organ fibrosis, and autoimmune features, leading to symptoms like dysphagia, hypertensive complications, and decreased exercise capacity due to lung fibrosis.

questions.text: Patient’s father has complained against the doctor for negligence leading to patient’s death and under which IPC section can the medical practitioner be held liable? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IPC 304 A

 

IPC Section 304A deals with “Causing death by rash or negligent act” so death by medical negligence is also covered in this section.

 

Professional Negligence

 

304 A IPC (causing death by rash or negligent act): Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished up to two years, or with fine, or with both.

 

The above section applies when death occurs due to negligence. If death does not occur but doctor was negligent then following sections will be applicable:

 

  1. 336 IPC: No injury occurred but negligence of patient endangered patient’s life
  2. 337 IPC: Causing Hurt by Negligence
  3. 338 IPC: Causing Grievous Hurt by Negligence

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPC 304 B: Punishment for dowry death

 

Option C. IPC 84:  Act of a person of unsound mind

 

Option D. IPC 302:  prescribes the punishment for murder

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical practitioners can be held liable under IPC 304 A for causing death due to rash or negligent acts, with a punishment of up to two years of imprisonment, or a fine, or both.

questions.text: Before traveling to a tropical area, a pregnant woman seeks advice on preventing Zika virus transmission, as travelling to tropical region. Which mosquito is the primary vector for Zika virus? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aedes aegypti

 

Aedes aegypti is the vector for Dengue, Chikungunya, Yellow Fever and Zika virus.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Sandfly is responsible for the transmission of Kala azar.

 

Option C. Culex transmits JE and Lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito acts as a vector in malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Lysosomal enzymes are present in:(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endoplasmic reticulum

 

Explanation

 

Lysosomes are the Principal Sites of Intracellular Digestion. Lysosomal enzymes are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum and then transported to the Golgi apparatus, where they are modified and packaged into lysosomes. Once inside lysosomes, these enzymes help to break down a variety of substances, including proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids.

 

They contain about 40 types of hydrolytic enzymes, including proteases, nucleases, glycosidases, lipases, phospholipases, phosphatases, and sulfatases

 

  • Proteases: enzymes that break down proteins into smaller peptides and amino acids.
  • Nucleases: enzymes that break down nucleic acids, such as DNA and RNA.
  • Glycosidases: enzymes that break down carbohydrates, such as sugars and glycogen.
  • Lipases: enzymes that break down lipids, such as fats and cholesterol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytosol: Incorrect because lysosomal enzymes are not free in the cytosol; they are contained within lysosomes.

 

Option B. Mitochondria: Incorrect as mitochondria do not contain lysosomal enzymes; they have their own distinct set of enzymes for cellular respiration.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Incorrect because the nucleus does not house lysosomal enzymes; it is primarily involved in storing and processing genetic information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomal enzymes are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum, further processed in the Golgi apparatus, and finally sorted into lysosomes where they aid in breaking down a variety of substances, playing a crucial role in the cellular degradation pathway.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The diagnosis based on the Image given is the Turners Syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features-

 

  • Short stature,
  • Shield chest,
  • Webbed neck,
  • Wide spread nipples and
  • Short fourth metacarpal.

 

Associated anomalies-

 

  • Cvs: coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Renal: horse shoe kidney.
  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.
  • Strabismus
  • Cataract.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.
  • Karyotype is indicated in all turner syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with gonadoblastoma).
  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.
  • Managements: GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: Down syndrome typically presents with intellectual disability, characteristic facial features (up-slanting palpebral fissures, flat nasal bridge), and single palmar crease. It does not show the webbed neck or wide-spaced nipples seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is seen in males and presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, and infertility, which is not consistent with the clinical features of the patient in the image.

 

Option D. Noonan syndrome: Noonan syndrome can present with features similar to Turner syndrome, including short stature and webbed neck, but it occurs in both males and females. It is associated with congenital heart disease, typically pulmonary stenosis, which differs from the coarctation of the aorta commonly seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome presents with short stature, shield chest, webbed neck, and is associated with cardiac (coarctation of the aorta) and renal anomalies (horseshoe kidney).

 

Ref - Essential paediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition – Page No-637

questions.text: PrP deposition is seen in? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CJD

 

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is caused by an abnormal infectious protein in the brain called a prion disease.
  • In this disease there is an abnormal folding of specific normal cellular proteins called prion proteins that are found in the brain.
  • It is characterized by change of PrP to PrPsc.
  • They are the most resistant form on earth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Rabies is a viral infection that affects the central nervous system, but it is not associated with prion proteins or PrP deposition.

 

Option C. Parkinson’s disease: This neurodegenerative disorder is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein proteins in Lewy bodies, not prion proteins.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s disease: Alzheimer's disease involves the accumulation of amyloid-beta plaques and neurofibrillary tangles of tau protein, not prion proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PrP deposition and the transformation of normal prion protein (PrPc) to its abnormal form (PrPsc) are characteristic features of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

questions.text: Which of the following Structure develops in the dorsal mesogastrium?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Spleen

 

Explanation

 

During embryonic development, the spleen develops with in the dorsal mesogastrium and is suspended by it. As development progresses, the spleen rotates into its normal position in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen while maintaining its connection to the dorsal mesogastrium.

 

Note - The dorsal mesogastrium is a double-layered fold of peritoneum that connects the stomach and other abdominal organs to the posterior abdominal wall during embryonic development. As the digestive system and other organs develop, various structures form within the dorsal mesogastrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Liver: The liver does not develop within the dorsal mesogastrium. Instead, the liver originates from endodermal tissue and is located in the upper right quadrant of the abdominal cavity. It has its own set of ligaments, including the falciform ligament and the lesser omentum, which are associated with its support and attachment.

 

Option B) Falciform Ligament: The falciform ligament is a thin, fold of peritoneum that extends from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver. It does not develop within the dorsal mesogastrium but rather serves to suspend the liver from the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Option D) Lesser Omentum: The lesser omentum is a double-layered fold of peritoneum that connects the liver and the stomach. While it is associated with the liver, it does not develop within the dorsal mesogastrium. Instead, it forms as part of the development of the digestive organs in the abdominal cavity.

 

Educational Objective

 

Spleen develops in the mesenchyme of the dorsal mesogastrium. Lesser omentum in falciform ligament and liver develop in ventral mesogastrium.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma of the breast presents with swelling of the ankle for the past 3 months. Urinary examination showed heavy proteinuria and hematuria. Renal biopsy is likely to reveal? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MGN

 

The patient with carcinoma of the breast presents with swelling of the ankle for the past 3 months, heavy proteinuria, and hematuria. This clinical picture is most suggestive of secondary Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.

 

Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN):

 

  • Association with Malignancies: MGN is frequently associated with malignancies such as breast cancer. This is due to the immune complex deposition that occurs in the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Nephrotic Syndrome Characteristics: High proteinuria (nephrotic range proteinuria), hypoalbuminemia, and edema are typical. Hematuria can also be present.
  • Renal Biopsy Findings: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial immune deposits. There is typically no significant inflammation seen in MGN.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): Characteristics: FSGS is characterized by segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli. It is less commonly associated with malignancies and is more frequently seen in younger patients or those with conditions like HIV, heroin use, or obesity.

 

Option B. Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN): Characteristics: MPGN is characterized by intense inflammation, mesangial proliferation, and double contour (tram-track) appearance of the glomerular basement membrane. It is associated with immune complex deposition and is commonly linked with infections (e.g., hepatitis C) or autoimmune diseases. Crescents on biopsy are indicative of severe inflammation, which is not typical in malignancy-associated nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Minimal Change Disease (MCD): Characteristics: MCD is more common in children and presents with minimal changes on light microscopy but with effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. It is rare in elderly patients and not typically associated with malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary Membranous Glomerulonephritis (MGN) is the most likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with a history of carcinoma of the breast, presenting with heavy proteinuria, hematuria, and swelling of the ankle. MGN is commonly linked with malignancies and is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly. Renal biopsy would reveal thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial immune deposits.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was brought to the ER with altered sensorium and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and icterus. Lab investigations show AST ratio of 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcoholic liver disease

 

The patient's presentation with jaundice, altered sensorium, rapid shallow breathing, distended abdomen, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and the presence of spider nevi (as shown in the image) is suggestive of liver disease. The laboratory finding of an AST ratio of 3:1 is highly indicative of alcoholic liver disease.

 

Alcoholic liver disease typically presents with the following characteristics:

 

  • Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin.
  • Hepatomegaly and Splenomegaly: Enlarged liver and spleen.
  • Spider Nevi: These are small, spider-like blood vessels visible under the skin.
  • Altered Sensorium: Confusion or altered level of consciousness, possibly indicating hepatic encephalopathy.
  • AST Ratio: An AST ratio greater than 2:1, especially around 3:1, is a classic marker for alcoholic liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute viral hepatitis: Typically presents with very high levels of AST and ALT, often greater than 500 U/L. The AST ratio is usually less than 1.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hepatitis: Usually has elevated AST and ALT in the range of 200-1000 U/L. It also often includes extrahepatic manifestations, such as arthralgia, skin rashes, and thyroiditis.

 

Option D. Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) poisoning: Presents with very high levels of AST and ALT, often greater than 1000 U/L, and is associated with acute liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic liver disease is suggested by the presence of jaundice, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, spider nevi, altered sensorium, and an AST ratio of 3:1. This condition is distinguished from other liver diseases by these clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male chronic alcoholic abstained from alcohol. 2 days later he was brought to the emergency with disorientation, tremors, hallucination, and hypertension. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by acute onset of confusion (disorientation), tremors, hallucinations (which can be visual, auditory, or tactile), and autonomic hyperactivity such as hypertension and tachycardia. DT carries a high risk of mortality due to the sympathetic autonomic surge, which can lead to cardiovascular collapse and arrhythmias.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff psychosis: This condition is characterized by severe memory disturbances, particularly anterograde amnesia and confabulation, and is usually a chronic condition following Wernicke encephalopathy. The acute symptoms of disorientation, tremors, and autonomic instability described in this patient are not typical of Korsakoff psychosis.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hallucinosis: This condition involves hallucinations, typically auditory, that occur during alcohol withdrawal but without the severe autonomic symptoms (e.g., hypertension) and disorientation seen in DT. Hallucinations in alcoholic hallucinosis occur within 12-48 hours after cessation of drinking.

 

Option D. Marchiafava-Bignami syndrome: This is a rare neurological condition associated with chronic alcoholism, characterized by the demyelination of the corpus callosum. It presents with symptoms such as epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, and spastic limb paralysis, rather than the acute withdrawal symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition that occurs 48-72 hours after alcohol withdrawal, characterized by disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity such as hypertension.

questions.text: A mother with her preterm newborn is worried as the newborn hasn't passed the meconium till now. What is the maximum time to wait for meconium to pass in this infant? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 48 hours

 

  • The normal newborn will pass urine within 24 hrs and Meconium within 48 hrs.
  • The time taken to reach air to the descending colon is 8-9 hrs.
  • Delayed passage of meconium is seen in case of Hirschsprung's disease

 

Meconium is often evacuated within 6 hours of birth or earlier, however it can be delayed up to 24-48 hours.

 

 

Pancreatic atresia or pancreatic duct stenosis may also cause meconium ileus.

 

Educational Objective:


A normal newborn should pass meconium within 48 hours after birth; delays beyond this may indicate Hirschsprung's disease or other gastrointestinal pathology.

choices.text: Eye injury

questions.text: The ophthalmic surgical instrument shown in the figure is used in which of the following conditions?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chalazion

 

The instrument shown in the image is a chalazion forcep.

 

Chalazion is a cyst that forms in the eyelid as a result of blockage of sebaceous glands of the tarsal plate.

 

A chalazion forceps is a self-retaining type of thumb forceps that has discoid ends. One arm has a flattened plate at its End, which is round and solid. The other arm has a matching ring that fits into the opposite arm’s solid plate. There is an adjustable screw at the middle of the plates, which can be tightened until it has a firm and fine grip to the cyst.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eye injury: While various forceps can be used in the management of eye injuries, the specific design of the chalazion forceps, with its discoid ends and adjustable screw, is tailored for isolating and holding chalazia rather than general eye injuries.

 

Option B. Ectropion: Ectropion is the outward turning of the eyelid margin. The management of ectropion typically involves procedures to tighten or reposition the eyelid, often requiring different surgical instruments such as scissors, needle holders, and suturing materials rather than chalazion forceps.

 

Option D. Bitot’s spot: Bitot’s spots are foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, usually associated with vitamin A deficiency. The treatment involves addressing the underlying nutritional deficiency, and surgical instruments are generally not required. Chalazion forceps would not be used in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chalazion forceps are specifically designed for the surgical treatment of chalazia, providing a secure grip on the eyelid and the cyst during the procedure

choices.text: X Ray guided drainage of peritoneal accumulation
Insert Flatus tube and repeat X ray

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute abdominal pain to the casualty. He has history of taking painkillers for a month due to dental pain. X-Ray abdomen was done in erect position. Which of the following is correct about management of this condition? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given the scenario of acute abdominal pain, NSAID abuse, and the presence of free gas under the diaphragm on an erect X-ray of the abdomen, the most likely diagnosis is a hollow viscous perforation. NSAIDs are known to cause peptic ulcers, which can perforate. The definitive management for this condition is exploratory laparotomy. During this surgical procedure, the surgeon will directly visualize the perforation, repair it, and perform a thorough washout of the peritoneal cavity to prevent infection and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Drain the peritoneal fluid:
    • Draining the peritoneal fluid can be helpful in diagnosing the nature of the fluid (whether it's pus, blood, or digestive juices). However, it doesn't address the root cause of the issue, which is the perforation. Thus, while draining might be done as part of a diagnostic paracentesis to understand the nature of the fluid, it isn't the definitive treatment for a perforation.
  • Option B. X-Ray guided drainage of peritoneal accumulation:
    • While image-guided drainage can be useful for localized collections like abscesses, it isn't the right choice for generalized peritoneal fluid accumulation due to a perforation. The perforation itself needs to be addressed, which requires surgical intervention.
  • Option D. Insert Flatus tube and repeat X-ray:
    • A flatus tube, or rectal tube, is a device inserted into the rectum to relieve built-up gas in the colon. After doing so, an X-ray might be repeated to evaluate the situation. While a flatus tube can help relieve excessive gas, it wouldn't address a perforation. It's more typically used for conditions like postoperative paralytic ileus, not for managing hollow viscous perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of suspected hollow viscous perforation, especially in the presence of free gas under the diaphragm on X-ray, the definitive management is exploratory laparotomy to repair the perforation and prevent further complications.

choices.text: He is at a risk of intestinal obstruction
It’s a case of body packer’s syndrome

questions.text: A man at an airport was found in an agitated state and was shouting at passersby following which he suddenly collapsed. An Xray chest and abdomen showed the below picture.  All of the following are true regarding this case except? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The person is malingering

 

Malingering involves feigning illness or symptoms. The X-ray evidence clearly indicates the presence of ingested packets, confirming a genuine medical condition.

 

Body packers are those that carry drugs such as heroin or cocaine, packed in rubber or plastic, in his/her body cavity in order to smuggle them. These people can present with symptoms from mild to severe ranging from respiratory insufficiency to even death. Physical examination and additional radiology tests are helpful for the diagnosis. Any packages can usually be seen on a plain abdominal X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal scan is mandatory: True. It is essential to further evaluate the presence and integrity of the packets.

 

Option C. He is at a risk of intestinal obstruction: True. The presence of multiple packets can lead to obstruction or rupture.

 

Option D. It’s a case of body packer’s syndrome: True. The X-ray findings are characteristic of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of body packer's syndrome, an abdominal scan is mandatory, and the individual is at risk of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray findings confirm the presence of ingested drug packets, ruling out malingering.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy often has difficulty in writing and he tends to make multiple spelling mistakes. His IQ level is normal and he is good at mathematics. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Specific learning disorder

 

The boy's presentation of difficulty with writing and multiple spelling mistakes, despite having a normal IQ and competence in other academic areas such as mathematics, suggests a specific learning disorder.

 

Other Options:
