Option B. Mental retardation (now called Intellectual Disability): Would manifest with deficits in general intellectual functioning across multiple areas, not just one specific skill like writing.

 

Option C. Depression: While it can affect academic performance, it would present with additional symptoms such as persistent sadness, anhedonia, and changes in appetite or sleep.

 

Option D. Exam phobia: Would be specific anxiety or stress related to examinations and not a persistent difficulty with a particular academic skill.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Specific learning disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by significant impairment in one or more of the scholastic skills which are out of proportion to the intellectual functioning of the child. Children with this disorder often excel in areas not affected by the disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 141

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with rapidly enlarging breast lump which is firm, mobile and does not have any lymph nodes involved. What could be the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brodie’s serocystic disease

 

The clinical picture (rapidly growing breast lump without any lymph node involvement) and the image shown are suggestive of Brodie’s serocystic disease.

 

Brodie’s serocystic disease is also called as Phyllodes tumor / Cystosarcoma phyllodes.

 

Origin - mammary epithelium & stroma

 

Appearance leaf like appearance on cut section

 

Spread – through blood vessels (hematogenous)

 

Investigation of choice – Biopsy

 

Most common site of metastasis: lungs

 

Management: Wide local excision or simple mastectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibroadenoma (Breast Mouse) is a mobile benign breast tumor. It is commonly seen in younger women. Clinically, it is a smooth, round, rubbery palpable lump. On Mammogram, popcorn calcification is seen (BIRADS 2). Its management involves Excision or enucleation.

 

Option C. Breast Cancer presents with a lump, commonly in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. By the time of presentation, axillary lymph nodes are commonly involved. There are also nipple changes and discharge. Its management depends on the staging of the cancer.

 

Option D. Galactocele is a benign cystic swelling that can develop in the breast tissue during lactation. It occurs as a result of milk accumulation within the mammary ducts. It is typically painless and may present as a smooth, round and mobile lump in the breast.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brodie’s serocystic disease, also known as Phyllodes tumor or Cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a rapidly enlarging breast lump without lymph node involvement and is characterized by its leaf-like appearance on cut section. The investigation of choice is a biopsy, and management involves wide local excision or simple mastectomy.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Local anesthetic agents? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocking voltage gated sodium channel

 

Local anesthetics primarily work by blocking the voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve cells. By doing so, they prevent the influx of sodium ions, thus inhibiting the propagation of action potentials along nerve fibers. This prevents the sensation of pain from being transmitted to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blocking of calcium channel: Local anesthetics mainly target the sodium channels, but some can also have minor effects on calcium channels. However, calcium channel blockade is not their primary mechanism of pain inhibition.

 

Option C. Opening Sodium channels: This is not a recognized mechanism of action for local anesthetics.

 

Option D. Opening of potassium channel: Opening potassium channels would lead to the hyperpolarization of the nerve membrane, making it less likely to fire an action potential. While some drugs do act by opening potassium channels, this is not the primary mechanism by which local anesthetics function.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Local anesthetics primarily work by blocking the voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 872

choices.text: Bacterial corneal ulcer
Giant papillary conjunctivitis

questions.text: A 22-year-old lady has been wearing contact lens for the past two years. She presents with the complaints of pain and redness in the eyes and decreased vision. What is the most common differential diagnosis in this case?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial corneal ulcer

 

  • Contact lens wear is a common predisposing factor for bacterial keratitis and is one of the preventable risk factors for corneal infection in working age population.
  • A bacterial corneal ulcer, or bacterial keratitis, is an infection of the corneal stroma that causes rapid visual loss and pain. Infectious corneal ulcers need to be treated as soon as possible to preserve vision.
  • It is most commonly caused by pseudomonas and can destroy the cornea within 48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant papillary conjunctivitis: This condition can be caused by prolonged contact lens wear and results in redness and irritation of the eyes. However, it typically does not cause significant pain or decreased vision, which makes it less likely to be the primary diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Fungal keratitis: Although fungal keratitis can occur in contact lens wearers, it is less common than bacterial keratitis. Fungal infections usually progress more slowly and are less likely to present with the acute and severe symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. HSV keratitis: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) keratitis is not typically associated with contact lens wear. HSV keratitis usually presents with recurrent episodes of corneal infection and may include symptoms such as pain and redness, but contact lens use is not a predisposing factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial corneal ulcer, or bacterial keratitis, is the most common differential diagnosis in a contact lens wearer presenting with pain, redness, and decreased vision. It is primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and requires immediate treatment to prevent rapid and severe vision loss.

choices.text: From bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles
From AV node to bundle of His
From purkinje fibers to ventricles
Throughout His-Purkinje system

questions.text: The HV interval in the given His-bundle electrogram represents which of the following? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From bundle of his and Bundle branches to ventricles

 

The HV interval refers to the conduction time from the His bundle to the ventricles. In the context of an intracardiac electrocardiogram (ECG), this interval is crucial for assessing the conduction time through the His-Purkinje system, which includes the bundle of His and the bundle branches leading to the ventricles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. From AV node to bundle of His: This would be represented by the AH interval, not the HV interval.

 

Option C. From Purkinje fibers to ventricles: This is a part of the HV interval but not the entire interval; the HV interval includes conduction through the His bundle and bundle branches as well.

 

Option D. Throughout His-Purkinje system: While the HV interval does reflect conduction through a portion of the His-Purkinje system, it is specifically from the His bundle to the ventricles, not the entire His-Purkinje system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

HV interval refers to conduction from H (His bundle, bundle branches) to V(ventricles)

choices.text: Apply heat to the area and cast as soon as possible

questions.text: A patient who is a tour guide on Mount Everest presented with blisters on the foot as shown. The patient has severe pain and the examination reveals erythema and tenderness. Which of the following is not used in the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apply heat to the area and cast as soon as possible.

 

Given the history and the image showing blisters on the hand, the condition is suggestive of frostbite. Frostbite is a cold-induced injury that causes tissue damage due to freezing and reduced blood flow. The management of frostbite involves several key steps, and applying heat directly or casting the area is not recommended.

 

Management of Frostbite:

 

  1. Initial Analgesics: Pain management is crucial, often starting with NSAIDs.
  2. Rewarming: Rapid rewarming in a water bath at 40-42°C (104-107.6°F) is recommended to thaw the affected tissues.
  3. Cleaning the Wound: Careful cleaning and debridement of the wound if necessary.
  4. Antibiotics: Empirical antibiotics are not routinely recommended but may be considered if there is a risk of infection.
  5. Prostacyclin and Thrombolytics: IV prostacyclin and intra-arterial thrombolytics (t-PA) can be used for severe cases and pain control.
  6. Amputation: In severe cases where tissue damage is extensive and irreversible, amputation may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pentoxifylline: This drug is sometimes used to improve blood flow in cases of frostbite.

 

Option B. NSAID: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are commonly used for pain management in frostbite.

 

Option D. Oxygen supplementation: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can be considered in severe frostbite to improve oxygenation and reduce tissue damage.

 

Applying direct heat to the frostbitten area can cause further tissue damage and is not recommended. Casting the area can also impede necessary treatment and monitoring of the frostbitten tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of frostbite, avoid applying direct heat or casting the affected area. Proper management includes rewarming, pain control, wound cleaning, and in severe cases, considering thrombolytic therapy and possibly amputation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of a female? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rectouterine pouch

 

Explanation:

 

  • The rectouterine pouch, also known as the pouch of Douglas, is the most dependent part of a female pelvis.
  • Being the lowest point in the female peritoneal cavity, it is the site where fluid accumulates when there is intraperitoneal bleeding or infection.
  • This area is clinically significant because it can be assessed for the presence of fluid collection, such as blood in cases of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, by performing a culdocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian fossa: The ovarian fossa is a shallow depression on the lateral wall of the pelvis where the ovary resides. It is not the most dependent part of the female pelvis.

 

Option C. Posterior fornix: The posterior fornix is a recess formed by the vagina around the cervix. Although it is a low point in the vagina, it is not the most dependent part of the pelvic cavity.

 

Option D. Vesicouterine pouch: The vesicouterine pouch is an area between the bladder and the uterus. It is higher than the rectouterine pouch and therefore not the most dependent part of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas) is the most dependent part of the female pelvis, making it the primary site for the collection of fluid from intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 442, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text:
A patient presents with chronic small bowel diarrhea and says that he is allergic to wheat. Duodenal biopsy shows villous atrophy. Anti-endomysial antibodies and TTG IgA antibodies are positive. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)

 

TTG - tissue transglutaminase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Celiac sprue

 

A positive serological test for anti-endomysial antibodies and IgA anti-TTG antibodies along with villous atrophy on duodenal biopsies point to the diagnosis of celiac disease.

 

Most all patients with celiac disease express (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, which facilitate the immune response against gluten proteins (gliadin).


Gluten is present in → barley, rye, oat, wheat → Resulting in loss of bowel villi → Associated with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Signs and Symptoms

 

  • Abnormal liver function
  • Vomiting
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Neurologic dysfunction
  • Constipation
  • Nausea
  • Common
  • Diarrhea
  • Fatigue
  • Borborygmus
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal distention
  • Flatulence

 

Diagnosis of Celiac Disease

 

  • Clinical Findings
  • Small Intestines Mucosal Biopsy
  • Gluten Re-challenge

 

Serologic testing

 

  • IgA antigliadin antibodies
  • IgA endomysial antibodies
  • IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies

 

Management of Celiac Disease

 

  • Gluten avoidance is the mainstay of treatment
  • Prior to the introduction of a strict gluten-free diet, prognosis was very poor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis: This is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs, pancreas, and intestines. It primarily causes thick mucus production leading to respiratory and digestive problems. Celiac disease is not related to cystic fibrosis.

 

Option B. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection affecting the small intestine, leading to malabsorption. While it can cause diarrhea and weight loss, it is diagnosed by the presence of Tropheryma whipplei bacteria in the biopsy, not villous atrophy or positive serologic markers for celiac disease.

 

Option C. Tropical sprue: This condition mimics celiac disease with similar symptoms but occurs in people living in or visiting tropical regions. It is treated with antibiotics and folic acid supplements. Unlike celiac disease, it is not caused by gluten ingestion.

 

Educational Objective:


Celiac disease is characterized by villous atrophy on biopsy and is diagnosed by positive anti-endomysial and TTG IgA antibodies. The treatment is lifelong gluten avoidance.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 387- Page No 8386.

questions.text: Which of the following proteoglycans is responsible for maintaining the transparency of cornea?  (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

Keratan sulphate is a proteoglycan that plays a crucial role in maintaining the transparency of the cornea. The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber. For the cornea to remain transparent, it must stay in a dehydrated state, be avascular, have a regular arrangement of corneal lamellae, and contain unmyelinated nerve fibers. Keratan sulphate contributes to this transparency by being a key component of the corneal stroma, which helps in maintaining the precise arrangement of collagen fibrils necessary for optimal light transmission through the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondroitin sulphate: While chondroitin sulphate is important for maintaining the compressibility of cartilage in weight-bearing joints, it does not play a primary role in the transparency of the cornea.

 

Option C. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid facilitates cell migration and is involved in the compressibility of cartilage. It also plays a role in wound healing and maintaining the viscoelastic properties of certain tissues, but it is not directly responsible for corneal transparency.

 

Option D. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is involved in various biological processes including anticoagulant action, cell adhesion, and determining the charge selectiveness of the renal glomerulus. It is also a component of plasma membranes and synaptic vesicles. However, it is not primarily responsible for maintaining corneal transparency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Corneal transparency is maintained by:

 

  • Dehydrated state (hydration leads to loss of transparency)
  • Avascularity
  • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae
  • Unmyelinated nerve fibres

questions.text: In a study at a rehabilitation center, participants were divided into those who were divorced and those who were not, to investigate the influence of past substance use. What type of study was employed? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Case Control study

 

This study is classified as a Case-Control study because it begins with an outcome (divorce) and retrospectively examines the exposure (substance use) to determine if there is a correlation. Participants were categorized based on their marital status, and their past behavior was analyzed to establish any significant differences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Incorrect for this scenario as RCTs involve intervention and random assignment, not retrospective analysis.

 

Option B. Cohort study: Not suitable here since cohort studies track subjects based on their exposure status forward in time to observe future outcomes.

 

Option D. Descriptive study: This option does not fit because descriptive studies do not typically examine the relationship between variables through comparison of outcomes based on different exposures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Case-Control study is effective for exploring associations between exposure factors and outcomes by comparing subjects with the outcome to those without, making it ideal for examining links between behaviors like substance use and social outcomes such as divorce.

 

Exposure & Outcome in Analytical Studies

questions.text: Beta blockers should be avoided in all of the following conditions except?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glaucoma

 

Beta blockers like Timolol, Betaxolol reduce aqueous humour production and are used in the treatment of glaucoma. They work by reducing the production of aqueous humor, thereby lowering intraocular pressure (IOP), which is a critical factor in the management of glaucoma. Glaucoma is an eye condition that can lead to vision loss if not properly managed, and lowering IOP is a primary goal of treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peripheral vascular disease: Beta blockers can exacerbate symptoms of peripheral vascular disease (PVD) by causing vasoconstriction, which can lead to reduced blood flow to the extremities and worsening of PVD symptoms.

 

Option C. COPD: Beta blockers can cause bronchoconstriction, which can be particularly problematic for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This can lead to increased difficulty in breathing and exacerbations of COPD.

 

Option D. Diabetes: Beta blockers can mask the symptoms of hypoglycemia (such as tachycardia) and prolong hypoglycemia by interfering with glucose metabolism. This makes them less suitable for patients with diabetes, especially those on insulin or other hypoglycemic agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta Blockers

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the CT scan below. (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horseshoe kidney

 

  • The image shows CT abdomen with both kidneys fused together from the hilum. This is called horseshoe Kidney.
    • Features of horseshoe kidney - symptoms may occur from hydronephrosis, stones, infection.
    • Lower abdominal pain may be present at times.
    • Flower vase appearance on IVU.

 

Management of horseshoe kidney – Conservative management

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancake Kidney is also called discoid kidney or fused pelvic kidney. It is an incidental finding. The upper and lower poles of the kidneys are fused hence giving it an appearance of a pancake. It is usually located anterior to the bifurcation of aorta.

 

 

Option B. Polycystic Kidney: It is genetic disorder characterized by presence of cystic masses in the one or both kidneys. It could be autosomal dominant or recessive disorder. ADPKD is found associated with cerebral berry aneurysms, hypertension, colonic diverticulosis, bicuspid aortic valve, mitral valve prolapse, aortic dissection etc. ARPKD is seen commonly in children and is associated with Caroli disease and hepatic fibrosis.

 

 

Option D. Renal Cell Cancer: It is also called as Hypernephroma or Grawitz tumor. It is a primary malignant adenocarcinoma derived from renal tubular epithelium. There are variants of RCC which appear differently on CECT. The most common of RCC called as Clear Cell Variant is shown below –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horseshoe kidney is characterized by the fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys, forming a U-shape, and is the most common type of renal fusion anomaly.

choices.text: CCF (Congestive cardiac failure)

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with hypertension presented with dyspnea on exertion for one week. Examination showed elevated JVP, fine crackles in both lung fields, and palpable liver. What is the likely physical examination finding that is shown? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pitting pedal edema

 

The images provided show pitting pedal edema, which is a clinical finding often associated with congestive cardiac failure (CCF). CCF results in increased filling pressures due to systolic or diastolic dysfunction, leading to fluid accumulation in the interstitial tissues, such as in the lower extremities, causing pitting edema.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): This typically causes unilateral, painful limb edema, rather than the bilateral pitting edema shown in the image.

 

Option C. Superficial vein thrombosis: This condition causes severe localized pain and inflammation but does not typically result in significant limb swelling.

 

Option D. CCF (Congestive cardiac failure): While CCF is the underlying condition, it is not the direct physical examination finding shown in the image. The examination finding is pitting pedal edema, which is a symptom of CCF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pitting pedal edema, often associated with congestive cardiac failure, is a clinical finding characterized by the indentation left after pressing on the swollen area, indicating fluid accumulation in the interstitial spaces.

questions.text: An epidemiology graduate is analyzing a graph that delineates the timing of disease detection through screening. The graph segments from point B, representing the initial detection through screening, to point C, marking a crucial diagnostic milestone. What does the duration between points B and C represent? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Screening time

 

The segment from point B to point C in the graph reflects the Screening time, which is the interval from when a disease is first detected by a screening test to when it reaches a critical stage of diagnosis. This period highlights the advantage of early detection and its potential to alter the disease management path effectively.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead time: This covers the period from early detection to the usual diagnosis time, which is not relevant to points B to C.

 

Option C. Incubation time: This refers to the time from infection to the onset of symptoms, unrelated to screening or diagnosis timing.

 

Option D. Latent period: This is the interval when an individual is infected but not yet infectious, which does not pertain to the diagnostic process described in the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Screening time" between points B and C on the disease detection timeline graph is critical for understanding the benefits of early diagnostic interventions in managing diseases more effectively.

questions.text: A 8-day old neonate with respiratory distress showed the following findings on chest X-ray. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia is the diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and X-ray.

 

Bochdalek hernia is the most prevalent type of it.

 

It is caused by a deficiency in the pleuroperitoneal membrane in the Posterolateral aspect.

 

Morgagni hernia is caused by a deficiency in the anterior pleuroperitoneal membrane.

 

Pathophysiology and cause

 

  • Cause is unknown
  • Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing embryo Abdominal contents herniate and compress the ipsilateral developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension.

 

Types of congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia: Poster lateral (occurring at approximately 6 weeks' gestation) Morgagni hernia: Morgagni hernia: Anteromedial - The hiatus hernia

 

Protrusion of abdominal organs through opening in diaphragm.

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Mild to severe respiratory distress
  • Tachypnea, cyanosis, dyspnea
  • Absent breath sound.
  • Shock.

 

Three general presentations:

 

Severe respiratory distress Severe respiratory distress at the time of birth. (Severe hypoplasia) Respiratory deterioration hours after delivery (honeymoon period).

 

Benefit from correction of hypoxemia and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Diagnosis - Therapeutic Symptoms Radiographic study.

 

Prenatally as early as 25 weeks of gestation.

 

Therapeutic

 

Supportive treatment of respiratory distress (Use of end tracheal intubation, oxygenation).

 

Prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Surgical reduction of hernia and repair of defect.

 

Surgical Care - Antenatal

 

Open Fetal Surgery:

 

  • Involves removing compression on the abdominal viscera in the fetus.
  • Considered high-risk for both the mother and the fetus.
  • Does not provide a survival advantage.

 

Fetal Tracheal Occlusion:

 

  • Involves stimulating lung growth in the fetus by accumulating fluid in the lungs.
  • Results in larger but persistent abnormal lungs.

 

Steroid Therapy:

 

  • Administering steroids weekly can help improve lung function in foetuses.
  • However, the use of steroids in this context is controversial.
  • This is because there is a risk of adverse effects on brain and body development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) is a developmental anomaly of the lung characterized by cystic lesions in the lung. However, this does not present with herniated abdominal organs on imaging.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic cysts: Bronchogenic cysts are benign cysts that develop from abnormal budding of the bronchial tree. These typically present as mediastinal masses on imaging, not as herniated abdominal organs.

 

Option D. Hyaline membrane disease: Hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome) presents in preterm infants with diffuse lung disease due to surfactant deficiency. It does not show herniated organs or diaphragmatic defects on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH), particularly Bochdalek hernia, is a diaphragmatic defect that leads to herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, causing severe respiratory distress due to lung compression and pulmonary hypoplasia.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition – Page No- 3855-3856

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presented with a swollen knee after suffering a trauma. Which of the following is the likely condition seen in this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8 deficiency

 

Hemophilia-A is a genetic disorder that affects primarily males due to a mutation in the gene responsible for producing factor VIII. Symptoms include bleeding in joints and deep tissues, but petechiae and purpura are usually not present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand disease: is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, with many different variants. The most common type is autosomal dominant, specifically type-1 VWD. Clinically, this type presents with mild bleeding of the mucous membranes or skin.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP): ITP is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of platelets, leading to petechiae, purpura, and mucocutaneous bleeding. Joint bleeding is not a common feature of ITP.

 

Option D. Vitamin K deficiency: is characterized by a lack of gamma carboxylation in clotting factors, which is necessary for their proper function. This deficiency can occur in newborns, individuals on long-term antibiotics, and those with malabsorption conditions. Vitamin K is essential for gamma carboxylating factor II, VII, XI, X, Protein-C, and Protein-S.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor 8 deficiency (Hemophilia A) is characterized by bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) following trauma due to impaired clot formation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of chest pain seen on exertion or exercise lasting for 3-5 minutes. The patient has persistently elevated BP and has been diagnosed with stable angina. What is the most appropriate drug? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atenolol

 

The treatment of stable angina typically involves the use of beta-blockers, which improve coronary perfusion and decrease myocardial oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility. Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is therefore the most appropriate choice in this case.


Atenolol:

 

  • Mechanism: Beta-blocker that reduces heart rate, contractility, and blood pressure, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand.
  • Indication: First-line treatment for stable angina to prevent angina episodes and improve exercise tolerance.
  • Additional Benefits: Beta-blockers have been shown to improve survival in patients with coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Enalapril:

 

  • Mechanism: ACE inhibitor that helps prevent remodeling of the heart, reduces afterload, and has a beneficial effect on blood pressure.
  • Indication: More commonly used in patients with heart failure, diabetic nephropathy, and hypertension. It is not the first-line treatment for stable angina.

 

Option B. Thiazide:

 

  • Mechanism: Diuretic that helps reduce blood pressure by reducing fluid volume.
  • Indication: Used in hypertension and heart failure but not specifically for stable angina. It helps in volume overload conditions.

 

Option C. Amlodipine:

 

  • Mechanism: Calcium channel blocker (CCB) that reduces myocardial oxygen demand by dilating coronary arteries and reducing afterload.
  • Indication: Used in hypertension and angina, including stable angina. However, beta-blockers are generally preferred as the first-line treatment for stable angina due to their additional benefits in improving survival in coronary artery disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers like atenolol are the first-line treatment for stable angina as they improve coronary perfusion and decrease myocardial oxygen demand. Other medications like ACE inhibitors, thiazide diuretics, and calcium channel blockers can be used based on the patient's overall condition but are not the primary choice for stable angina.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1700 mL

 

As per history given the child weight is 30 kg needs 1700 cc of maintenance fluid each day.

 

For this calculation daily maintenance fluid, the following table is considered.

 

 

Calculation:

 

As per the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs.

 

So, the formula for >20 Kg is used.

 

1500 mL + (20 mL × weight more than 20 Kgs)

 

Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more.

 

Therefore, fluid required is

 

= 1500 mL + (20 mL × 10)

 

= 1500 mL + 200 mL

 

= 1700 mL/1700cc

 

Educational Objective:


To calculate daily maintenance fluid for children, use the formula based on their weight, adjusting for ranges over 10 and 20 kg.

questions.text: A 32-year- old female died within 7 years of marriage. The cause of death was suspected as dowry. Who will perform the inquest in this case? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Magistrate

 

It is a case of Dowry death, hence the inquest will be done by magistrate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Police officer:

 

  • Police Inquest (174 CrPC):
    • Description: The most common type of inquest conducted in India.
    • Conducted by: A police officer of at least the rank of head constable.
    • Application: Used for investigating most types of deaths, including those that occur under suspicious circumstances but do not specifically fall under the categories requiring a magistrate inquest.
    • Limitations: Not used for specific cases like dowry deaths, custodial deaths, or exhumations which require a higher level of oversight.

 

Option C. Member of Parliament:

 

  • Role: A Member of Parliament (MP) is a representative elected to the legislative body of the government.
    • Relevance: MPs do not have any legal authority to conduct inquests or investigations into deaths. Their role is legislative and political, not investigative or judicial.
    • Application: MPs can raise issues in the parliament, propose new laws, or amend existing laws, but they do not perform inquests or judicial functions.

 

Option D. Judge:

 

  • Role: A judge presides over court proceedings and makes decisions in legal cases.
    • Relevance: Judges are involved in the judicial process of trying cases and delivering judgments, but they do not typically perform inquests.
    • Application: Judges may review the findings of inquests and trials, but the inquest itself is conducted by a magistrate or police officer, depending on the circumstances.
    • Limitation: Their primary role is to adjudicate cases brought before the court, not to conduct initial death investigations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

questions.text: A young female presented with abdominal swelling. The swelling was moving perpendicular to the line of attachment of mesentery. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylolymphatic cyst

 

Tillaux sign: Swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery.

 

  • This sign is seen in mesenteric cyst.
  • Most common type of mesenteric cysts are Chylolymphatic and Enterogenous cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudocyst: A pseudocyst is a fluid-filled sac in the abdomen that resembles a true cyst but lacks an epithelial lining. It usually develops as a complication of acute or chronic pancreatitis.Although pseudocysts can present as abdominal swelling, they are typically related to a history of pancreatitis and are located around the pancreas. They do not exhibit the Tillaux sign, which is specific to mesenteric cysts.

 

Option C. Fat Nodule: They can be present anywhere in the body but are most commonly seen in the subcutaneous tissue. The characteristic mobility in the question is not related to fat nodules.

 

Option D. Peritoneal Cyst: A cyst arising from the peritoneum. These are relatively rare and can vary in size.While a peritoneal cyst could theoretically present as an abdominal swelling, the specificity of the Tillaux sign strongly suggests a mesenteric origin, as it indicates movement perpendicular to the mesentery's attachment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Tillaux sign, which indicates a swelling moving perpendicular to the line of attachment of the mesentery, is specific for mesenteric cysts, most commonly chylolymphatic cysts.

choices.text: Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
HIV infected women

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication of the device shown below? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV infected women

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is Copper-T 380A, which is an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).
  • HIV-infected women can use IUCDs as long as they are clinically well and not at risk of acquiring more sexually transmitted infections.
  • Absolute contraindications for an IUCD include:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Suspected pregnancy
    • Post-abortal sepsis, puerperal sepsis, current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), genital tuberculosis
    • Cancers such as endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroids distorting the uterine cavity and Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding: This is an absolute contraindication because the underlying cause needs to be determined before placing an IUCD.

 

Option B. Suspected pregnancy: An IUCD should not be inserted if there is any suspicion of pregnancy due to the risk of miscarriage or infection.

 

Option D. PID: Current PID is an absolute contraindication because inserting an IUCD can exacerbate the infection and lead to serious complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV infection is not an absolute contraindication for the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device, whereas unexplained vaginal bleeding, suspected pregnancy, and current pelvic inflammatory disease are absolute contraindications.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549257

questions.text: The Image below shows origin from which of the following cells? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B cells

 

Reed–Sternberg cells (also known as lacunar histiocytes for certain types) are distinctive, giant cells

 

  • Owl eye appearance is due to prominent nucleoli inside nucleus.
  • Found with light microscopy in biopsies from individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma. They are derived from B Lymphocytes, classically considered crippled germinal center B cells.
  • Activation of transcription factor NF-Kẞ is a common event that turns on genes that are believed to promote the growth and survival of RS Cells.

 

Note: Don’t confuse this with CMV owl eye inclusion bodies – Intranuclear & basophilic inclusion bodies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD4 Cells: CD4 cells, also known as T helper cells, play a crucial role in the immune system by helping other cells respond to infections. They do not form Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Option C. NK Cell: Natural Killer (NK) cells are a type of lymphocyte that play a role in the innate immune response by targeting and killing virally infected cells and tumors. They are not involved in the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Option D. CD8 Cell: CD8 cells, also known as cytotoxic T cells, are involved in directly killing infected cells and tumor cells. They are not responsible for the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reed-Sternberg cells are derived from B lymphocytes and are a hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, characterized by their distinctive owl-eye appearance.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination his vitals are stable, but he could not speak. He had no other neurological findings, had normal handwriting skills, and could understand what was being asked of him to which he responds by nodding. Where could be the lesion for this clinical condition?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Broca’s area

 

Broca's area is involved in this case, as only speech production is affected, indicating a lesion here. This region, located in the inferior frontal lobe, is responsible for speech production and language formulation. Damage to Broca's area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia, characterized by the inability to produce fluent speech while retaining the ability to understand language and perform non-verbal tasks such as writing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect for this scenario as Wernicke's area deals with language comprehension. Damage to this area results in Wernicke's aphasia or sensory aphasia, where patients can produce fluent but often nonsensical speech and have difficulty understanding spoken language.

 

Option C. Primary motor cortex: Incorrect because damage to this area would result in more widespread motor deficits, not isolated to speech production.

 

Option D. Brainstem: Incorrect as lesions here typically affect more critical functions and present with more severe neurological deficits, not isolated speech production issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's and Wernicke's areas are critical regions for language processing. Broca's area handles the production of speech and language. In contrast, Wernicke's area is crucial for the comprehension of language. Damage to these areas can lead to distinct types of aphasia, highlighting their specific functions in language processing. Both areas are interconnected by the arcuate fasciculus, emphasizing the integrated nature of language processing in the brain.

questions.text: Which one of the listed medications is classified as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tamoxifen

 

Tamoxifen is a well-known selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used primarily in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in premenopausal women. It acts by binding to estrogen receptors on the cells, blocking estrogen from binding to these sites, particularly in breast tissue, thereby inhibiting the growth of estrogen-dependent tumors. Tamoxifen, however, can act as an estrogen agonist in other tissues such as the endometrium, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anastrozole: Anastrozole is classified as an aromatase inhibitor, not a SERM. It works by lowering estrogen levels in the body by inhibiting the enzyme aromatase, which converts androgens into estrogens, particularly useful in postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. Mifepristone: This drug is a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM). It is used primarily for its antiprogestational effects, including termination of pregnancy and management of high blood sugar levels caused by Cushing's syndrome due to its glucocorticoid receptor antagonism.

 

Option D. Ethinyl estradiol: This is a synthetic form of estrogen used primarily in oral contraceptives and hormone replacement therapy. It is not a SERM as it acts as an estrogen itself rather than modulating its receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SERM (Selective estrogen receptor modulator)

 

  1. Tamoxifen – Used in the treatment of ER +ve Breast cancers in Premenopausal women. It increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.

  2. Raloxifene - Can be used to treat Osteoporosis in post-menopausal women as a second line therapy. It doesn’t cause endometrial hyperplasia.

  3. Clomiphene - Used for ovulation induction

  4. Ospemifene – It is used to treat senile vaginal atrophy.

  5. Ormeloxifene – It is available as Centchroman or ‘Saheli’. It is used a once-a-week non-steroidal contraceptive pill.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with the following lesion on his face. He has a history of acne rosacea. The condition is? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rhinophyma

 

The given image is diagnostic of Rhinophyma.

 

Rhinophyma or potato tumor or nasal elephantiasis is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of nose often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea.

 

It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation; mostly affects men past middle age.

 

Patient seeks advice due to cosmetic reasons, or obstruction to breathing and vision due to large size of the tumor. Treatment consists of paring down the bulk of tumor with sharp knife or carbon dioxide laser and the area allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes, tumor is completely excised and the raw area skin grafted.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Gram negative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

 

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma is a systemic collagen disorder. Features are pinched-up nose, pursed lips, immobile facies.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rhinophyma is a notable dermatological condition linked with chronic acne rosacea, leading to hypertrophic and vascular changes to the nasal skin. It is important for cosmetic and functional reasons to manage this condition effectively, often necessitating surgical intervention to restore the normal appearance and function of the nose.

choices.text: Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool
Urban Health Evaluation assessment and Response Tool
Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Technique
Urban Health Evaluation Assessment and Response Technique

questions.text: A public health researcher is exploring tools to address health disparities in urban areas and discusses a WHO-developed guide. What is the correct name of this tool designed to help cities assess and respond to urban health equity issues? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool

 

The Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool used by WHO (World Health Organization) to identify and analyze the inequities in health between people living in various parts of cities or belonging to different socioeconomic groups within the city. It facilitates decisions on viable and effective strategies, interventions and actions that should be used to reduce inter- and intra-city health inequities.

 

It has 3 components:

 

  • Sound Evidence
  • Intersectoral Action
  • Community Participation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urban Health Evaluation Assessment and Response Tool: This variation misuses the word "Evaluation" instead of "Equity," which is central to the tool's purpose.

 

Option C. Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Technique: The term "Technique" inaccurately replaces "Tool."

 

Option D. Urban Health Evaluation Assessment and Response Technique: Incorrectly uses both "Evaluation" and "Technique," deviating from the official terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool are vital for effectively tackling health inequities in urban settings through informed policy and practice.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below. (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mirizzi Syndrome

 

  • The picture shown above is of Mirizzi’s syndrome.
  • Mirizzi syndrome is a rare condition caused by the obstruction of the common hepatic duct by external compression from multiple impacted gallstones or a single large impacted gallstone in Hartman's pouch or in cystic duct. Presenting symptoms are similar to symptoms of cholecystitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Porcelain gall bladder is a pre-malignant condition characterized by calcification around the gall bladder. Its presence warrants the need of prophylactic cholecystectomy. It is sequelae of chronic inflammation

 

 

Option C. Gallbladder polyp is an abnormal growth that develops on the inner lining of the gallbladder. These are detected incidentally. These are mostly benign. These polyps could be cholesterol polyps, inflammatory, adenomas etc.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirizzi syndrome is a condition caused by the external compression of the common hepatic duct by gallstones, leading to symptoms similar to acute cholecystitis. It is diagnosed using imaging techniques and typically requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with diffuse back pain. Upon examination, there is no limitation of motion in the sacroiliac joints, and the intervertebral disc spaces appear preserved. The cervical spine X-ray reveals flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DISH

 

Option B:

 

The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.

 

DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis) DISH is characterized by calcification and ossification of the spinal ligaments, particularly the anterior longitudinal ligament. On X-ray, DISH presents as flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies with preservation of the disc spaces, without significant facet joint ankylosis or sacroiliac joint involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton, leading to the fusion of affected joints, known as ankylosis. The hallmark radiographic findings in AS are sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes, leading to a "bamboo spine" appearance. However, the intervertebral disc spaces are typically preserved until late in the disease.

 

Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae. It may present with a short neck, limited neck movement, and low hairline. Radiographs would show fused cervical vertebrae, but not the flowing ossifications typical of DISH.

 

Option D. Sprengel Deformity: Sprengel deformity is a congenital condition in which the scapula is abnormally high due to its failure to descend during development. It's not related to spinal pathology and wouldn't show the characteristic findings of DISH on spinal imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray findings of flowing ossification along the anterior aspects of the thoracic spine with preserved intervertebral disc spaces in an elderly patient is indicative of DISH, which does not involve the sacroiliac joints.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 616

questions.text: In a village with 5,000 residents, the birth rate is reported as 25 live births per 1,000 people per year. Including estimated pregnancy losses, what is the total number of pregnancies expected in one year? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 138

 

As Newborn birth rate is given as 25 per 1000 population. Therefore for every 1000 people = 25 births.

 

Therefore for 5000 people = 125 births.

 

But in question total no of pregnancies is asked

 

In India we have about 10% of pregnancy wastage so we add that along with 125 here

 

So, 125 + 12.5 = 137.5 pregnancies

 

From options 138 would be the exact answer

 

Educational Objective:

 

When calculating the total number of pregnancies in a population, it is essential to include both the expected live births based on the birth rate and an estimated percentage for pregnancy losses to obtain a comprehensive figure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old developed progressive vision loss in both eyes with a history of chronic oral steroid intake for the last 10 years. What is the likely cause of vision loss? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cataract

 

Chronic oral steroid use is strongly associated with the development of posterior subcapsular cataracts. This type of cataract occurs at the back of the lens and can significantly impair vision, particularly in bright light or when reading.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glaucoma: While steroid use can increase intraocular pressure, leading to glaucoma, this is more commonly associated with topical steroid use rather than chronic oral intake.

 

Option C. Retinal detachment: Steroids are sometimes used in the treatment of proliferative vitreoretinopathy, a complication that can follow retinal detachment surgery, but they are not typically a direct cause of retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: Topical steroids are used to manage cystoid macular edema, but it is not a common cause of vision loss directly associated with chronic oral steroid use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic oral steroid use can lead to the development of posterior subcapsular cataracts, causing progressive vision loss in both eyes.

questions.text:
In a suburban district, healthcare professionals are reviewing data on child mortality to calculate the Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) using recent statistics. The district recorded a total of 4000 live births. Given the following numbers of deaths in different neonatal age groups, what is the NMR for this district? (FMGE DEC 2020)

 

Data:

Total death among day 0-7 :40

Total death among day 7-28 :40

Total death >than 1 month :40

Perinatal death :40
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 20

 

Neonate is one who is having an age of 0-28 days and is divided into:

 

  1. Early Neonatal Period = 0-7 days (40 from question)
  2. Late Neonatal Period = 8-28 days (40 from question)

 

  Therefore, Neonatal period = Early neonatal period + Late neonatal period

 

 

Therefore, from the given data → NMR = (80/4000) *1000 = 20

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is a critical indicator of neonatal health and reflects the effectiveness of healthcare services during the neonatal period. It is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths (age 0-28 days) per 1000 live births, highlighting areas for potential healthcare improvements

questions.text: What is the condition seen in the following X ray in a 2-month infant with bilious vomiting? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

Clinical features:

 

Bilious vomiting indicates restriction either distal to or at the level of the duodenum.

 

Two sizable gas bubbles are visible in the abdomen X-ray shown above (Double bubble appearance)

 

 

  • Projectile vomiting: Infants with duodenal atresia often have projectile vomiting, which can occur shortly after feeding. The vomiting is typically non-bilious, meaning it does not contain bile.
  • Abdominal distension: Due to the blockage in the duodenum, there is a build-up of fluid and gas in the stomach and proximal small intestine. This can cause abdominal distension and visible peristaltic waves.
  • Failure to pass meconium: Meconium is the first stool that newborns pass, and its absence can indicate a bowel obstruction.
  • Absent or decreased bowel sounds: A blockage in the duodenum can cause decreased or absent bowel sounds upon auscultation.
  • Polyhydramnios: In some cases, polyhydramnios (excessive amniotic fluid) may be present during pregnancy, which can be a sign of duodenal atresia in the fetus.
  • Down syndrome: Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with Down syndrome, and infants with this genetic condition may be screened for the condition.
  • Other associated anomalies: In some cases, duodenal atresia may be associated with other congenital anomalies such as cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, or imperforate anus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically presents with non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 2-8 weeks. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle and does not cause the double bubble sign seen in duodenal atresia.

 

Option C. Intestinal obstruction: Intestinal obstruction can cause bilious vomiting but usually presents with more diffuse bowel dilatation on imaging, unlike the localized double bubble sign seen in duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. Jejunal obstruction: Jejunal obstruction also causes bilious vomiting, but the X-ray findings differ, with dilated loops of bowel rather than the characteristic double bubble sign.

 

Educational Objective:


Duodenal atresia is characterized by bilious vomiting and the double bubble sign on X-ray, often associated with Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following pneumoconiosis is associated with increased risk of tuberculosis: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Silicosis

 

Silicosis is a pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of silica particles, which are phagocytosed by pulmonary macrophages. This process impairs macrophage function and increases susceptibility to infections, particularly tuberculosis (TB). Silica exposure leads to a higher risk of TB because the particles interfere with the macrophages' ability to control and kill Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Unique Points in Silico-TB:

 

  • Sputum is rarely AFB (acid-fast bacilli) positive.
  • Typically does not affect children or women.
  • Radiology findings of tuberculosis and silicotuberculosis appear similar, making differentiation based on imaging challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asbestosis: This condition is caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, which primarily affect the lower lobes of the lungs. Asbestosis increases the risk of developing mesothelioma and lung cancer but is not specifically associated with an increased risk of TB.

 

Option B. Berylliosis: Beryllium exposure can cause a condition that mimics sarcoidosis. The Beryllium Lymphocyte Proliferation Test (BeLPT) is used for diagnosis. It is not specifically associated with an increased risk of TB.

 

Option D. Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP): Also known as "black lung disease," it is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. While CWP can lead to chronic lung disease, it is not particularly associated with an increased risk of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Silicosis is the pneumoconiosis associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis due to the impairment of pulmonary macrophage function by silica particles.

questions.text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease presented with the following lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyoderma gangrenosum

 

The image shows a characteristic lesion that is most consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum (PG). Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation often associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It typically presents as painful, ulcerative lesions with a violaceous border and can occur on the anterior surface of the legs.

 

Dermatological Manifestations of IBD:

 

  • Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG): Commonly found on the anterior surface of feet and legs, characterized by painful ulcers with purulent bases and violaceous borders. It is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD.
  • Sweet syndrome (Acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis): Characterized by fever and painful skin lesions.
  • Panniculitis (Erythema nodosum): Presents as tender, red nodules typically on the shins.
  • Cutaneous metastasis: More common in Crohn's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic ulcer: Diabetic ulcers typically present as non-healing ulcers, often on the feet, and are associated with peripheral neuropathy and vascular disease. They may also present with necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum, which shows yellow, waxy plaques with a reddish-brown border.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: These ulcers are commonly found in the gaiter area (around the ankles) and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency, often in the context of varicose veins. They present with edema, hyperpigmentation, and lipodermatosclerosis.

 

Option D. Erythema nodosum: Erythema nodosum is a form of panniculitis that presents with tender, erythematous nodules, usually on the shins. It does not cause ulceration or oozing as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with inflammatory bowel disease presenting with ulcerative skin lesions on the legs, pyoderma gangrenosum is the most likely diagnosis. Treatment typically involves corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapies.

choices.text: Bronchial Asthma, Hypertension, CVD
Diabetes, Hypertension, Bronchial Asthma
CVD, Diabetes, Bronchial Asthma
CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, Stroke

questions.text: An intern is preparing for a health awareness session and needs to know which diseases the NPCDCS focuses on in India. Which group of conditions is targeted by this program? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, Stroke

 

The NPCDCS (National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases, and Stroke) specifically targets four major non-communicable diseases: Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD), Cancer, Diabetes, and Stroke. This initiative aims to enhance disease control measures and raise public awareness about these prevalent health conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NATIONAL PROGRAMME FOR PREVENTION & CONTROL OF DIABETES, CV DISEASES & STROKE (NPCDCS)

 

 

Through formation of NCD clinics, this was established in 100+ districts in India

 

Set of 9 voluntary Global NCD targets for 2025 are:

 

  • Smoking and salt intake to be reduced by 30%
  • Risk factors like alcohol and less physical activity to be reduced by 10%
  • Reduction the premature deaths due to non-Communicable diseases by 25%
  • Reduction in the prevalence of Hypertension by 25%
  • > 80% of the community must have access to affordable medicines for all NCDs in all private and public centres
  • > 50% of all patients must get access to drugs and medicines to prevent coronary artery disease or stroke
  • Halt the epidemics of diabetes and obesity.

questions.text: Introduction of new drug in the market is done after which of the following phases of clinical trials? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phase 3

 

The process of introducing a new drug into the market typically occurs after the completion of Phase 3 clinical trials. These trials are crucial as they involve a large patient population (often around 1000 or more subjects), where the drug’s efficacy is confirmed, and its safety profile is compared with the current standard of care. This phase is designed to provide a comprehensive assessment of the drug’s effectiveness and monitor adverse reactions with the use of randomization and control groups, often across multiple sites. Upon successful completion of Phase 3, a New Drug Application (NDA) is filed with regulatory bodies such as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to approve the drug for marketing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 1: This initial phase involves testing the drug on a small group of healthy volunteers to determine its basic safety, the range of tolerable doses, and to gain early insights into its pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. It is too early in the drug development process for market introduction.

 

Option B. Phase 2: This phase tests the drug on a larger group of people who have the disease or condition the drug is designed to treat. It aims to determine efficacy and further evaluate safety. However, the scale and scope of Phase 2 are insufficient for market approval, as more comprehensive data from diverse patient populations are needed.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Known as the post-marketing surveillance phase, this occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed. It is designed to detect any rare or long-term adverse effects over a more extensive population and period, which was not possible in earlier phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phases Overview:

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of long-standing black urine. Both, Ferric chloride and Benedict's test were found to be positive in this patient. Pinna and Sclera of eyes have black pigmentation. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alkaptonuria

 

The symptoms and findings mentioned in the case, such as long-standing black urine, positive Ferric chloride and Benedict's tests, and black pigmentation of the pinna and sclera of the eyes, are consistent with alkaptonuria. The darkening of urine upon exposure to air is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a different metabolic disorder that results from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine. PKU does not present with black urine or pigmentation of the pinna and sclera.

 

Option B. Galactosemia: Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder related to the inability to metabolize galactose, leading to its accumulation. Clinical features are jaundice, mental retardation and cataract. It does not typically present with black urine or pigmentation of the pinna and sclera.

 

Option D. MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine Disease): MSUD is a disorder of branched-chain amino acid metabolism. In this, the urine of patient smells like burnt sugar but it does not result in black urine or pigmentation of the pinna and sclera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase (old name) homogentisate 1, 2-dioxygenase (new name). This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine. In individuals with alkaptonuria, there is an accumulation of homogentisic acid which is reducing substance and comes out in the urine of patient, giving positive Benedict test and FeCl3 test. The accumulation of homogentisate in connective tissues give rise to black pigmentation.

questions.text: A newborn is found to be born with the condition shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

  • Omphalocele also called exomphalos, is a rare abdominal wall defect.
  • Beginning at the 6th week of development, rapid elongation of the gut and increased liver size reduces intra-abdominal space, which pushes intestinal loops out of the abdominal cavity. In the image, the herniated bowel is covered by peritoneum, suggestive of omphalocele.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect where the intestines are located outside the baby’s body through a hole beside the belly button. Unlike omphalocele, it does not have a covering sac, and the intestines appear inflamed and edematous. It is typically seen in premature babies and the defect size is smaller (2-3 cm).

 

Option C. Epigastric Hernia: An epigastric hernia occurs in the epigastric region, which is the upper middle part of the abdomen, just above the umbilicus and below the chest. It does not involve herniation of the bowel through the umbilical region with a sac covering.

 

Option D. Ectopia Vesica: Also known as bladder exstrophy, this is a rare congenital condition that affects the development of the urinary bladder and surrounding pelvic structures. It is associated with an infraumbilical defect, exposure of the bladder outside the abdomen, pubic bone diastasis, and epispadias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is characterized by herniation of abdominal viscera covered by peritoneum and is associated with various congenital anomalies.

questions.text: Based on the image provided, what is the likely diagnosis of the depicted condition? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

 

The given histology slide shows presence of Flexner wintersteiner rosettes, which are characteristically seen in Retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastomas typically show Homer-Wright rosettes, where tumor cells surround a neuropil core. This neuropil is a dense feltwork of interwoven cytoplasmic processes of nerve cells and neuroglial cells. The absence of this specific feature helps rule out Medulloblastoma in the provided image.

 

Option C. Ewings sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is characterized by small round blue cells, and the presence of rosettes is uncommon. It typically shows sheets of uniform small round cells with scant cytoplasm and is not associated with the rosettes seen in the image.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma can present with Homer-Wright rosettes similar to Medulloblastoma, where the rosettes are centered around a neuropil rather than a true lumen. This differentiation helps to rule out Neuroblastoma in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are pathognomonic for Retinoblastoma and are key in its histopathological diagnosis.

questions.text: 56-year-old diabetic patient has chronic renal failure and is undergoing Hemodialysis. Which of the following amyloid most likely to get deposited? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A beta 2

 

Beta 2 microglobulin is a component of MHC class I molecules and is not excreted via the filter of dialysis membrane. The levels rise in the body and get deposited in or around the joints or soft tissues of patients. It can lead to two manifestations, Dialysis dementia and Carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AA: Amyloid A protein is associated with secondary (AA) amyloidosis, which typically occurs due to chronic inflammatory conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, or malignancies like multiple myeloma. It is not primarily related to dialysis or beta 2 microglobulin.

 

Option B. A beta: Amyloid beta (A beta) is primarily associated with Alzheimer's disease. It forms plaques in the brain, contributing to neurodegeneration seen in this condition. It is not related to renal failure or hemodialysis.

 

Option D. A Cal: Calcitonin-derived amyloid (A Cal) is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. In this cancer, amyloid deposits are derived from calcitonin or its precursor. This type of amyloid is not linked with dialysis or renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AA is associated with multiple myeloma, A beta with Alzheimer’s disease and A cal  with medullary carcinoma thyroid.

questions.text: Lysosomal enzymes are synthesized by? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoplasmic reticulum

 

The synthesis of lysosomal enzymes begins in the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Ribosomes bound to the ER membrane synthesize the enzymes, which are initially produced as precursor proteins. These precursor proteins undergo various post-translational modifications, including folding, glycosylation, and acquisition of necessary targeting signals.

 

After synthesis and initial modifications in the ER, the lysosomal enzymes are packaged into transport vesicles that bud off from the ER membrane. These vesicles then transport the enzymes to the Golgi apparatus.

 

In the Golgi apparatus, further modifications occur, such as the addition of mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) tags to the lysosomal enzymes. These M6P tags serve as sorting signals that allow the enzymes to be recognized and specifically transported to lysosomes.

 

Finally, the lysosomal enzymes are packaged into vesicles called lysosomes, which are organelles specialized for digestion and recycling processes. Lysosomes fuse with endocytic vesicles or autophagosomes containing material to be degraded, and the lysosomal enzymes are released into the lysosomal lumen, where they function to break down and digest the captured material.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytosol: While the cytosol contains enzymes and is the site for numerous metabolic processes, it is not directly involved in the synthesis of lysosomal enzymes. These enzymes are synthesized in the rough ER and processed through the secretory pathway.

 

Option B. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are responsible for energy production and various metabolic processes but are not involved in the synthesis of lysosomal enzymes.

 

Option D. Nucleus: The nucleus contains the genetic material and is responsible for transcription, but protein synthesis, including lysosomal enzymes, occurs in the cytoplasm at the rough ER.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomal enzymes are synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, undergo modifications in the Golgi apparatus, and are finally targeted to lysosomes. This complex process ensures that these enzymes are correctly processed and delivered to their functional location within the cell.

choices.text: Chest Xray artifact
Travel tract for accessory pathway

questions.text: The device seen in the following image is ___ ? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac pacemaker

 

Image shows a device with lead in the cardiac chambers which is suggestive of cardiac pacemaker

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chemoport is a device placed subcutaneously with one end attached to the IJV ensuring optimal delivery of chemo drugs. It does not have leads extending into the cardiac chambers like a pacemaker.

 

Option C. Chest Xray artifact is unlikely.

 

Option D. Travel tract for accessory pathway: This option does not correspond to any known medical device or structure. It seems to be a non-medical term and is not relevant to the identification of the device in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cardiac pacemaker, is identified by the device and leads extending into the cardiac chambers. This device is used to regulate the heartbeat in patients with arrhythmias or heart block.

questions.text: A 25-year-old comes to your OPD with the complaint that he develops pain in penis during erection and interfering with sexual intercourse. Examination reveals a plaque on glans. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peyronie’s disease

 

Peyronie’s disease is a condition where fibrous scar tissue develops inside the penis, causing curved, painful erections. The presence of a plaque (fibrous scar tissue) on the glans or shaft of the penis is characteristic of Peyronie’s disease. This scar tissue causes the penis to bend or become indented during erections, leading to pain and difficulty with sexual intercourse. The exact cause isn't always known, but it is sometimes related to trauma or injury to the penis. Treatment can range from medications to surgery, depending on the severity of the curvature and the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraphimosis: Paraphimosis occurs when the foreskin, once retracted behind the glans of the penis, cannot be pulled back over the glans again. It is considered a medical emergency because it can restrict blood flow to the head of the penis, which might lead to tissue death. However, it does not cause a plaque on the glans.

 

Option B. Phimosis: Phimosis is a condition in which the foreskin of the penis is too tight to be pulled back over the glans or head of the penis. This can sometimes cause pain, especially during an erection, and can also predispose to infections. It does not involve the formation of a plaque on the glans.

 

Option C. Hypospadias: Hypospadias is a congenital condition where the opening of the urethra is on the underside of the penis, rather than at the tip. It is one of the most common birth anomalies of male genitalia. Depending on its severity, it might affect urination and later in life, sexual function. Hypospadias is not associated with pain during erection or the presence of a plaque on the glans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peyronie’s disease is characterized by the presence of fibrous scar tissue (plaque) in the penis, leading to curved, painful erections and difficulty with sexual intercourse.

choices.text: Frontal eye field

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following lesion. Where is the likely localisation of this defect? (FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital lobe

 

The image shows homonymous hemianopia, which is the loss of vision in the same side of the visual field in both eyes. This type of visual field defect is typically due to a lesion located behind the optic chiasma (retrochiasmal lesion).

 

The presence of macular sparing is a characteristic feature of occipital lobe lesions. The macula, which is responsible for central vision, has a dual blood supply from both the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and the middle cerebral artery (MCA), allowing it to remain functional even if one of these arteries is compromised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Frontal eye field: Lesions in the frontal eye field cause gaze palsies but do not produce visual field defects.

 

Option B. Optic radiation: Lesions in the optic radiation typically produce quadrantanopia, not homonymous hemianopia. The optic radiation is divided into the superior and inferior fibers, each affecting different quadrants of the visual field when lesioned.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasma produce heteronymous visual field defects, such as bitemporal hemianopia, where the temporal visual fields of both eyes are lost.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing localizes to the occipital lobe, as the occipital lobe lesions are behind the optic chiasma and can affect the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

questions.text: What is the clinical sign shown in the below picture? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Koebner's phenomenon

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.
  • Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.
  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon: Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermographism (or Dermatographic Urticaria)

 

  • Description: This refers to the development of wheal-like lesions on the skin after pressure or light scratching as shown in the below image.

 

  • Why it might not be the answer: Dermographism causes immediate wheal responses from pressure or scratching but doesn't typically lead to the development of lesions similar to an existing skin condition (isomorphic response).

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

  • Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

Option D. Auspitz Sign

  • Description: Observed when psoriasis scales are scraped off, leading to pinpoint bleeding as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with the complaint of reduced sleep at night. She is anxious that her parents might die soon and she would have to live alone. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Generalized anxiety disorder

 

The patient's symptoms of excessive worry, especially about future events (parents' possible deaths) and its impact on daily function (sleep disturbances), align with Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Relates to reactions from identifiable stressors, typically resolving within six months after the stressor ends.

 

Option C. Major depression: Central features are persistent low mood and loss of interest in activities.

 

Option D. Panic disorder: It is characterized by sudden, intense panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive anxiety (also called “free floating anxiety”) and worry about various aspects of life, lasting for a period of 6 months or longer. This is often associated with physical symptoms such as restlessness, easy fatigability, muscle tension, insomnia etc. Treatment mainly includes SSRIs with short duration of benzodiazepines with CBT.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 405.
