questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urea

 

Nitrogenous waste, which is a byproduct of protein metabolism, is primarily excreted from the body in the form of urea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric acid: While uric acid is another nitrogenous waste product, it is typically excreted in lower quantities and is more commonly associated with the excretion of avian and reptilian waste. In humans, a smaller portion of nitrogenous waste is excreted as uric acid.

 

Option C. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is not a nitrogenous waste product. It is a gas that is sometimes used as an anesthetic or in dentistry, but it is not a waste excreted from the body.

 

Option D. Glutamine: Glutamine is an amino acid and a component of proteins. While it contains nitrogen, it is not excreted as a waste product in the same way urea or uric acid is. Glutamine has various roles in cellular metabolism and serves as a precursor for other molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea is formed in the liver through the urea cycle, a process that converts ammonia, a highly toxic substance, into urea, which is less toxic and more soluble in water. The urea is then transported to the kidneys, where it is filtered out of the blood and excreted in the urine. It is the major product formed from the nitrogenous waste in humans.

questions.text: Identify the genetic disorder: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Turner’s syndrome

 

  • The image depicts Turner's syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is monosomy X (45XO) with no second sex chromosome.
  • It is the most common sex chromosomal abnormality in young girls.
  • It is also the most common cause of primary amenorrhoea
  • This syndrome is characterized by: short stature (Seen in all girls with Turner), gonadal dysgenesis (typically streak gonads reflecting a failure of ovarian maintenance), characteristic unusual facies, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and elevated frequency of renal and cardiovascular anomalies are typical abnormalities in Turner syndrome.
  • Edema of the dorsum of the foot is frequently present at birth in infants with this syndrome, which is a helpful diagnostic sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Feminization syndrome:

 

  • Also called as androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Phenotypically female with breast development + but absent pubic and axillary hairs
  • Karyotype: 46XY
  • Presents as primary amenorrhoea
  • External genitalia: Female
  • Internal genitalia: Absent male/ female
  • Male gonads +

 

Option B. Kallman syndrome:

 

  • Presents as primary amenorrhoea with anosmia

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome:

 

  • Presents usually as an infertile male (46XXY)
  • Tall statured with slightly feminized appearance
  • Mildly impaired IQ
  • Gynecomastia
  • Small testes

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Turner syndrome (45XO) is characterized by short stature, primary amenorrhea, and characteristic physical features such as a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.

 

Ref: Page no 442, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: The marked area on the femur serves as the insertion point for which of the following muscles? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Iliopsoas

 

Explanation

 

The image shown is the posterior surface of the right femur, and the pointed structure is the lesser trochanter, which houses the iliopsoas muscle.

 

  • The iliopsoas comprises Psoas major and Iliacus.
  • They arise from the lumbar spine and the inner surface of the ilium bone respectively, and insert on the lesser trochanter.
  • The iliopsoas cause flexion of the hip.

 

Other option:

 

Option A) Gluteus Maximus: The gluteus maximus is a large muscle of the buttocks that originates from the ilium and sacrum and inserts into the femur's posterior surface. It is primarily responsible for hip extension, which is the movement of moving the thigh backward, as well as external rotation of the hip.

 

Option B) Adductor Magnus: The adductor magnus is a muscle of the inner thigh. While it has multiple attachments, it primarily inserts into the linea aspera of the femur. Its main function is to adduct the thigh, bringing it toward the midline of the body.

 

Option C) Quadriceps Femoris: The quadriceps femoris, often referred to as the quadriceps, is a group of four muscles on the front of the thigh. These muscles converge to form the quadriceps tendon, which inserts into the patella (kneecap) and then continues as the patellar tendon, attaching to the tibial tuberosity on the anterior surface of the tibia. The quadriceps muscles are primarily responsible for knee extension.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective

 

The iliopsoas is a group of muscles located in the hip region, composed of the iliacus muscle and the psoas major muscle. These muscles originate from different areas but converge to form a common tendon that attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated fractures for the past 2 years. On examination, there is the presence of blue sclera and dental abnormalities. There is a positive family history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical history given is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature. The clinical features include;

 

 

  • Multiple fractures: Recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • Blue sclera: Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Dental problems: Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly.
  • Hearing loss
  • Skeletal deformities: Scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • Short stature: Due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • Easy bruising: Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and typically presents with gingival bleeding, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages. It does not cause blue sclera or multiple fractures.

 

Option B. Rickets: Rickets is caused by vitamin D deficiency and is associated with bone deformities like bowing of the legs, but not with blue sclera, dental abnormalities, or a positive family history.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia refers to softening of bones in adults due to vitamin D deficiency, causing bone pain and muscle weakness, but not the fractures and blue sclera seen in OI.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent fractures, blue sclera, dental abnormalities, and often has an autosomal dominant inheritance.

questions.text: A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell, and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy and turbinates are atrophied. Which of the following surgeries can be done on this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Young’s operation

 

The clinical presentation indicates the presence of atrophic rhinitis, a condition that can be addressed through Young's and modified Young's surgical procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submucous resection: This procedure is typically used to correct a deviated septum by removing parts of the cartilage or bone. It would not address the underlying problems of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: Similar to submucous resection, septoplasty corrects deviations in the nasal septum but would not be beneficial in treating the mucosal atrophy and crusting seen in atrophic rhinitis.

 

Option D. Vidian neurectomy: This surgical procedure targets the vidian nerve to reduce nasal hyperreactivity in conditions like vasomotor rhinitis. It is not indicated for atrophic rhinitis, as it does not address mucosal dryness or atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Young's operation is an effective surgical treatment for atrophic rhinitis, designed to reduce nasal airflow and facilitate the healing and regeneration of the nasal mucosa. This operation is particularly beneficial in severe cases where medical treatments have been insufficient.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 months history of erythematosquamous lesions involving the exposed areas especially in the neck region associated with diarrhea, photosensitivity and irritability. What do you think diagnosis is? (FMGE December 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Niacin deficiency

 

This patient's symptoms are consistent with pellagra, a condition caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). Pellagra is characterized by the "Ds": dermatitis (erythematosquamous lesions, especially in sun-exposed areas), diarrhea, dementia (including irritability), Delirium and death if left untreated. The necklace like rash on the neck is called as Casal’s necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, neurological symptoms, and other systemic manifestations, but it does not typically present with erythematosquamous lesions, diarrhea, or photosensitivity.

 

Option B. Ascorbic acid deficiency (Vitamin C deficiency): Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is characterized by bleeding gums, joint pain, and weakness, but it does not typically present with erythematosquamous lesions, diarrhea, or photosensitivity.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can cause bone-related symptoms, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It is not associated with erythematosquamous lesions, diarrhea, or irritability as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra is a condition caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) and tryptophan in the diet. It typically presents with the following "3 D's" of pellagra:

 

  1. Dermatitis: Erythematosquamous lesions, which are red, scaly skin rashes, are a characteristic dermatological feature of pellagra. These rashes often appear on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the neck, hands, and face.
  2. Diarrhea: Pellagra can also lead to gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, abdominal pain, and nausea.
  3. Dementia: Irritability and neurological symptoms, including confusion, memory loss, and even psychosis, can occur in advanced cases of pellagra.

 

In addition to the "3 D's," patients with pellagra may also experience photosensitivity, fatigue, and a sore mouth and tongue. Pellagra is most commonly associated with a diet lacking in niacin-rich foods (such as meat, fish, and legumes) or tryptophan, which can be converted to niacin in the body.

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cottle’s test

 

Cottle’s test is used in nasal obstruction due to abnormality of the nasal valve. In this test, cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates abnormality of the vestibular component of nasal valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver is done in Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).

 

Option B. Heimlich maneuver is performed to dislodge a foreign body.

 

Option D. Trotter's method is an initial treatment for epistaxis. It is done by pinching the nose tightly and sit bending forwards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cottle’s test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool for evaluating the integrity and functionality of the nasal valve, particularly useful in patients complaining of nasal obstruction. It helps to determine if surgical intervention might be necessary to correct any identified nasal valve collapse.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the complaint of chronic epiphora for the past one year. What is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

Epiphora refers to excessive flow of tears from the eyes, other than that caused by normal crying. It can occur due to inefficient clearing of tears from the eyes through the nasolacrimal duct.

 

Management of congenital dacryocystitis:

 

 

Tarsal plate fracture is used for management of entropion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct massage: This technique, also known as hydrostatic sac massage, is primarily effective in infants up to 6–8 weeks of age. It involves applying pressure at the medial canthus to facilitate the opening of the nasolacrimal duct. Given the boy's age (7 years), this method would not be effective.

 

Option C. Tarsal plate fracture: This is a surgical procedure used to correct entropion (inward turning of the eyelid). It is not relevant to the treatment of nasolacrimal duct obstruction or chronic epiphora.

 

Option D. Lacrimal sac massage: Similar to nasolacrimal duct massage, this method is effective in infants and young children but is unlikely to be effective in a 7-year-old with chronic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the appropriate treatment for chronic epiphora in older children, as it creates a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, effectively bypassing the obstructed nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. There was no pulse and hence CPR was started. The monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epinephrine
 

The patient's ECG shows pulseless electrical activity (PEA), which is characterized by electrical activity on the ECG without a palpable pulse. PEA is treated with high-quality chest compressions and administration of epinephrine as soon as possible. The reversible causes of cardiac arrest (5 H's and 5 T's) should also be rapidly evaluated and treated if present.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Defibrillation: This is used for shockable rhythms such as ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT), not for PEA.

 

Option B. Atropine: This is used for symptomatic bradycardia, not for PEA.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: This is used for certain types of tachyarrhythmias with a pulse, not for PEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient in cardiac arrest with PEA, the next step is to continue high-quality CPR and administer epinephrine while evaluating for and treating reversible causes.

questions.text: Complex IV in ETC is inhibited by? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyanide

 

Complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase, is the terminal enzyme in the electron transport chain. It plays a crucial role in the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, ultimately leading to the formation of water. Cyanide inhibits complex IV by binding to the enzyme and preventing the transfer of electrons to oxygen. This inhibition blocks the final step in the electron transport chain, leading to a halt in cellular respiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barbiturates: These are not known to inhibit Complex IV directly. They mainly act on the central nervous system by enhancing the effects of the neurotransmitter GABA. Some barbiturates like phenobarbital inhibit Complex I of the ETC, not Complex IV.

 

Option C. Phenobarbitone: Similar to other barbiturates, Phenobarbitone primarily impacts Complex I, inhibiting it rather than Complex IV. It is used clinically primarily for its sedative and anticonvulsant properties.

 

Option D. Malonate: This compound is a known inhibitor of Complex II (succinate dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain. It competes with succinate, blocking the transfer of electrons within Complex II, but does not affect Complex IV.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

 

The presence of a dull tympanic membrane accompanied by tinnitus, hearing loss, and B type impedance audiometry findings indicates a possible case of serous otitis media. In the elderly, the leading cause of unilateral serous otitis media is often linked to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media: patients on examination shows presence of granulations, in-growth of squamous epithelium from the edges of perforation, tympanosclerosis and adhesions.

 

Option B. Glomus tumour: is a slow growing benign tumor. On examination, tympanic membrane has a "rising sun" appearance.

 

Option D. Sensorineural hearing loss: will show type A curve on tympanometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with unilateral serous otitis media and neck nodes, nasopharyngeal carcinoma should be considered as a potential underlying cause, especially if accompanied by symptoms such as tinnitus and hearing loss. Diagnostic evaluations, including imaging and possibly a biopsy of the nasopharyngeal region and neck nodes, are crucial for confirming the diagnosis and determining the extent of the disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with irregular periods. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image. This is most likely due to: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCOD

 

The ultrasound image shows a polycystic ovary with a characteristic "necklace pattern," which is indicative of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is diagnosed using the Rotterdam criteria, which require the presence of at least two out of the following three criteria:

 

  • Ultrasound morphology of PCOS: Ovarian volume greater than 10 ml or 12 or more follicles measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter in one or both ovaries.
  • Clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism: This includes symptoms such as hirsutism (excessive hair growth), acne, and elevated levels of androgens.
  • Oligo or anovulation: Irregular or absent menstrual cycles indicating infrequent or lack of ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obesity: Obesity can be a contributing factor to PCOS and may exacerbate its symptoms, but it is not a direct cause of the ultrasound findings described.

 

Option C. Hirsutism: Hirsutism is a clinical manifestation of hyperandrogenism, which is one of the criteria for diagnosing PCOS. However, it is not the direct cause of the ultrasound appearance.

 

Option D. Turner's syndrome: Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal disorder in females characterized by the partial or complete absence of one X chromosome. It does not present with the polycystic ovarian morphology seen in the ultrasound image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by the presence of polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, clinical or biochemical signs of hyperandrogenism, and oligo or anovulation.

 

Ref: Page no 379, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic valve opens

 

Explanation

 

  • Point C on the left ventricular pressure-volume loop marks the moment when the aortic valve opens. This occurs at the end of the isovolumetric contraction phase when the pressure within the left ventricle exceeds the pressure in the aorta, forcing the aortic valve to open and allowing blood to be ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral valve closes: Incorrect as this occurs at point B, marking the end of ventricular filling and the beginning of isovolumetric contraction.

 

Option C. Aortic valve closes: Incorrect because this happens at point D, which signifies the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation.

 

Option D. Mitral valve opens: Incorrect as this occurs at point A, indicating the start of ventricular filling when the pressure in the left ventricle falls below that in the left atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point C - Aortic valve opens

 

Point D - Aortic valve closes

 

Point A - Mitral valve opens

 

Point B - Mitral valve closes

questions.text: A patient was posted for dilatation and curettage and a sound was introduced into the uterus but there was no resistance felt. What is the next line of management in the given options? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immediate laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

  • As the uterine sound enters without any resistance, it signals that there is a perforation, necessitating rapid laparoscopy.
  • Uterine perforation can be a serious complication during dilatation and curettage procedures. Immediate laparoscopy is recommended to assess the extent of the perforation, manage any associated injuries, and complete the procedure safely.

 

Management protocol of uterine perforation:

 

  • The procedure is stopped immediately.
    • Perforation made by small instruments (e.g., smaller size dilator) and if the procedure is completed:
      • Expectant treatment with observation of vital signs.
      • Administration of antibiotics to prevent infection.
    • Perforation caused by larger instruments (e.g., bigger size dilator, ovum forceps, suction cannula) or if the procedure is incomplete:
      • Diagnostic laparoscopy to assess the perforation and complete the procedure.
      • In cases of lateral cervical tear or broad ligament hematoma, laparotomy with repair or hysterectomy might be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue the procedure: Continuing the procedure without addressing the perforation could lead to further complications and is not advisable.

 

Option B. Do planned evacuation: Planned evacuation without assessing and managing the perforation is not appropriate. Immediate evaluation and management of the perforation are crucial.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Misoprostol: Mifepristone and Misoprostol are used for medical termination of pregnancy, not for managing uterine perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate laparoscopy is indicated in cases of suspected uterine perforation during dilatation and curettage to assess the extent of the perforation and manage associated injuries.

 

Ref: Page no 526, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

questions.text: A farmer presented to the outpatient department with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling over his palm as shown in the image. A few months back he got injured with a thorn. What is the presentation given below?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Implantation dermoid

 

IMPLANTATION / ACQUIRED DERMOIDS:

 

  • This is an acquired condition that develops as a result of the penetration of epidermal fragments into the dermis.
  • The epidermis keeps expanding and eventually develops a cyst that is lined with stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratin.
  • Seen in individuals like tailors, gardeners who sustain repeated minor injuries.
  • Sites: fingers, toes, feet.
  • Minor trauma - epidermal cells gets buried in the subcutaneous space → cyst formation
  • Signs: painless, soft, smooth, adherent to skin, tensely cystic, mobile swelling.
  • Managed by surgical excision, careful complete excision; removal of the entire cyst wall is necessary to avoid the recurrence, under local anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ameloblastoma

 

  • Description: It is a benign tumor originating from odontogenic epithelium, primarily involved in tooth development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Ameloblastoma typically manifests in the jaw, especially the mandible as shown in the image below

 

 

The presentation in the palm after a thorn injury is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Embryogenic Dermoid

 

  • Description: These cysts arise from trapped pluripotent cells during fetal development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Embryogenic dermoids are congenital and are frequently found at fusion lines such as the midline of the body. Their occurrence on the palm and their association with a traumatic event (like a thorn prick) is not typical.

 

Option C. Sequestration Dermoid

 

  • Description: Formed due to sequestration (separation) of ectodermal tissue during embryonic development.
  • Why it is not the answer: Like embryogenic dermoids, sequestration dermoids are commonly found in the midline, and their formation isn't associated with trauma or injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a farmer presenting with a non-tender, non-mobile, non-compressible firm swelling on the palm following a puncture wound from a thorn is an implantation dermoid cyst (D). These cysts are acquired through the traumatic implantation of epidermal elements into the dermis, which is consistent with the patient's history and clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient after surgery of breast cancer developed the deformity as shown below. Which of the following is most likely cause for this condition? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Injury to long thoracic nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The long thoracic nerve is a nerve that originates from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5-C7) and supplies the serratus anterior muscle.

 

Effect of Injury: If the long thoracic nerve is injured or compromised, it can lead to weakness or paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle. This, in turn, results in an inability to adequately stabilize the scapula, leading to winging of the scapula when the arm is moved away from the body. In the case of breast cancer surgery, injury to the long thoracic nerve can occur during the surgical procedure or due to damage to nearby structures.

 

Appearance: The winged scapula deformity is typically seen when the patient is asked to push against a wall or perform similar movements that require scapular stability.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Paralysis of Latissimus Dorsi: Paralysis of the latissimus dorsi muscle can result in impaired arm extension and adduction. However, it is not the primary cause of winged scapula. The latissimus dorsi muscle has a different function and innervation (thoracodorsal nerve).

 

Option B) Injury to Suprascapular Nerve: Injury to the suprascapular nerve can result in weakness or atrophy of the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. While this can affect shoulder function, it does not directly cause winged scapula.

 

Option D) Paralysis of Deltoid Muscle: Paralysis of the deltoid muscle can lead to difficulty in raising the arm at the shoulder (abduction), but it does not cause winged scapula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Winged scapula is characterized by the protrusion of the scapula (shoulder blade) away from the ribcage. The condition can result from various causes, but the most likely cause is Injury to the long thoracic nerve.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male child presents with a history of spontaneous excessive bruising and hemarthrosis. On investigation, he has a normal platelet count, prolonged PTT, and a normal PT. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemophilia A

 

The Hemophilia A diagnosis is the most likely one. Hemarthrosis, or bleeding into the joints after slight trauma, is a distinctive hemophilia symptom.

 

The clinical case given is the case of a Hemophilia A, and the pattern of inheritance seen in Hemophilia is XLR.

 

Deficiency of factor VIII.

 

C/F:

 

  • ﻿﻿Family history
  • ﻿﻿Bleeding/Bruising with Petechiae.
  • ﻿﻿Hemarthrosis (ankle > knee

 

Pathology; Intrinsic pathway is affected-prolonged aPPT (Normal PT, BT, Platelet count).

 

  • Clinical severity of hemophilia A corresponds positively with factor VIII activity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand Disease: This condition also causes bleeding, but it typically affects platelet adhesion and causes prolonged bleeding time (BT) along with prolonged aPTT. Unlike hemophilia, von Willebrand disease often presents with mucosal bleeding rather than hemarthrosis.

 

Option C. Bernard-Soulier Syndrome: This is a rare inherited platelet disorder characterized by defective platelet adhesion due to a deficiency in glycoprotein Ib. It results in thrombocytopenia and giant platelets, which is not seen in the given case. Platelet count and function would be abnormal, unlike in this patient’s presentation.

 

Option D. Glanzmann Thrombasthenia: This is a platelet aggregation disorder due to a deficiency in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Patients would present with prolonged bleeding time and mucosal bleeding rather than hemarthrosis. Platelet function studies would reveal abnormal aggregation.

 

Educational Objective:


Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of clotting factor VIII, resulting in prolonged aPTT with normal PT and platelet count, and presenting clinically with hemarthrosis and easy bruising.

questions.text: Identify the procedure in the following image? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loop ileostomy

 

A loop ileostomy involves bringing a loop of the ileum out to the abdominal surface, creating a stoma with two lumens (openings). This procedure is commonly used as a temporary diversion of stool to protect a distal anastomosis, such as in segmental colonic resections. The image clearly shows two openings, which is characteristic of a loop ileostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. End Colostomy

 

  • Description: An end colostomy will show a single opening where the end of the colon is brought to the surface of the abdomen.
  • Relevance: The presence of two lumens in the image rules out an end colostomy.

 

 

Option C. Entero-cutaneous Fistula

 

  • Description: An entero-cutaneous fistula is a complication of bowel injury where the bowel communicates exteriorly.
  • Relevance: The image shows surgical sutures, implying an intentional procedure, not a complication like an entero-cutaneous fistula.

 

Option D. Appendectomy

 

  • Description: Appendectomy is the surgical removal of the appendix.
  • Relevance: The image does not show the typical appearance or site of an appendectomy incision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A loop ileostomy is characterized by two lumens brought out to the skin and is typically used as a temporary measure to divert stool and protect distal anastomoses in surgeries.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following condition as shown below. What could be the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Venous ulcer

 

  • The area affected is known as Gaiter’s region - It is located just above medial malleolus and there is characteristic sloping edge seen in Healing or varicose ulcers.
  • Appearance of a Venous ulcer - Skin surrounding a venous ulcer is often discolored. The skin may be pale, hyperpigmented, purple, red, dark brown, speckled with dark spots, and/or covered with spider veins. Visible varicose veins may also be present
  • Arterial ulcer- that appears punched out with thin and shiny skin surrounding it. There is loss of hair and the nails are brittle.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are commonly located just above the medial malleolus in the Gaiter’s region and present with discoloration of the surrounding skin. They are associated with chronic venous insufficiency and are differentiated from arterial, neuropathic, and pressure ulcers by their location, appearance, and associated skin changes.

questions.text: A person was lost in the desert. For more than 24 hours he did not consume food or water. His vitals were normal. In which of the following parts of the nephron must have been the site of maximum water reabsorption in this case? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Proximal convoluted tubule

 

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is where the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the nephron, consistently reabsorbing about 67% of the filtered water regardless of hydration status. This part of the nephron is crucial for initial volume regulation of the filtrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loop of Henle: Incorrect because while it does contribute to water reabsorption, especially in its descending limb, it is not the site of maximum water reabsorption.

 

Option C. Distal convoluted tubule: Incorrect as this section of the nephron is primarily involved in the reabsorption of ions rather than water.

 

Option D. Collecting duct: Incorrect because, although it can significantly increase water reabsorption under the influence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) during dehydration, it does not inherently reabsorb as much water as the proximal tubule under normal conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percentage of reabsorption occurring in pct -

Sodium potassium and Water (67%)

Calcium (70%)

Phosphate and HCO3 (80%)

Glucose and amino acid (100%)

Parts of nephron and their major function is shown in the image below

choices.text: Hypopharyngeal abscess
Parapharyngeal abscess
Post-cricoid malignancy
Prevertebral abscess

questions.text: In all of the following, laryngeal crepitus is absent except? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parapharyngeal abscess

 

Laryngeal crepitus is normally felt, while moving larynx over the cervical spine.

 

Any condition posterior to cricoid (Post-cricoid malignancy) and anterior to cervical vertebra (Prevertebral abscess, Hypopharyngeal abscess) can lead to Absent Laryngeal crepitus.

 

Parapharyngeal abscess: Though an abscess in this area may seem to significantly influence the structure of the throat, it does not typically block the lateral movement of the larynx as severely as other conditions, allowing some degree of normal laryngeal crepitus.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hypopharyngeal abscess: Positioned posterior to the cricoid area, which can obstruct the larynx's movement, leading to the absence of crepitus.

 

Option C. Post-cricoid malignancy: Directly impacts the region behind the cricoid cartilage, likely restricting laryngeal movement and therefore reducing or eliminating crepitus.

 

Option D. Prevertebral abscess: This is located anterior to the cervical vertebrae and can severely restrict the backward movement of the larynx, leading to the absence of crepitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parapharyngeal abscess is the only condition listed that does not inherently restrict the side-to-side movement of the larynx to the degree that would abolish laryngeal crepitus. This differentiates it from the other conditions which involve structures directly affecting the ability of the larynx to move freely over the cervical spine.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is given to mother delivering premature baby for fetal lung maturation? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dexamethasone

 

Corticosteroids are used in pregnant females delivering premature babies in order to prevent respiratory distress syndrome in the newborn due to inadequate levels of surfactants in the lungs of premature babies. Corticosteroids also reduce the chances of development of Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intraventricular Hemorrhage in the new born.

 

For this purpose, we can use either Dexamethasone or Betamethasone.

 

Dose:

  1. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly x 4 doses

  2. Betamethasone 12mg 24 hourly x 2 doses

 

Total dose should be 24 mg in 48 hrs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: This medication is primarily used as an anti-inflammatory and antithrombotic agent but is not employed for fetal lung maturation. In pregnancy, it's often prescribed in low doses to prevent preeclampsia in high-risk cases, not for lung development.

 

Option C. Magnesium sulfate: This drug is used during pregnancy to prevent seizures in women with severe preeclampsia or eclampsia and to protect the brains of premature babies, not directly for lung maturation.

 

Option D. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a form of long-acting progesterone used for contraception. It has no role in fetal lung maturation and is not recommended during pregnancy for any indication related to fetal development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the purpose of accelerating lung maturity in fetuses at risk of premature birth, corticosteroids such as dexamethasone are the treatment of choice. This intervention is critical to enhancing neonatal outcomes by reducing the incidence and severity of respiratory distress and other complications associated with prematurity.

questions.text: Identify the labelled tarsal bone in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Navicular

 

The image shows the navicular bone which is interposed between the head of the talus and the cuneiforms. The navicular bone is important for maintaining the longitudinal arch of the foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcaneus:  It  is the largest bone in the human foot and forms the heel. It is located at the posterior (back) part of the foot, just below the talus. It articulates with the talus bone superiorly and with the cuboid bone anteriorly. Injuries to the calcaneus, such as fractures, can be quite disabling and may result from falls or high-impact trauma.

 

Option B. Cuboid:  It is one of the seven tarsal bones in the foot. It is located on the lateral (outer) side of the foot, between the calcaneus and the fourth and fifth metatarsal bones. The cuboid bone helps to maintain the arch of the foot and provides stability to the lateral aspect of the midfoot.

 

Option D. Talus bone: often referred to as the anklebone, is a small bone that forms the main connection between the foot and the leg. It sits atop the calcaneus and articulates with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint. The talus is essential for ankle movement, allowing dorsiflexion (raising the foot) and plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward). It also plays a role in inversion and eversion of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are 7 tarsal bones and they occupy the proximal half of foot.

 

  • The proximal row is made up of the talus and calcaneus.
  • The distal row from medial - lateral contains - cuneiforms (medial, intermediate, lateral) and the cuboid.

 

Medially the navicular bone is interposed between the head of the talus and the cuneiforms

questions.text: A patient presented with anal discharge. On examination there is no pain. The picture is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in Ano

 

Perianal fistula

 

  • A fistula-in-Ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin.
  • Anal fistulas can have many causes but are most commonly the result of an anorectal abscess.

 

Symptoms of an anal fistula include:

 

  • Skin irritation around the anus.
  • A constant, throbbing pain
  • Anal discharge

 

Treatment: Fistulotomy or Fistulectomy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fistula-in-Ano is characterized by an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin, commonly resulting from an anorectal abscess and presenting with skin irritation, constant throbbing pain, and anal discharge.

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the casualty with symptoms of recurrent non-bilious vomiting and extreme hunger after vomiting. The mother has felt a lump in his abdomen while bathing him. What could he possibly be suffering from? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Congenital Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)

 

  • IOC is USG – on USG, increase pyloric canal length >16mm and also there is increase pyloric muscle wall
  • Thickness >3 mm thickness → Cervix sign.
  • The thick muscle which appears hypoechoic and hyperechoic mucosa in the center gives target sign

 

Appearance

 

  • On barium → string sign / double tract sign.
  • Mucosal outpouching → Twinning recess / diamond sign
  • The shape of the duodenum gets altered producing – mushroom sign, beak sign, teak sign.
  • Single bubble sign in CHPS
  • Image should show 16 mm not 16 cm

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal Atresia: It is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in a newborn characterized by projectile bilious vomiting, polyhydramnios. It is frequently associated with Down syndrome and on X-ray, it is characterized by Double Bubble Sign.

 

Option B. Divarication of recti: Divarication of recti, also known as diastasis recti, refers to the separation of the rectus abdominis muscles along the midline of the abdomen. It commonly occurs during and after pregnancy due to the stretching of the abdominal wall but can also be seen in other situations, including obesity and in some newborns.

 

Option D. Para-umbilical hernia: It is a protrusion of a viscous or part of it through the linea alba abutting superiorly or inferiorly on the umbilicus. Most common presentation of PUH is swelling adjacent to umbilicus with the involvement of one of the walls of the umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting and a palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen, with the diagnosis confirmed by ultrasound showing increased pyloric canal length and muscle wall thickness.

choices.text: Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 32 weeks of gestation. She underwent OGTT (75 g of glucose) and her values were fasting 110 mg/dl and 2 hours glucose at 180 mg/dI. Which of the following is the next step regarding the management of this patient? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Admit and start insulin

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) as her OGTT results exceed the normal ranges.
  • The diagnostic criteria for GDM with a 75 g OGTT are:
    • Fasting glucose: ≥92 mg/dl
    • 1-hour glucose: ≥180 mg/dl
    • 2-hour glucose: ≥153 mg/dl
  • Given her fasting glucose level of 110 mg/dl and 2-hour glucose of 180 mg/dl, her levels are significantly elevated, indicating the need for medical management.
  • Insulin is preferred over oral hypoglycemics (OHAs) in this scenario due to the elevated fasting glucose level.
  • The initial insulin dose is typically divided and ranges from 0.7 to 1 unit/kg/day, often using a combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral hypoglycemics: OHAs are not the first choice in this scenario due to the elevated fasting glucose levels. Insulin is preferred for better control.

 

Option B. Reassurance: Reassurance alone is inappropriate as the patient has gestational diabetes requiring intervention to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Induce labour due to risk of fetal macrosomia: Immediate induction of labour is not indicated solely based on the diagnosis of gestational diabetes at this stage. Proper management with insulin and monitoring is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of gestational diabetes mellitus, especially with elevated fasting glucose levels, insulin is the preferred treatment to achieve optimal glycemic control and prevent complications.

 

Ref: Page no 2783, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Hepatitis B in the remote past
Recovering from hepatitis B
All of the above

questions.text: The lab reports of a 40-year-old man show positive IgG anti-HbC and negative HbsAg. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B in the remote past.

 

The lab findings of positive IgG anti-HbC (anti-Hepatitis B core antibody) and negative HbsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) indicate that the patient had a past infection with Hepatitis B and has now recovered. This serological pattern is seen in individuals who were previously infected with Hepatitis B, have cleared the infection, and developed immunity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Immunisation with HbsAg: Immunization with the Hepatitis B vaccine would result in a positive anti-HbS but negative anti-HbC, as the vaccine does not contain the core antigen.

 

Option C. Recovering from hepatitis B: During the recovery phase, both HbsAg and anti-HbC (IgM initially, then IgG) can be positive. However, the presence of IgG anti-HbC and negative HbsAg suggests that the infection is not recent and the patient has recovered.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: During a clinical teaching session in a teaching hospital, a senior physician is guiding a medical intern on the appropriate method to elicit the knee reflex. The intern is carefully observing and then practicing the technique himself under supervision. Considering the domains of learning, this type of hands-on learning where a skill or physical action is being taught and practiced primarily pertains to which category? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Psychomotor learning

 

In the given example, learning is happening by the demonstration of the action.

 

Actions which demonstrate the fine or gross motor skills, such as use of precision instruments or tools and attention is given to the learning of coordinated activity involving the arms, hands, fingers and feet while verbal processes are not emphasized.  Thus, this is an example of psychomotor learning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type of Learning and Associations

 

  • Cognitive learning - Knowledge
  • Affective learning - Attitudes
  • Psychomotor learning - Skills

questions.text: While camping in a forest, backpackers find a dead body of a 10-year-old child. Which bone would be best for gender assessment? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hip

 

As per Krogman’s table, best bone for determination of sex is Hip/ pelvis.

 

In pelvis greater sciatic notch is best used for gender estimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skull: Provides 90% accuracy in sex determination.

 

Option B. Femur: Long bones generally provide around 80% accuracy.

 

Option D. Mandible: While useful, it is less accurate compared to the pelvis.


Educational Objective:

 

The hip (pelvis) bone is the most reliable for gender assessment, providing the highest accuracy according to Krogman’s table.

 

Krogman’s Table: percentage of accuracy in determination of sex from bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above clinical characteristics, history, and hysteroscopic findings are suggestive of Asherman syndrome.
  • Asherman syndrome is intra-uterine adhesions which usually occurs following a D & C.
  • It can also be seen as a sequalae of genital TB
  • C/F: Hypomenorrhea, Secondary amenorrhea and infertility
  • Diagnosis: 
    • HSG: moth eaten appearance, honeycomb appearance

 

 

  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallman syndrome: Kallman syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not related to intrauterine adhesions or previous surgical history.

 

Option C. Sheehan syndrome: Sheehan syndrome refers to hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis due to severe postpartum hemorrhage. It presents with symptoms of pituitary hormone deficiencies, not intrauterine adhesions.

 

Option D. Stein-Leventhal syndrome: Stein-Leventhal syndrome, commonly known as Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), is characterized by irregular menstrual periods, excess androgen levels, and polycystic ovaries. It does not cause intrauterine adhesions or a honeycomb appearance on HSG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions often following procedures like dilatation and curettage, presenting with secondary amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, and infertility. It can be diagnosed through HSG showing a honeycomb appearance.

 

Ref: Page 384, DC Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition

choices.text: Diffuse esophageal spasm

questions.text: In which of the following condition is Dohlman’s procedure is performed? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

 

Zenker’s diverticulum: Most common type of esophageal diverticulum

 

  • Symptoms – Dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation and weight loss
  • Most common complication in lung abscess.
  • Investigation of choice: barium swallow
  • Treatment: Dohlman’s procedure (diverticulo-esophagostomy)
  • Alternative treatment: Diverticulectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cricoid webs are seen in Plummer Vinson Syndrome. It is a pre-malignant condition and can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus. It is seen in females and is characterized by iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia and esophageal webs. Koilonychia, Glossitis, Weight loss are also seen.

 

 

Endoscopy showing Post-cricoid web

 

 

Note the post-cricoid constriction in the barium swallow

 

Option C. Achalasia cardia is the most common esophageal motility disorder characterized by absence of peristalsis. It occurs due to loss of inhibitory neurons at the lower esophagus, leading to un-inhibited contraction of LES. For Achalasia cardia, Heller’s cardiomyotomy is performed. Nowadays, POEM (Per-oral endoscopic myotomy) is being performed. IOC: Endoscopy + Manometry. On barium swallow, bird beak or rat tail appearance is seen.

 

 

Note the bird beak appearance on barium swallow

 

Option D. Diffuse Esophageal spasm is characterized by diffuse irregular spasmodic contraction of the esophagus. The patient complaints of dysphagia, chest pain, heartburn. Treatment options include Injection Botox, Calcium channel blockers etc. On barium swallow, corkscrew esophagus is seen.

 

 

Note the corkscrew appearance on barium swallow

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman’s procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker’s diverticulum, which is an esophageal diverticulum characterized by symptoms such as dysphagia and halitosis

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman diagnosed with malaria based on the peripheral blood smear, as shown below. What could be the causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum:

 

In the given blood smear multiple rings can be seen known as the trophozoite with in the RBC’s which are a Specific characteristic of plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Typically infects young RBCs (reticulocytes) and shows Schüffner's dots in the infected RBCs. The schizonts and gametocytes are not banana-shaped.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Infects young RBCs and shows oval-shaped infected cells with fimbriated edges.

 

Option D. P. malariae: Infects older RBCs and has a band form in the trophozoite stage. It does not show multiple ring forms within a single RBC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important points to remember can be simplified as AMBER:

 

  • A – All age RBCs are affected
  • M – Maurer’s dot can be seen
  • B – Banana shaped gametocyte are observed
  • A – Accole forms are observed
  • R – Recrudescence is associated with it also renal failure is seen

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came with complaints of right flank a pain associated with fever and chills. On examination, the patient had pain on the passive extension of the hip over the right side. CT scan shows findings as shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoas Abscess

 

  • Right psoas muscle is bulky with presence of a ring enhancing lesion within it suggestive of psoas abscess.
  • Etiology: Pyogenic or TB
  • IOC: MRI
  • Clinical test for flexion limitation: Thomas test

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: Would typically present with signs of infection and might show changes in the kidney such as swelling or striation but would not cause the muscle changes seen in the psoas area.

 

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Could present with right lower abdominal pain and systemic symptoms but would not explain the changes in the psoas muscle or a mass in that location.

 

 

Option D. Torsion of Right Undescended Testis: Presents with acute scrotal or inguinal pain, not typically associated with a psoas mass or changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoas abscess should be suspected in patients presenting with flank pain, fever, and hip extension pain, particularly when imaging shows a bulky psoas muscle with a ring-enhancing lesion.

questions.text: Along with scorpion sting, which of the following venoms produces catecholamine storm? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spider

 

Spider venom is capable of harming humans similar to scorpion venoms. These are excitatory neurotoxins and locally necrotic cytotoxins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tick venom is presynaptic neurotoxin

 

Option C. Sea urchins occur worldwide and most injuries occur when they are trodden on or occasionally when they are picked up. Most spines are non-venomous and the type of spines range from chalk-like to strong thorn-like material.

 

Option D. Ciguatera is the commonest marine poisoning and is endemic to regions of the Indo-Pacific and Caribbean. It is due to accumulated toxins in tropical reef fish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spider venom, similar to scorpion venom, can cause a catecholamine storm due to the release of excitatory neurotoxins.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male student and several of his peers from the same boarding school present with abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever after eating in their canteen. Which immunological marker should be tested to confirm the suspected infectious disease? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IgM for Hepatitis A

 

From the given clinical clue, it seems to be an outbreak of acute viral hepatitis due to consumption of contaminated food from the same canteen. Hepatitis A and E can be transmitted by feco oral route and in the acute setting, testing for IgM antibodies against Hepatitis A would be most appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IgG for Hepatitis A: Indicates past infection or immunity and does not reflect acute infection.

 

Option C. IgM for Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B's primary transmission is not feco-oral, making it less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D. IgG for Hepatitis B: Shows past infection or vaccination, irrelevant for diagnosing an acute outbreak from a shared food source.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the likely metabolic abnormality that can be seen? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

Chronic vomiting leads to the loss of gastric acid (HCl), resulting in a metabolic alkalosis. The loss of HCl means that chloride is also lost, which leads to hypochloremia. The body tries to compensate for the loss of chloride by retaining bicarbonate, which exacerbates the alkalosis.

 

Vomiting also results in the loss of potassium, leading to hypokalemia. Additionally, vomiting causes the loss of sodium and water, which can lead to hyponatremia due to volume depletion and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This system further increases renal excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, exacerbating the hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Initial vomiting leads to loss of HCl (hydrochloric acid), causing a metabolic alkalosis.
  • The body compensates by excreting bicarbonate along with sodium, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Hyponatremia triggers the RAAS, which retains sodium but also increases potassium and hydrogen ion excretion, leading to hypokalemia and further metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial vomiting → HCL loss = metabolic alkalosis = loss of alkali in urine (with Na)→ Hyponatremia → RAAS Activation → Hypokalemia + loss of H+ = aciduria.

choices.text: Occurs more commonly in sunny areas.
Conjunctival autograft may be used in its treatment.

questions.text: What of the following statement is incorrect about the given image?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It causes myopia

 

The give condition in the image is pterygium.

 

Pterygium

 

  • A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • Typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and may represent a response to UV exposure and chronic surface dryness.
  • Familial.
  • Histologically similar to a pinguecula: shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.
  • Encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer.
  • Clinical features

 

Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt excision biopsy.

  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying – effect at the advancing edge due to interference with the precorneal tear film (more likely if the head of the pterygium is especially elevated).
  • Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Extensive lesions (if recurrent) may have subconjunctival fibrosis extending to the fornices causing restricted ocular excursion.
  • Made up of three parts: a ‘cap’ (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head and a body.
  • Linear epithelial iron deposition (Stocker line): seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the head of the pterygium.
  • Fuchs islets are small discrete whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells often present at the advancing edge.
  • Treatment
    • Advised to wear sunglasses to reduce UV exposure.
    • Surgery:
      1. Simple excision (‘bare sclera’ technique: The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva leaving bare sclera) (around 80% rate of recurrence).
      2. Conjunctival autografting: (reduces recurrence) The donor conjunctival patch is sutured or glued into position.
      3. Adjunctive treatment: (reduces recurrence) With mitomycin C or betairradiation can be used in place of patching techniques.
      4. Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty: For deep lesions.
  • Pseudopterygium resembles pterygium clinically but is caused by a band of conjunctiva adhering to a compromised cornea at its apex. It is located away from the horizontal (though sometimes seen in true pterygia) and is firmly attached to the cornea only at its apex (head).
  • It forms in response to acute inflammatory events like chemical burns, corneal ulcers (especially marginal ones), trauma, and cicatrizing conjunctivitis. Suspected pseudopterygium may be associated with a history of the causative episode.
  • A 'probe' test can be performed where the probe can be passed beneath the tissue in pseudo-pterygium but not in pterygium. It can appear in any quadrant of the eye and is non-progressive in nature. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs more commonly in sunny areas: This is true because UV exposure is a major risk factor for pterygium.

 

Option B. Conjunctival autograft may be used in its treatment: This is true and is a common method to reduce recurrence after surgical removal.

 

Option D. Iron deposition is found: This is true as the Stocker line is a characteristic feature of pterygium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium typically does not cause myopia but can induce astigmatism. It is characterized by a fibrovascular growth on the cornea, often associated with UV exposure, and can be treated surgically with techniques like conjunctival autografting to reduce recurrence.

 

Ref: Pg 198/ Ch.6 Conjunctiva/ Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology/ 9th ed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with gum bleeding and fatigue. His peripheral smear showing marked leukocytosis with 70% cells showing MPO positivity. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AML

 

By Taking bone marrow aspiration with more than 30% MPO positive immature cells points to acute leukemia with myeloid origin. MPO is the hallmark enzyme of myeloid lineage and can be detected by cytochemical staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CML presents with massive splenomegaly with FISH Showing t (9:22) translocation.

 

Option C. CLL presents with cervical lymphadenopathy with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

 

Option D. ALL presents in children with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphoblasts and Immunophenotyping shows terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myeloperoxidase (MPO) positivity is a key marker for diagnosing Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).

questions.text: An elderly diabetic male patient underwent kidney transplantation from his twin brother. The type of grafting is SURGERY. (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. In this scenario, the elderly diabetic male patient received a kidney from his twin brother, making it an isograft. Since the donor and recipient are genetically identical, the risk of graft rejection is minimal, and the immunologic compatibility is at its highest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allograft: An allograft refers to a graft between genetically different individuals of the same species. This type of graft is common in most organ transplants where the donor and recipient are not genetically identical, leading to a higher risk of rejection and the need for immunosuppressive therapy.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissues or organs between two different species. An example would be grafting pig heart valves into humans. This type of graft faces significant immunological challenges and a high risk of rejection.

 

Option D. Autograft: An autograft is a graft taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body. This is commonly seen in skin grafting for burn patients or using one's own vein for coronary artery bypass surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autografts: Taking from one part to another in the same body
  • Allografts: between genetically different individuals of same species
  • Isografts: The graft between identical twins
  • Xeno grafts: The graft between two different species

questions.text: A person was found dead on road side. On examination there was cyanosis of the nails, scratches over face, neck and chin, and laceration near lips. Which of the following is not the probable mode of death in this case? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Case of a suicide

 

The described findings—cyanosis of the nails, scratches over the face, neck, and chin, and a laceration near the lips—are indicative of a violent struggle and are consistent with asphyxial death due to smothering and throttling. These injuries suggest external force was applied to the neck and face, pointing towards a homicidal act.

 

Unlikely, as the nature and distribution of injuries suggest an external assault rather than self-inflicted harm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Likely, as it involves external pressure applied to the neck, causing asphyxia.

 

Option B. It’s a Homicide: Likely, given the evidence of struggle and violent assault.

 

Option C. Asphyxia: Likely, as indicated by the cyanosis and external injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple external injuries and signs of a struggle strongly indicates that the mode of death is likely homicide due to throttling and asphyxia, not suicide.

questions.text: Rice water stools are characteristic feature of: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholera

 

Rice water stools are a characteristic feature of cholera, caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The hallmark of cholera is profuse, watery diarrhea that resembles rice water. This is due to the action of cholera toxin, which has a specific mechanism that leads to severe fluid loss.

 

Cholera toxin:

 

  • Made up of 2A + 5B (B- helps in binding to GM1 ganglioside receptor) helps in ADP Ribosylation of GTP as a result there is an increase in adenylate cyclase activity causes an Increase in CAMP leads to intra cellular water in lumen causing massive cholera (rise watery stool)
  • Treatment: rehydration with IV fluids
  • It mimics arsenic metal poisoning
  • Lab diagnosis: Stool sample
  • Hanging drop: darting motility seen
  • String sign: stool + Na deoxycholate: string forms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shigella: Typically causes dysentery with bloody stools, not rice water stools.

 

Option C. E. coli: Various strains cause different types of diarrhea, but rice water stools are not characteristic.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Generally causes gastroenteritis with diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps, but not rice water stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice water stools are characteristic of cholera, which is caused by the cholera toxin leading to severe watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Based on the logo depicted in the image, which of the following does it represent? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Suraksha clinic

 

The above image is the logo for Suraksha clinic. Suraksha clinics are the Chain of RTI/STI clinics to provide reproductive and sexual health services.

 

  • Established by: National AIDS Control Program, NACO
  • Purpose: Control of STI/RTIs viz., HIV, Syphilis, Gonorrhea, Herpes, Chlamydia, Genital warts
  • Facilities: Blood sample testing, Counselling, Syndromic case management (RTI/STI/RPR kits)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allopathic private clinic practitioner logo:

 

 

Option B. First aid logo:

 

 

Option C. Red cross emblem logo: 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suraksha clinics, established under the National AIDS Control Program to provide specialized healthcare services related to STIs and RTIs, enhancing public health outreach in sexual health.

questions.text: Postoperative delirium and hallucination is seen with which intravenous anesthetic agent? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Ketamine:

 

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative used as a dissociative anesthetic. It is known to cause postoperative delirium and hallucinations. Its dissociative properties result in a state where the patient feels detached from their surroundings.

 

  1. K – Kids - Suited for children due to its rapid onset and minimal respiratory depression.
  2. E – Emergent reactions like hallucinations and vivid dreams.
  3. T – It produces a unique Type of anesthesia termed "dissociative anesthesia," where the patient might appear awake but is not responsive to pain stimuli.
  4. A – It provides Analgesia, making it useful for pain management.
  5. M – Safe to administer even if the patient has a full stomach because it preserves airway reflexes, thus reducing the risk of aspiration.
  6. I – uses an Increase in blood pressure, Intraocular pressure, and Intracranial pressure.
  7. N – Acts as an antagonist to the NMDA receptors, which is its primary mechanism of action.
  8. E – Acts as a bronchodilator, making it a preferred agent in asthmatic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol is a sedative-hypnotic agent primarily used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. While it provides rapid onset and short duration of action, it doesn't commonly cause delirium or hallucinations postoperatively.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate anesthetic used for rapid induction. It's known for its quick onset and longer duration but is not typically associated with postoperative delirium or hallucinations.

 

Option D. Etomidate: Etomidate is a non-barbiturate hypnotic used for induction in anesthesia. It provides rapid onset and short duration of anesthesia without significant cardiovascular or respiratory depression. It's not known for causing postoperative delirium or hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Ketamine is known to cause postoperative delirium and hallucinations.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs. 2643-2644

questions.text: Beta blockers should be avoided in all of the following conditions, except? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glaucoma

 

Beta blockers are actually beneficial in the treatment of glaucoma. Topical beta blockers, such as Timolol, Betaxolol, and Levobunolol, are commonly used to reduce intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients. They achieve this by decreasing aqueous humor production within the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bradycardia: Beta blockers should be avoided in patients with bradycardia as they reduce heart rate. Using them in patients with already low heart rates can lead to dangerously low levels that might not support adequate cardiac output.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: While not an absolute contraindication, caution is advised when prescribing beta blockers to diabetes patients. They can mask hypoglycemic symptoms (like tachycardia), potentially leading to unawareness in diabetic patients during a hypoglycemic episode.

 

Option D. Acute decompensated Congestive heart failure: Beta blockers are generally avoided in the acute management of decompensated heart failure because they can further depress myocardial function and exacerbate the condition. They are, however, used in the chronic management of heart failure due to their benefits in reducing mortality over the long term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta blockers should be avoided in -

 

  • Bradycardia

  • Bronchial asthma

  • Diabetes mellitus

  • Peripheral vascular disease

  • Acute decompensated Congestive heart failure

questions.text: A medical officer at the NCDC is developing a rabies prevention program and notes that certain Indian territories are rabies-free. Which of the following is recognized as such? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Andaman & Nicobar

 

The Andaman & Nicobar Islands, along with Lakshadweep, are recognized as rabies-free regions in India. This status is attributed to strict animal control and surveillance measures that prevent the introduction and spread of rabies in these island territories.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep Island and now goa  are currently Rabies-free.

questions.text: A kidney disease patient comes for organ transplantation. He has a twin brother who is a match donor for him. Which type of grafting it would be considered as?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isograft

 

An isograft is a graft between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. In this scenario, the kidney disease patient and his twin brother are genetically identical, which classifies the transplant as an isograft. The benefit of isografting is that there is minimal risk of graft rejection because the donor and recipient are genetically identical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allograft: An allograft is a graft between genetically different individuals of the same species. This type of grafting is common but carries a higher risk of rejection due to the genetic differences between donor and recipient.

 

Option C. Autograft: An autograft involves transplanting tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. This method is commonly used in skin grafts and does not apply to the scenario where the donor is a twin.

 

Option D. Xenograft: A xenograft is a graft between individuals of different species. This type of grafting has a very high risk of rejection due to the significant genetic differences and is not applicable to human-to-human transplants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autografts: from one part to another in the same body
  • Allografts: between genetically different individuals of same species
  • Isografts: graft between identical twins
  • Xenografts: graft between two different species

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with weakness in the right arm for 6 hours. The weakness gradually became lesser and resolved. She is a known case of diabetes and hypertension and is obese. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this case? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transient ischemic attack


The clinical scenario of sudden onset weakness that resolves within 24 hours is suggestive of a Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA). TIAs are characterized by transient neurological symptoms due to temporary ischemia without acute infarction. The symptoms resolve completely within 24 hours.

 

ABCD² Score: The ABCD² score is used to assess the risk of stroke following a TIA:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to the original score. However all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidence.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ischemic stroke: An ischemic stroke typically leaves a lasting focal neurological deficit and would be evident on radiological imaging. The resolution of symptoms within 24 hours makes ischemic stroke less likely.

 

Option C. Compressive neuropathy: This condition usually presents with paraparesis, radiculopathy, and potentially sphincter disturbances (bladder and bowel issues). The sudden onset and resolution of symptoms are not characteristic of compressive neuropathy.

 

Option D. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy generally presents with distal sensory motor symptoms or proximal neuroradiculopathy and does not typically cause sudden onset and resolution of unilateral weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is characterized by sudden onset of neurological symptoms that resolve within 24 hours. The ABCD² score is used to assess the risk of stroke following a TIA, with higher scores indicating a greater risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient after gunshot injury is brought to emergency department with acute blood loss resulting in severe hypovolemia. Which color iv cannula can be used for most rapid blood transfusion? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orange  

 

Orange Cannula:

 

  • Definition: The orange IV cannula has the largest gauge among the commonly used cannulas, specifically 14G.
  • Usage: Due to its large diameter, it allows for the most rapid administration of fluids, making it ideal for situations requiring rapid blood transfusion, such as severe hypovolemia from acute blood loss.

 

Color and Gauge of IV cannulas: -

 

  • Yellow - 24G
  • Blue - 22G
  • Pink - 20G
  • Green - 18G
  • Grey - 16G
  • Orange - 14G

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow Cannula:

 

  • Gauge: 24G
  • Usage: This is a very small gauge cannula used typically for pediatric patients or for very slow infusion rates. It is not suitable for rapid blood transfusion due to its small size.

 

Option C. Gray Cannula:

 

  • Gauge: 16G
  • Usage: This is a large gauge cannula and can also be used for rapid blood transfusion.

 

Option D. Green Cannula:

 

  • Gauge: 18G
  • Usage: This is a medium-sized cannula commonly used for general IV infusions. It allows for moderate flow rates but is not the best option for rapid blood transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For rapid blood transfusion in emergency situations involving severe hypovolemia, the orange IV cannula (14G) is preferred due to its large diameter, allowing for the highest flow rate among the commonly used IV cannulas.

questions.text: For disposal of which of the following, a white bag is used? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sharp waste

 

Sharp wastes like needles etc. are discarded in puncture proof white containers

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Anatomical wastes are discarded in Yellow bags.

 

Option B. Glassware wastes are put in Blue containers.

 

Option D. Plastic wastes are discarded in Red bags.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW BMW Management Guidelines

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with deformity of the hand as shown below. There is decreased motion in the small joints and loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. Her chest radiograph showed prominent bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scleroderma
 

The clinical scenario described is suggestive of scleroderma, specifically characterized by sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands) and systemic involvement such as interstitial lung disease (ILD). The decreased motion in the small joints, loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin, and bilateral lower lobe infiltrates on chest radiograph further support the diagnosis of scleroderma.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): RA can present with joint deformities in the later stages but does not typically involve skin thickening and tightening as seen in scleroderma.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: While pneumonia can cause bilateral infiltrates on chest radiographs, it does not cause the hand deformities or skin changes described.

 

Option D. Systemic lupus (SLE): SLE can produce a variety of systemic symptoms and can lead to secondary Sjogren's syndrome or overlap with RA, but it does not typically cause the specific hand deformities and skin tightening seen in scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleroderma, characterized by sclerodactyly and systemic involvement such as interstitial lung disease, is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's clinical presentation and radiographic findings.

 

Comparison of Limited vs. Diffuse Scleroderma:

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of facial edema that has now progressed to generalized swelling affecting his face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and a urine protein: creatinine ratio of 3. What is the primary treatment of choice for this child? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Prednisolone

 

The above clinical features of facial edema followed by anasarca, along with proteinuria is suggestive of Nephrotic Syndrome in a child. Considering the age given, this is most likely a case of minimal change disease.

 

  • The DOC for the initial episode of Nephrotic Syndrome in a child is Prednisolone. It is given at a dose of 2mg/kg/day or 60mg/m2/day daily for 6 weeks followed by 1.5mg/kg/day or 40mg/m2/day every alternate day for 6 weeks.

  • 80-90% of the children show response within 2-3 weeks.

 

Other Options:
