Option B. Cyclophosphamide: It is not recommended as first line treatment choice in Nephrotic Syndrome. Treatment with cyclophosphamide and alternate day prednisolone is effective in many patients with frequent relapsing or steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. A high fluid intake is ensured to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis. It carries a minimal risk of gonadal toxicity and malignancies.

 

Option C. Levamisole: It is not recommended as first line treatment choice in Nephrotic Syndrome. It is an immunomodulator which is effective in reducing relapses in patients with frequent relapsing or steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. Treatment with levamisole is given for 1-2 year or longer. The chief side effect is leukopenia, which should be monitored every 2 months; others include flu-like symptoms and rash.

 

Option D. Cyclosporine: It is not recommended as first line treatment choice in Nephrotic Syndrome. It is indicated in patients that fail to benefit with other steroid-sparing agents or show high steroid threshold with steroid toxicity. It has a strong steroid-sparing potential, with steroid discontinuation achieved in most patients over 6-9 months. Adverse effects include acute and chronic nephrotoxicity. A renal biopsy is done after 2-3 years of continuous therapy. Patients receiving cyclosporine have cosmetic side effects (hirsutism, gum hyperplasia), hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For initial episodes of Nephrotic Syndrome in children, particularly when minimal change disease is suspected, Prednisolone is the first-line treatment, effectively reducing proteinuria and managing symptoms with a high success rate in inducing remission.

questions.text: While performing surgery for acute appendicitis on a 5-year-old child the following structure was found 2 feet proximal to ileocecal junction and it was 2 inches long. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Meckel's diverticulum is the structure that is present 2 feet near the ileocecal junction and it is 2 inches long, according to the clinical history provided.

 

When a congenital diverticulum first appears in children.

 

With all three layers of the gut wall out pouched, it is a "real" diverticulum.

 

Pathogenesis

 

  • Persistence of vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct in small intestine  
  • May have ectopic acid-secreting gastric or pancreatic tissue

 

Epidemiology - most common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract

 

Rule of 2’s

 

  • Affects 2% of population
  • 2 feet from ileocecal valve
  • 2 inches long
  • 2 types of epithelia tissue: gastric and pancreatic
  • Male: female ratio 2:1
  • Patients < 2 years old
  • 2% symptomatic

 

Symptoms -

 

  • Painless rectal bleeding -due to gastric acid secretion causing damage to small bowel tissue
  • Normal abdominal exam
  • May serve as lead point for intussusception
  • Small bowel obstruction

 

Evaluation - Most commonly discovered as incidental finding on laparotomy

 

  • Technetium-99m scan aka Meckel scan
  • Most accurate test
  • Technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope is taken up by ectopic gastric mucosa

 

Treatment - Surgical removal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoma: Sarcomas are malignant tumors originating from connective tissues such as bone, cartilage, and muscle, and are not typically associated with findings near the ileocecal junction as described in the case.

 

Option B. Appendicitis: Appendicitis involves inflammation of the appendix, located at the junction of the small and large intestines. The clinical history given, with a structure located 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal junction, does not fit with appendicitis.

 

Option D. Zenker’s diverticulum: Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx. It is not associated with the small intestine or the ileocecal junction, making it unrelated to the case in question.

 

Educational Objective:


Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital outpouching found near the ileocecal junction, diagnosed by the "Rule of 2's" and often discovered incidentally during surgery.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition Chapter 357 – Page No- 7762

questions.text: A gunshot case brought for autopsy shows an entry wound with inverted margins and the wound is surrounded by blackening and tattooing. Singed burnt hair was noted. What is the range of the weapon? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Close contact

 

All three features - singeing, blackening and tattooing are present which is a feature of contact or close contact wound. In close contact they are present around the wound, but in contact only on the margins. In the question all these features are present around the wound (“wound is surrounded by…."), which indicates close contact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Near Range: In the question all three features - singeing, blackening and tattooing are present, whereas in near range, the main feature is tattooing. While blackening may be present sometimes in near range, but singeing is never seen in near range.

 

Option B. Intermediate Range: It is same as near range

 

Option D. Distant Range: Neither of three features (singeing, blackening and tattooing) are present in distant range

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  • Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Loose contact (Near contact) / Close Range (close contact range): Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range / Near range/ Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range / Long Range: None of these present around the wound.

 

Near Contact and Near range are different

questions.text: The image below shows a procedure that was done in the patient. What is the procedure? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tracheostomy

 

The given image shows a tracheostomy tube in the patient. The procedure is called tracheostomy.

 

Tracheostomy is making an opening in the anterior wall of trachea and converting it into a stoma on the skin surface.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endotracheal intubation is done through mouth.

 

 

Option B. Needle cricothyroidotomy provides a secure airway temporarily, to oxygenate and ventilate a patient in severe respiratory distress when other less invasive methods have failed.

 

Option  D. Oropharyngeal airway is used in airway management to maintain or open a patient's airway.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that provides direct access to the breathing tube (trachea) and is used for long-term ventilation and airway management in patients with chronic respiratory problems, severe throat obstructions, or neurological impairments that compromise breathing.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a sudden onset headache, profuse sweating, and palpitations. He had several such episodes in the past with elevated BP recordings. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma


The clinical vignette is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytomas are rare catecholamine-secreting tumors that arise from the adrenal medulla. The classic presentation includes a triad of symptoms: episodic headache, tachycardia, and sweating. These symptoms are due to the excessive production of catecholamines, which cause adrenergic symptoms and episodes of significantly elevated blood pressure.

 

The diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is supported by the finding of elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels. Metanephrines are metabolites of catecholamines, and their elevated levels indicate excess production of catecholamines, which is characteristic of pheochromocytoma. Additionally, VMA (vanillylmandelic acid), an intermediate in catecholamine metabolism, is often elevated in patients with pheochromocytoma and PPGL (paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma syndrome).

 

To assess the adequacy of alpha-blockade, the ROIZEN criteria are used. This ensures proper management of pheochromocytoma, particularly in preparation for surgical removal of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism can cause symptoms such as palpitations and sweating, it does not typically present with the episodic nature of symptoms or the significant hypertension described in the vignette. Furthermore, hyperthyroidism is not associated with elevated urinary metanephrines or VMA levels.

 

Option C. Renal artery stenosis: This condition can lead to secondary hypertension but does not cause the episodic adrenergic symptoms (headache, sweating, palpitations) seen in pheochromocytoma. Renal artery stenosis is not associated with elevated urinary metanephrines or VMA levels.

 

Option D. Fibromuscular dysplasia: This condition affects the renal arteries and can lead to secondary hypertension. However, it does not typically present with the episodic symptoms or elevated urinary metanephrines seen in pheochromocytoma. Fibromuscular dysplasia is not characterized by elevated VMA levels either.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating, along with elevated blood pressure. Diagnosis is supported by elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels. The ROIZEN criteria are used to assess the adequacy of alpha-blockade in the management of pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: What is the most common cause for the appearance shown in the image below?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinoblastoma

 

The image given here shows leukocoria (white eye reflex).

 

Retinoblastoma:

  • Most common eye tumor in children.
  • Rb1 gene located on 13q14 requires both alleles mutated (Knudson’s hypothesis).
  • Rb1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

I. Quiescent stage:

  • Characterised by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

II. Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphaema or pseudohypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

III. Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

IV. Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes
  • Treatment:
    • Enucleation
    • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:

V – Vincristine

E – Etoposide

C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic melanoma: While melanoma can affect the eye, it is not typically associated with leukocoria, especially in children.

 

Option C. HSV keratitis: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) keratitis causes corneal ulcers and inflammation but does not present with leukocoria.

 

Option D. Geographic ulcer: Geographic ulcers are related to corneal infections and do not cause leukocoria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common cause of leukocoria (white eye reflex) in children and requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent life-threatening complications.

 

Other Common causes of leukocoria are-

  • Coats disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
  • Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)
  • Ocular toxocariasis and toxoplasmosis
  • Astrocytic hamartoma
  • Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy (FEVR)
  • Vitreous haemorrhage

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to you with a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a handkerchief. Presence of which of the following features helps you in diagnosing the condition as CSF rhinorrhea? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Halo sign

 

CSF rhinorrhoea after head trauma is mixed with blood and shows double target sign when collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows central red spot (blood) and peripheral lighter halo. Also called as Halo sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Handkerchief sign: This refers to the test where CSF does not stiffen the handkerchief, unlike mucus. Although relevant, it is not as specific as the Halo sign for diagnosing CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Option C. Schwartz sign: This sign is associated with a reddish-blue discoloration seen through the tympanic membrane, indicative of a glomus tumor or vascular abnormality, not CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Option D. Phelps’ sign: Not specifically related to CSF rhinorrhea; it does not pertain to this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Subungual oil drop sign
Thinning of nails

questions.text: The image shown below is a pathognomonic finding in Psoriasis. What is it called?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subungual oil drop sign

 

Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It an inflammatory non-infectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17 & Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails. Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis.
  • It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting (Option A)
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails    

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Nail Pitting: Although commonly seen in psoriasis, nail pitting is not pathognomonic as it can occur in other conditions as well.

 

Option C: Thinning of Nails: Thinning of the nails is not typically associated with psoriasis and is not indicative of this condition.

 

Option D: Nail Pterygium: It is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. Fusion of proximal nail fold and nail bed with destruction of nail plate, leads to pterygium as shown in the below image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis - Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

• P – Pitting (Most common feature)

• O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis

• L - Leukonychia

• I - Irregular pitting pattern

• S - Splinter Hemorrhage

• H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6, 35.9

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with enlarged lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Further investigations reveal the presence of abnormal cells in a lymph node biopsy. The histopathological examination shows large cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli, consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, the biopsy reveals characteristic owl's eye inclusions within the cells.  Which type of cell gives rise to Reed-Sternberg cells, and in which disease are owl's eye inclusions seen? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B cells, Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal cells that are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma. They are derived from B cells, which are a type of lymphocyte involved in the immune response. Reed-Sternberg cells have distinctive morphological features, including multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli.

 

Owls eye appearance

 

 

  • Owl's eye appearance of inclusion bodies - highly specific for cytomegalovirus infection.
  • Owl's eye appearance of the entire nucleus – a finding in Reed–Sternberg cells in individuals with Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Owl's eye appearance of the Lentiform nucleus of the basal ganglia on head CT scan images in individuals with cerebral hypoxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monocytes, Infectious mononucleosis (EBV): Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is associated with atypical lymphocytes, not Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Option C. Neutrophils, Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection: HSV infection is characterized by intranuclear inclusions in epithelial cells, not neutrophils, and does not produce Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Option D. T cells, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection: CMV infection typically affects endothelial cells and other tissues, showing owl's eye inclusions, but not involving T cells directly.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the image below? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Elephantiasis

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis).

 

Causative Agent/ Etiology: Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi.

 

 

 

  • The delayed complication of ongoing lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema is elephantiasis. Repeated lymph leakage into tissues causes lymphedema first, then elephantiasis.
  • The obstruction of lymphatic vessels and nodes is the cause of the typical manifestations of filariasis.
  • Lymphadenopathy, lymphangitis, lymphangiovarix, lymphorrhagia or chylorrhagia, hydrocele, lymphoedema & elephantiasis & chyluria, and lymphorrhagia or chylorrhagia are the key symptoms. Sometimes the swelling involves the whole leg, the whole arm, the scrotum, the vulva or the breast.
  • In bancroftian filariasis, the lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most frequently affected, resulting in episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis.
  • Extremity Adenolymphangitis is less frequent.
  • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria during the day.

 

Blood tests, usually done at night when the microfilariae are circulating.

 

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis

 

  • Causative Agent: Bacterium called Treponema pallidum.
  • Transmission: Primarily sexually transmitted, but can also be passed from mother to child during pregnancy (congenital syphilis).
  • Clinical Stages: Primary (chancre at site of infection), secondary (rashes, systemic symptoms), latent (no symptoms), and tertiary (gummas, cardiovascular, and neurological complications).
  • Diagnosis: Blood tests, examination of samples from sores.
  • Treatment: Antibiotics, primarily penicillin.

 

Option B. Leprosy (Hansen's disease)

 

  • Causative Agent: Bacterium called Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Transmission: Prolonged close contact with an untreated person. Not highly contagious.
  • Symptoms: Skin lesions, nerve damage leading to numbness, and muscle weakness.
  • Diagnosis: Skin biopsy, nerve biopsy.
  • Treatment: Multidrug therapy (MDT) using antibiotics for 6 months to 2 years.

 

Option D. Leishmaniasis

 

  • Causative Agent: Protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania.
  • Transmission: Sandfly bites.
  • Types and Symptoms:
    • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis: Skin sores.
    • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar): Weight loss, spleen and liver enlargement, anemia, and more.
    • Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis: Ulcers of the skin, mouth, and nose.
  • Diagnosis: Microscopic examination of samples from sores or internal organs, blood tests.
  • Treatment: Antiparasitic drugs like pentavalent antimonials, liposomal amphotericin B, and others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elephantiasis (lymphatic filariasis) is identified by the characteristic severe limb swelling and skin thickening.

 

References:

Harrisons Principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1630

Paniker’s Textbook of medical Parasitology 8th Edition Page no 215

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with difficulty in breathing and rashes after ingestion sea food. He has shown similar reaction in the past following consumption of the same food items. Which of the following hypersensitivity reaction do you relate with this? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1

 

Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, also known as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction, is commonly associated with food allergies. In this type of reaction, allergen-specific IgE antibodies bind to mast cells via their Fc receptors. Upon subsequent exposure to the specific allergen, cross-linking of IgE antibodies occurs, leading to the degranulation of mast cells and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. This results in symptoms such as difficulty breathing, rashes, and anaphylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 2: Type 2 hypersensitivity reactions involve IgG or IgM antibodies binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to complement activation and cell lysis. Examples include red blood cell destruction after transfusion with mismatched blood types and hemolytic disease of the newborn. This type does not typically present with symptoms related to food allergies.

 

Option C. Type 3: Type 3 hypersensitivity reactions are caused by immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that are deposited in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation. Examples include post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and systemic lupus erythematosus. These reactions are not typically associated with immediate allergic responses to food.

 

Option D. Type 4: Type 4 hypersensitivity reactions are delayed-type hypersensitivity mediated by T cells. Examples include contact dermatitis, type I diabetes mellitus, and multiple sclerosis. These reactions develop over a longer period and are not associated with the immediate allergic symptoms seen in food allergies.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is high-level disinfectant? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutaraldehyde

 

The case shows glutaraldehyde

 

  • 2% glutaraldehyde: used for bronchoscopes, endoscopes, colonoscopies, proctoscope
  • Available in inactive form & activated by alkalinization before use
  • Once activated, glutaraldehyde remains active for only 14 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol:

 

  • Ethyl Alcohol: Used in 60-70% concentration for disinfection.
  • Isopropyl Alcohol: Commonly used in hand rubs and sanitizers. It is also used for disinfecting stethoscopes and is a better fat solvent compared to ethyl alcohol. However, alcohols are intermediate-level disinfectants and not considered high-level disinfectants.
  • Isopropyl alcohol is better than ethyl alcohol, as it is a better fat solvent.

 

Option C. Lysol: Contains phenolic compounds and is used as a disinfectant, but it is not classified as a high-level disinfectant.

 

Option D. Phenol: Phenolic compounds are used for disinfection, but like Lysol, they are not considered high-level disinfectants. They are more commonly used for environmental and surface disinfection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutaraldehyde is a high-level disinfectant commonly used for disinfecting medical instruments. It is effective against a broad spectrum of microorganisms and is activated by alkalinization before use.

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na+ K+ ATPase results in? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Depolarisation

 

Explanation

 

Inhibition of Na+K+ATPase results in depolarisation.

 

Depolarisation occurs when the Na+ K+ ATPase, a vital pump responsible for maintaining the cell's electrochemical gradient, is inhibited. This pump actively transports Na+ out of the cell and K+ into the cell, thereby maintaining lower intracellular Na+ levels and higher K+ levels.

 

When this pump's function is inhibited:

 

  • Intracellular accumulation of Na+ occurs because it is not being pumped out.
  • The reduction in the gradient negatively affects the function of other ion exchangers, particularly the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, leading to reduced Ca2+ extrusion from the cell.
  • The resultant increase in intracellular Ca2+ contributes to a less negative resting membrane potential, thus causing depolarization.
  • Continued dysfunction of this pump can also lead to cellular swelling and eventual cell injury due to water following the retained Na+ into the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarisation and then Depolarisation: Incorrect as the primary immediate effect of Na+ K+ ATPase inhibition is depolarisation, not hyperpolarisation.

 

Option C. Hyperpolarisation: Incorrect because the inhibition leads to depolarisation, as explained above.

 

Option D. Repolarisation: Incorrect as repolarisation in cardiac muscle cells is primarily managed by the outflow of K+ from the cell, which is distinct from the effects seen with Na+ K+ ATPase inhibition.

 

Educational objective:

 

Inhibition of the Na+ K+ ATPase in cardiac muscle leads to depolarisation due to the disruption of Na+ and Ca2+ homeostasis within the cell. This highlights the importance of this pump in maintaining cardiac cell stability and function.

questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice inspiratory stridor in the child and laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Laryngomalacia

 

The picture shows an epiglottis exhibiting an Omega shape, which, when combined with the patient's medical history, indicates a likelihood of laryngomalacia.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord paralysis can be due to birth trauma or congenital anomaly of great vessel or heart. The patient of bilateral paralysis presents with biphasic stridor and features of bilateral abductor paralysis and respiratory obstruction necessitating tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Subglottic stenosis is due to abnormal thickening of cricoid cartilage or fibrous tissue seen below the vocal cords. Patient presents with biphasic stridor.

 

Option C. Laryngeal papilloma is a benign condition caused by human papilloma virus subtype 6 and 11. Patient presents with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor can be heard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is a benign, self-limiting condition seen in infants, characterized by a floppy epiglottis and other supraglottic structures that collapse inward during inspiration, causing stridor. Most cases resolve spontaneously by the age of 2 years, though severe cases may require surgical intervention such as supraglottoplasty to alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A newborn at birth was noticed to have a herniated liver and small intestine via the umbilicus. The herniated mass was covered with membranes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

 

An omphalocele or exomphalos is a condition when the intestinal loops are unable to return to the abdominal cavity and is covered by a membrane.

 

A broad umbilical defect through which the abdominal viscera protrudes is known as an omphalocele.

 

The intestinal loops in the physiological umbilical hernia fail to return to the abdominal cavity between weeks six and ten, which results in the deformity. The amnion covers the bowel loops.

 

Omphalocele results in elevated levels of a-fetoprotein.

 

It can be seen in other anomalies such as trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: In gastroschisis, the abdominal organs also protrude through the abdominal wall, but unlike omphalocele, there is no protective membrane covering the exposed organs. The organs are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which can lead to inflammation and damage. Gastroschisis typically occurs next to the umbilicus and is not associated with genetic anomalies.

 

Option C. Persistent Vitello-intestinal Duct: This condition refers to the persistence of the vitelline duct, which connects the yolk sac to the midgut. It may present with a patent duct, leading to the discharge of intestinal contents through the umbilicus, but it does not involve herniation of abdominal organs covered by membranes.

 

Option D. Bochdalek Hernia: This is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, usually involving the herniation of abdominal organs into the chest cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. It leads to respiratory distress due to the compression of the lungs, but it does not involve a membrane-covered mass at the umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:


Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal organs through the umbilical ring, covered by a membrane composed of amnion and peritoneum.

questions.text: A post operative cardiac surgical patient developed sudden hypotension, raised CVP, pulsus paradoxus at the 4th operative hour. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

 

The clinical vignette describes a post-operative cardiac surgical patient who developed sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure (CVP), and pulsus paradoxus (a drop in blood pressure during inspiration). These signs are highly suggestive of cardiac tamponade, a condition where fluid accumulation in the pericardium compresses the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension.

 

Key Points for Cardiac Tamponade:

 

  • Hypotension: Due to decreased cardiac output.
  • Raised CVP: Due to impaired venous return to the heart.
  • Pulsus Paradoxus: An exaggerated decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.
  • Post-Operative Risk: Cardiac tamponade is a recognized complication after cardiac surgery due to potential bleeding into the pericardial space.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): CHF typically presents with symptoms like severe breathlessness, peripheral edema, and fine crackles on lung auscultation. Sudden hypotension is not a common feature of CHF.

 

Option C. Ventricular Dysfunction: Ventricular dysfunction can cause heart failure symptoms, but the presentation would include signs like fine crackles and would not typically cause sudden hypotension with raised CVP and pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option D. Mediastinal Effusion: While a mediastinal effusion can cause some similar symptoms, it is less likely to present with the acute and severe signs of cardiac tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus and sudden hypotension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade should be suspected in a post-operative cardiac surgical patient who develops sudden hypotension, raised CVP, and pulsus paradoxus, as these are hallmark signs of this potentially life-threatening condition. Immediate evaluation and management are critical.

questions.text: A patient presents with miosis, anhidrosis and ptosis as shown in the given image. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horner’s syndrome

 

Horner’s Syndrome

  • It is caused by a lesion of the sympathetic pathway either
    1. In its central portion, which extends from the posterior hypothalamus through the brainstem to the upper spinal cord (C8–T2); or
    2. In its preganglionic portion, which exits the spinal cord and synapses in the superior cervical (stellate) ganglion; or
    3. In its postganglionic portion, from the superior cervical ganglion via the carotid plexus and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, by which it enters the orbit.
  • The sympathetic fibers then follow the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic division of the V nerve and the long ciliary nerves to the iris and innervate Müller muscle and the iris dilator.
  • Clinical features:
    1. Miosis: due to iris dilator muscle paresis, which is more evident in dim light.
    2. Less pigmented iris: seen in congenital or longstanding acquired Horner’s syndrome because melanocyte maturation in the iris depends on sympathetic innervation.
    3. Ptosis: due to paresis of Müller muscle.
    4. Anhidrosis: on the ipsilateral face and neck in central and preganglionic lesions, whereas it is normal in postganglionic lesions because the relevant nerve fibers follow the external rather than the internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. III cranial nerve palsy: This condition typically presents with ptosis and mydriasis (dilated pupil), not miosis. It can also lead to eye movement abnormalities due to paralysis of extraocular muscles.

 

Option C. VI cranial nerve palsy: Causes paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to inability to abduct the eye (move it outward), but does not cause ptosis, miosis, or anhidrosis.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Characterized by swelling, redness, and pain around the eye, often with fever and potential vision loss. It does not cause miosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner’s syndrome is characterized by the triad of miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis, resulting from a disruption of the sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the Xray abdomen: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

 

  • The X-ray shows ‘Double bubble sign’ seen in duodenal atresia.
  • Duodenal atresia is a congenital intestinal obstruction that can cause bilious or non-bilious vomiting within the first 24 to 48 hours of neonatal life, typically following the first oral feeding.
  • Triple bubble sign is seen in jejunal atresia
  • Multiple air fluid levels are seen in ileal atresia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: CHPS shows single bubble sign on X-ray abdomen. History of a baby having projectile non-bilious vomiting with dehydration will be given. Maternal history of antenatal intake of erythromycin could be given.

 

 

Option C. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia shows bowel loops in the thorax with the ipsilateral lung collapse and contralateral mediastinal shift. Coiling of Ryle’s tube will be seen in the thorax instead of abdomen.

 

 

Option D. Transient Tachypnea of Newborn: Transient Tachypnea of Newborn is characterized by bulging of the lobar fissure on chest x-ray with clinical history of a term baby born via Caesarean section having respiratory distress.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Double bubble sign" on X-ray is characteristic of duodenal atresia, which presents with bilious or non-bilious vomiting within the first 24 to 48 hours of life.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with redness, pain, and light sensitivity in right eye. After examination, a diagnosis of anterior uveitis is made. Which of the following HLAs can be associated with his condition? (FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

Anterior uveitis is commonly associated with patients with HLA B27 positivity.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Earliest manifestation: Sacroilitis with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.

 

Clinical Presentation

 

  • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 20-40 years.
  • Most common symptom: Dull backache- insidious onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
  • Most common extra-articular manifestation: Anterior uveitis.

 

Investigations

 

Spine radiograph:

 

  • Earliest change: Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins.
  • Later on: SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Dagger sign: Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments.
  • Calcification of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B5: Associated with Behcet’s disease, which can also cause uveitis, but is not the most common association with anterior uveitis.

 

Option C. HLA B7: Associated with ragweed hay fever and certain other conditions like multiple sclerosis and psoriasis, but not primarily linked to anterior uveitis.

 

Option D. HLA DR4: Associated with extra-articular rheumatoid arthritis but not predominantly linked with anterior uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of discomfort while swallowing food. She has no history of fever, sore throat, or smoking but has a history of Marfan's syndrome in her father. On examination of the oral cavity, there is unilateral swelling of the tonsils along with pulsation. What is the most likely cause of the swelling? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extracranial internal carotid artery aneurysm

 

Marfan's syndrome, an autosomal dominant disease, has a significant historical relevance in relation to the pulsation of the tonsils, which raises suspicion of an extracranial internal carotid artery aneurysm.

 

The internal carotid artery (ICA) is situated approximately 2.5 cm away from the tonsils and lacks any branches in its cervical section. When an internal carotid artery aneurysm occurs, it can exert pressure on the tonsil, leading to the pulsating sensation. However, the external carotid artery would not cause medial displacement of the tonsils due to its more superficial course.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intracranial external carotid artery aneurysm and D. Intracranial internal carotid artery aneurysm: These conditions, while serious, would not typically manifest as pulsations in the tonsil due to their locations within the cranium.

 

Option C. Extracranial external carotid artery aneurysm: This type of aneurysm would more likely affect structures on the face or scalp, given the branching and superficial course of the external carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of an extracranial internal carotid artery aneurysm in a patient with a background of Marfan's syndrome and presenting with pulsatile tonsil swelling is consistent with the pathophysiological expectations of the condition. Proper imaging studies such as a Doppler ultrasound, CT angiography, or MRI would be crucial for confirming the diagnosis and planning appropriate management.

questions.text: Identify this movement that takes place in the intestine? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Peristalsis

 

Peristalsis is the propulsive movement in Gl tract, starting in esophagus and ends in rectum. It follows the law of gut- forward directed towards the rectum, because of intact myenteric plexus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Segmented movement: Incorrect because segmented movements are characterized by alternating contractions and relaxations that mix intestinal contents, not solely propel them.

 

Option C. Intersegmental contraction: Incorrect as it does not correspond to a recognized type of intestinal movement in standard physiological texts.

 

Option D. Diffusion: Incorrect because diffusion is a passive movement of particles across a concentration gradient, not a muscular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peristalsis is the propulsive muscular movement in the gastrointestinal tract that moves food from the esophagus to the rectum. It is governed by neurotransmitters like Substance P and Acetylcholine causing contraction, and Nitric Oxide and Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide causing relaxation.

 

Proximal Contraction done by -

 

  • Substance P
  • ACh

 

Distal Relaxation done by -

 

  • NO
  • VIP

questions.text: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx

 

Explanation:

 

The hysterosalpingogram (HSG) image shows features indicative of bilateral hydrosalpinx. Hydrosalpinx refers to a condition where the fallopian tubes are filled with a clear fluid, resulting from a blockage at the fimbrial end of the tubes, typically due to acute salpingitis or other inflammatory processes. The image displays the characteristic retort shape of the dilated ampulla, with the interstitial end of the tube remaining open and the fimbrial end being closed.

 

In the context of infertility, the treatment often involves salpingectomy (surgical removal of the fallopian tube) or clipping of the tubes near the cornua, followed by in vitro fertilization (IVF).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extravasation into the venous system: This would show contrast leaking into the surrounding venous structures, which is not evident in the given image.

 

Option C. Normal HSG: A normal HSG would show a well-defined uterine cavity with contrast filling and spilling out from the fallopian tubes into the peritoneal cavity, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Bilateral cornual block: A cornual block would show an obstruction at the cornua (the junction of the fallopian tubes and the uterus), preventing contrast from passing through the tubes, which is not the case in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hydrosalpinx appears as a retort-shaped dilation of the fallopian tubes on a hysterosalpingogram, typically resulting from inflammatory processes such as salpingitis.

 

Ref: Page no 658, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Based on the given peripheral smear, which of the following is most likely diagnosis: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myelofibrosis

 

Myelofibrosis: The proliferation of mature myeloid cells especially megakaryocytes. Also associated with JAK2 Kinase mutation. Remember that megakaryocytes produce excessive PDGF which cause bone marrow Fibrosis. Clinically present as an enlarged spleen, with increased risk of thrombosis, infection and bleeding. Tear drop RBCs are characteristically seen.

 

  • Myelodysplastic syndrome → an acquired disorder that affects stem cells, characteristically shows cytopenia and hyper cellular bone marrow.

 

Mostly it’s a disease of a adults, may therapy related like 8-10years exposure may cause AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IDA (Iron Deficiency Anemia): IDA typically presents with microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is not characterized by tear-drop RBCs. Instead, IDA shows RBCs that are smaller than normal and have increased central pallor.

 

Option B. Thalassemia major: Thalassemia major is a genetic disorder that results in the production of abnormal hemoglobin. The peripheral smear usually shows microcytic hypochromic anemia, target cells, and nucleated RBCs, but not the tear-drop RBCs seen in myelofibrosis.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome: This is an acquired disorder that affects hematopoietic stem cells, leading to cytopenias and a hypercellular bone marrow. It is primarily a disease of adults and can be therapy-related, with prolonged exposure (8-10 years) potentially leading to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). While myelodysplastic syndrome may show dysplastic changes in blood cells, tear-drop RBCs are not a characteristic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myelofibrosis is characterized by the presence of tear-drop shaped RBCs (dacrocytes) in the peripheral smear, resulting from bone marrow fibrosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a swelling on the lateral side of her eye. There are no vision disturbances or pain at site. What should be the definitive treatment for her condition? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Excision

 

The clinical scenario along with the image shown is suggestive of a Dermoid Cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cystic lesion that commonly occurs near the lateral aspect of the eye. It is typically asymptomatic but can cause cosmetic concerns or, in rare cases, functional issues if it enlarges. The definitive treatment for a dermoid cyst is surgical excision.

 

  • Description: Excision refers to the surgical removal of the cyst.
  • Relevance: Excision is the definitive treatment for dermoid cysts. Surgical removal ensures the entire cyst is removed, preventing recurrence and resolving any cosmetic concerns.

 

Characteristics of Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • Location: Commonly found near the lateral aspect of the eye.
  • Symptoms: Generally asymptomatic; no vision disturbances or pain.
  • Treatment: Excision ensures complete removal and prevents recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid injection:

 

  • Description: Steroid injections are used to reduce inflammation in various conditions such as arthritis or tendinitis.
  • Relevance: Steroid injections are not a definitive treatment for dermoid cysts as they do not address the cyst itself.

 

Option C. Biopsy:

 

  • Description: A biopsy involves taking a small tissue sample for microscopic examination.
  • Relevance: While a biopsy can confirm the diagnosis of a dermoid cyst, it is not a definitive treatment. Complete excision is preferred for both diagnostic and therapeutic reasons.

 

Option D. Conservative management:

 

  • Description: Conservative management involves monitoring the condition without specific treatment.
  • Relevance: Dermoid cysts do not resolve on their own. Observation might be considered for small, asymptomatic cysts, but definitive treatment is surgical excision, especially if symptoms or cosmetic concerns are present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The definitive treatment for a dermoid cyst, especially one causing symptoms or cosmetic concerns, is surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects will be seen in a patient with anterior pituitary tumor causing pressure over optic chiasma?(FMGE Dec 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

An anterior pituitary tumor can exert pressure on the optic chiasm. The optic chiasm is the part of the brain where the optic nerves partially cross. Specifically, the nasal (inner) fibers of each retina, which are responsible for the temporal (outer) fields of vision, cross to the opposite side at the chiasm. When there is a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as pressure from an anterior pituitary tumor, it affects these crossing fibers, leading to a loss of the temporal visual fields of both eyes. This condition is known as bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Homonymous hemianopia: This type of visual field defect occurs when there is a lesion posterior to the optic chiasm, such as in the optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, optic radiations, or visual cortex. It results in the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes (e.g., the left field in both eyes). An anterior pituitary tumor pressing on the optic chiasm would not cause this defect.

 

Option C. Heteronymous hemianopia with central sparing: This term is less commonly used and can be confusing. Typically, heteronymous hemianopia refers to visual field loss on opposite sides in each eye (e.g., bitemporal or binasal hemianopia). Central sparing usually describes conditions affecting the visual cortex, where central vision is preserved. Anterior pituitary tumors typically do not produce this pattern of field loss.

 

Option D. Monocular vision loss: This occurs when there is a lesion in the optic nerve or retina of one eye, leading to complete loss of vision in that eye. Since an anterior pituitary tumor affects the optic chiasm, it would not cause monocular vision loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The visual pathway and various lesions along the pathway are summarized in the following diagram

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with post-coital bleeding. On per vaginal examination, the following lesion is seen which bleeds on touching. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical Polyp

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image with the history of post-coital bleeding in a woman of childbearing age is suggestive of a cervical polyp.
  • An endocervical polyp arises from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal.
  • ﻿﻿The polyp is pedunculated; the pedicle being attached to the mucous membrane of the cervical canal.
  • ﻿﻿Occur in women during the childbearing period of life but may occasionally develop in menopausal and postmenopausal women.
  • Treatment- avulsion or by torsion and specimen should always be sent for microscopic examination as malignant changes may be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic cyst: This is an ovarian cyst and will not be visible on the cervix

 

Option C. Cervical cancer: Will appear as an irregular fungating/ ulcerative lesion on the cervix

 

Option D. Cervical fibroid: This appears as part of the cervix; and not protruding from the os. It is best diagnosed on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical polyps, which may cause post-coital bleeding, are typically pedunculated lesions arising from the cervical canal mucous membrane and should be microscopically examined for any malignant changes upon removal.

 

Ref: Page no 287, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A black ribbon collected from a crime scene was found to have yellow-colored, needle-shaped crystals on histo examination as shown below. These crystals are indicative of which type of body secretion? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Semen

 

The image shows yellow needle shaped crystals, which are seen in Barberio test.

 

Barberio’s test (MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN)

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate as shown below.

 

Microchemical test for semen and blood

 

In any microchemical test, the extract of stain is taken on the microscope slide and a reagent is added. The peculiar type of crystals get formed depending on the type of reagent and stain which helps to identify the stain. The Microchemical tests for Semen are Florence and Barberio test, and both are presumptive tests. The Microchemical tests for blood are Teichmann’s and Takayama test, and both are confirmatory tests.

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR SEMEN

 

1) Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals) as shown below

 

 

MICROCHEMICAL TESTS FOR BLOOD STAINS

 

1) Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride as shown below

 

 

2) Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin), as shown below

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with the described crystal structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals indicates the Barberio test for semen, identifying the component spermine picrate from the prostate gland.

choices.text: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
Perthes disease
Developmental Dysplasia of hip

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray pelvis is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

 

  • X-ray pelvis shows the displacement of the growth plate and epiphyses on the left side s/o Trethowan’s sign.
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition that affects the hip joint, typically occurring in obese adolescents.
  • MC C/F: Painful limp
  • X-ray finding: Trethowan's sign: Klein line does not intersect the epiphysis.

 

Klein line: line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perthe’s disease: Involved area looks smaller than on the scan. The right ossific nucleus is flattened, irregular and smaller than that on the normal left side. It shows collapse. The growth plate and metaphysis are irregular.

 

 

Option C. Developmental Dysplasia of hip: In DDH, the hip does not form well. The head of femur (ball part) of the joint may be completely, or partly, out of the socket. Sometimes the femur head may slide in and out of the socket. Often, the socket is shallow.

 

 

Option D. Ankylosing spondylitis: Primarily affects the spine and the sacroiliac joints, and would not typically show these findings in the hip region at this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis should be suspected in adolescents presenting with hip pain and limited range of motion, particularly if the X-ray shows a displacement of the growth plate relative to the femoral head, as evidenced by the absence of overlap with the Klein line. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent further slippage and associated complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nurse got needle prick injury from a HIV positive patient while doing blood sampling. Which test would be the confirmatory test to rule out the infection? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. p24 assay

p24 assay: The p24 test identifies actual HIV virus particles in blood. p24 is a capsid structural protein which makes up a protein ‘shell’ on the surface of the HIV virus.  It is one of the earliest antigenic markers to come positive in an HIV patient so diagnosing p24 in a needle stick patient is confirmatory test to rule out early infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBC (Complete Blood Count): This test is not specific for HIV infection and would not provide confirmatory evidence of HIV.

 

Option C. Western blot: This is a confirmatory test for HIV infection but is typically used after an initial screening test (such as an ELISA) has been positive. It detects the antibodies to specific proteins of the virus and It is not used as the first test following exposure.

 

Option D. Blood culture: This test is used to detect bacterial infections in the blood and is not applicable for diagnosing HIV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p24 test identifies actual HIV virus particles in blood. p24 is a capsid structural protein which makes up a protein ‘shell’ on the surface of the HIV virus. It is one of the earliest antigenic markers to come positive in an HIV patient so diagnosing p24 in a needle stick patient is confirmatory test to rule out early infection

questions.text: A patient presents with a protuberance shown in the picture below which reduces when he lies down. What is the likely cause of the protuberance? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Para-umbilical Hernia

 

A para-umbilical hernia is a protrusion of a viscous or part of it through the linea alba, abutting superiorly or inferiorly on the umbilicus. The most common presentation is swelling adjacent to the umbilicus with the involvement of one of the walls of the umbilicus. This type of hernia typically reduces when the patient lies down.

 

Characteristics of Para-umbilical Hernia:

 

  • Location: Near the umbilicus.
  • Appearance: Swelling adjacent to the umbilicus.
  • Behavior: Reduces when lying down.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This cyst is intra-abdominal and is typically found on imaging. It does not present as a visible external protuberance that reduces when lying down.

 

Option C. Caput medusae: Caput medusae is seen in portal hypertension. The superficial veins become tortuous and dilated over the abdominal wall due to increased resistance to the flow leading to elevated pressure. It does not reduce when lying down and is characterized by the appearance of tortuous veins radiating from the umbilicus.

 

 

Option D. Omphalitis: Omphalitis presents with umbilical discharge and inflammation. It is an infection of the umbilical stump, typically in neonates, and does not cause a reducible protuberance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A para-umbilical hernia presents as a reducible swelling adjacent to the umbilicus, typically protruding through the linea alba and reducing when the patient lies down.

questions.text: For day care surgeries, which of the following intravenous anesthetic agent is preferred? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

Propofol:

 

  • Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic agent that induces rapid and short-lasting anesthesia.
  • Usage in Day Care: Propofol is preferred for day care surgeries because:
    1. Short Duration: It has a quick onset and short duration, allowing patients to wake up faster post-surgery.
    2. Metabolism and Excretion: It's easily metabolized and excreted from the body, minimizing the risk of prolonged sedation or hangover.
    3. Additional Benefits: Propofol has antiemetic (reduces nausea and vomiting) and antipruritic (reduces itching) properties, making postoperative recovery more comfortable for patients.
    4. Few Side Effects: The drug is well-tolerated with minimal side effects, making it safe for short-term procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is not ideal for day care surgeries due to its longer duration and slower recovery. It also has a risk of prolonged postoperative drowsiness and hangover, which is not suitable for patients expected to be discharged the same day.

 

Option C. Opioid: While opioids are powerful pain relievers, they are not primarily used as induction agents for anesthesia. Additionally, they can have side effects like respiratory depression, which would require close monitoring. This makes them less ideal as the primary agent for day care surgeries.

 

Option D. Etomidate: While etomidate can be used for induction, it has a notable side effect of inhibiting adrenal steroid synthesis. This can lead to issues in patients with sepsis or adrenal insufficiency. Though it has a rapid onset and short duration, the adrenal side effects make it less favorable compared to propofol for day care surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is preferred for day care surgeries due to its rapid onset, short duration, and minimal side effects. It also provides antiemetic and antipruritic benefits, ensuring a comfortable postoperative recovery for patients.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs. 646-648

questions.text: Which is not a microelement? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcium

 

It is considered a macronutrient rather than a microelement. It is needed by the body in larger quantities compared to microelements, and it plays a crucial role in processes such as bone formation, blood clotting, and muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: It has important roles in various biological processes, including antioxidant defense mechanisms.

 

Option B. Copper: It is involved in several physiological processes, including the formation of red blood cells and the functioning of enzymes.

 

Option D. Zinc: It plays a role in various biological functions, including immune function, wound healing, and DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microelements, also known as trace elements or micronutrients, are essential elements required by living organisms in relatively small amounts for various physiological functions.

 

Classification of minerals based on body requirements:

questions.text: Sonographic evaluation of a 26-year-old woman, who presented with complaints of amenorrhea for 12 weeks revealed the twin gestation as shown in the image below. The type of gestation seen here is which of the following? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA)

 

  • The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
  • The inverted T sign is seen in Monochorionic Diamniotic pregnancy
  • Chorionicity in multiple pregnancy

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA): The inverted T or reversed T sign is seen in MCDA pregnancies, not the lambda sign.

 

Option C. Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA): No intertwin membrane is observed in MCMA pregnancies.

 

Option D. Conjoined twins: Conjoined twins do not have an intertwin membrane, and the fetuses are joined together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lambda sign or twin peak sign is indicative of a dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page 870, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: In the past one year, a patient had more than 4 episodes of psychiatric illness, consisting of mania, hypomania, and depression, with complete recovery in between the episodes. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rapid cycling bipolar disorder

 

The patient's presentation of having multiple episodes of mania, hypomania, and depression within a one-year timeframe, with full recovery between episodes, fits the description of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Major depression: It involves episodes of depression without mania or hypomania.

 

Option B. Dysthymia: A chronic form of subsyndromal depression lasting for at least two years without meeting the criteria for depression, mania or hypomania.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: It is a milder form of bipolar disorder where the highs and lows are not as severe as full-blown mania or major depression and lasts for at least two years.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid cycling bipolar disorder is defined as the occurrence of four or more mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) in a 12-month period. Drug of choice for rapid cycling is valproate.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 368-369.

questions.text: A male patient presented with bloody diarrhea. On Investigation of stool sample, the organism was found to be gram negative, non-motile and oxidase negative. What could be the cause? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shigella

 

Shigella:

 

  • Non-motile, catalase +ve, gram negative bacteria
  • Except shigella dysentriae type 1: catalase –ve
  • Most common cause of bacillary dysentriae in India – S. Flexneri
  • Most common cause of bacillary dysentriae in World – S. Sonnie
  • Transport media same as – sach’s buffered glycerol saline
  • Clinical manifestations: -
    • Incubation period- 1-4days
    • Initial phase: watery diarrhea
    • Dysentery phase: mucopurulent stools
    • Phase of complications: toxic mega colon, perforation, HUS, DIC, SIADH, Seizures & Encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: While some strains of E. coli can cause bloody diarrhea (e.g., E. coli O157), E. coli is typically motile and oxidase negative.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Salmonella is a gram-negative, motile, and oxidase-negative bacterium, typically associated with gastroenteritis and enteric fever rather than dysentery.

 

Option D. Yersinia pestis: Yersinia pestis is a gram-negative, non-motile bacterium, but it is primarily associated with plague, not gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shigella is a gram-negative, non-motile, and oxidase-negative bacterium that is a common cause of bacillary dysentery, presenting with bloody diarrhea and several potential severe complications.

questions.text: Identify the obstetric grip performed in the picture? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic grip

 

Explanation:

 

The obstetric grip shown in the picture is Pelvic grip.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Pawlick grip: The Pawlick grip is the third Leopold maneuver and is used to determine the presenting part of the fetus and its location relative to the true pelvis.

 

Option C. Fundal grip: The fundal grip is the first Leopold maneuver and is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.

 

Option D. Umbilical grip: The umbilical grip is the second Leopold maneuver and is used to locate the fetal back and extremities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic grip, part of the Leopold maneuvers, assesses the descent of the presenting fetal part into the maternal pelvis.

 

Ref: Page 424, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with arthralgia, difficulty in swallowing the food and gritty feeling in the eyes. He is also found to be having increased titers of ANA. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sjogren syndrome

 

SJOGREN SYNDROME - A chronic inflammatory & lymphoproliferative disease with autoimmune features, characterized by:

 

A progressive mononuclear cell infiltration of exocrine glands (notably the lacrimal & salivary glands).

 

Lead to dryness of the eyes and the mouth.

 

Sjogren Syndrome is the third most common autoimmune disease (Fox RI. 2005)

 

  • Approximately 90% occur in women.
  • Mainly affects middle-aged women.
  • In a cohort study of 400 patients:

 

The average age of the patients was 52.7 93% of the patients were women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: This is an autoimmune disease primarily affecting joints, leading to synovitis and joint destruction. While it can cause arthralgia and systemic symptoms, it does not typically cause dry eyes and mouth as primary features.

 

Option C. Serum sickness: This is a type III hypersensitivity reaction that can occur after exposure to foreign proteins or antiserum, characterized by fever, rash, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy. It does not typically present with the dryness of eyes and mouth.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and brain. It can cause arthralgia and ANA positivity, but it is less likely to present with prominent dry eyes and mouth as seen in Sjogren syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry eyes, dry mouth, and arthralgia, often with increased ANA titers, resulting from autoimmune infiltration of exocrine glands.

questions.text: A child with IQ of 50 comes under: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mild MR

 

Mild MR is defined as an IQ of 50.

 

The MR is now replaced with Intellectual Disability.

 

IQ scores were used as the basis for the DSM IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders) criteria for mental retardation:

 

  • The formula for calculating IQ is IQ = Mental age – Chronological age 100.
  • Typical IQ range: 90 to 110
  • 70 to 90 percent mental sub normality

 

The most common cause of MR is Down’s Syndrome.

 

Fragile X Syndrome- will also results in the MR.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Moderate MR: Moderate intellectual disability refers to an IQ range of 35-50, which is lower than the child’s IQ in this case.

 

Option C. Severe MR: Severe intellectual disability corresponds to an IQ range of 20-35. Children with this level of disability require substantial support for daily activities.

 

Option D. Profound MR: Profound intellectual disability refers to an IQ score below 20. Individuals with this level of disability need complete care and supervision throughout their life.

 

Educational Objective:


Mild intellectual disability is defined as an IQ range of 50-70, and children with mild intellectual disability can often live independently with some support.

questions.text: A child with mental retardation (MR) was found to have an IQ level of 55. This would be classified as: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mild MR

 

This is the largest group and they often can achieve social and vocational skills adequate for minimal self-support, but may need guidance and assistance during stress.

 

Other Options:

 

The classification of intellectual disabilities (formerly known as mental retardation) based on IQ levels is as follows:

 

Option B. Moderate MR: IQ of 35-50. These individuals can perform self-care and participate in routine social activities, but usually require supervision.

 

Option C. Borderline intelligence: IQ of 70-85. Individuals in this range don't qualify for a diagnosis of intellectual disability but may face learning and adaptive challenges.

 

Option D. Severe MR: IQ of 20-35. Individuals in this category require constant supervision.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mild intellectual disability (formerly mild MR) is characterized by an IQ level between 50 and 70.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry by Niraj Ahuja, 7th edition, Page No 156.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with chronic back pain, fatigue, and easy bruisability. ESR was elevated and the radiograph shown below. What is the next test to help in the evaluation? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum electrophoresis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of multiple myeloma, including chronic back pain, fatigue, easy bruisability, and elevated ESR. The radiograph shows multiple lytic lesions, which are characteristic of multiple myeloma.

 

Serum electrophoresis is the next appropriate test to evaluate for multiple myeloma. This test can detect the presence of a monoclonal protein (M protein) spike, which is indicative of multiple myeloma or other plasma cell dyscrasias.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET-CT: While PET-CT can help assess the extent of disease and identify additional sites of involvement, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. CT brain with contrast: This test is not indicated in this context as it is used for evaluating brain lesions or structural abnormalities, which are not suggested by the current clinical presentation.

 

Option D. MRI brain: Similar to CT brain, an MRI brain is not indicated here as it is used to identify structural brain lesions, not for diagnosing multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with symptoms and radiographic findings suggestive of multiple myeloma, serum electrophoresis is the appropriate next test to identify a monoclonal protein spike and help confirm the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

 

Additional Information

 

MDE (Myeloma defining Events)

 

1. Myeloma related organ impairment (ROTI):  Lytic bone lesions, ↑Ca >11, S. Creat >2, Hb <10

 

2. Any 1 of the 3 biomarkers

 

  1. BM Plasma cell >60%
  2. Serum Free Light Chain ratio >100:1
  3. >1 focal lesion on MRI

 

Treatment: Definitive Rx= Transplant

 

Drugs: Dexamethasone + Lenalidomide + Bortezomib ± Daratumumab (Anti-CD38)

 

Newer Drugs:

 

1.Elotuzumab: Anti-SLAM7

2.Panobinostat (HiDAC - Histone deacetylase inhibitors)

3.CAR-T cell therapy with idecabtagene vicleucel

choices.text: National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW)

questions.text: A political science postgraduate student at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi is preparing for a presentation on the evolution of planning bodies in India. As he delves into recent developments, he recalls that a renowned institution, which played a pivotal role in India's developmental planning for decades, was replaced by a new institution called NITI Aayog. Which of the following institutions was superseded by the formation of NITI Aayog? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. National Planning Commission (NPC)

 

The National Planning Commission, established in 1950, was the central planning authority in India until it was superseded by NITI Aayog on January 1, 2015. This change aimed to enhance inclusiveness and cooperative federalism in the planning process.

 

The Prime Minister is the Chairperson and the headquarter is at New Delhi.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. National Board of Examinations (NBE): Related to the conducting postgraduate medical exams.

 

Option B. National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW): Concentrates on health and family welfare research and training.

 

Option C. Medical Council of India (MCI): Dealt with medical education standards and was replaced by the National Medical Commission (NMC). Bill was passed on 8 Aug 2019. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NITI Aayog was established to replace the National Planning Commission, reflecting a shift towards a more inclusive and cooperative approach in India’s economic strategy formulation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with chronic hypertension presented to the ER with altered mental status and elevated blood pressure of 210/110 mmHg. CT scan of the brain revealed intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Which of the site is most common for hemorrhage? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Putamen
 

The clinical history of a 66-year-old man with chronic hypertension presenting with altered mental status and significantly elevated blood pressure, along with a CT scan showing intraparenchymal hemorrhage, is indicative of hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). The most common site of hypertensive ICH is the putamen.

 

Locations of Intracerebral Hemorrhage: Putamen> Thalamus> Pons > Cerebellum

 

Non-contrast CT is crucial in diagnosing intracerebral hemorrhage, helping to identify the location and extent of the bleed. In hypertensive patients, chronic high blood pressure leads to degenerative changes in the small penetrating arteries, making them prone to rupture, most frequently in the putamen.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: While the thalamus is a common site for hypertensive hemorrhage, it is not as frequent as the putamen.

 

Option C. Pons: Hemorrhage in the pons is less common than in the putamen or thalamus in the context of hypertension.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Although cerebellar hemorrhages can occur, they are less common than putaminal hemorrhages in hypertensive patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic hypertension presenting with intracerebral hemorrhage, the putamen is the most common site of bleeding. Non-contrast CT scans are essential for diagnosing and determining the location of the hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paresthesia of the fingers along with characteristic findings as shown. She has no other illnesses, and she says the episodes occur during stress/cold climates. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary Raynaud’s

 

The image and clinical presentation are indicative of Raynaud's phenomenon, characterized by episodic vasospasm of the arteries and arterioles in the fingers and toes, usually triggered by cold exposure or stress. The patient's lack of comorbidities and systemic symptoms points towards Primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Phases of Raynaud's Phenomenon:

 

  1. Phase I: Whitish coloration due to vasospasm.
  2. Phase II: Cyanosis due to venodilation distal to vasospasm.
  3. Phase III: Reddish discoloration due to relaxation of vasospasm.

 

Management:

 

  • Primary Raynaud's: Reassurance, avoidance of cold exposure, and stress reduction.
  • Advanced cases: Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) may be used.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Scleroderma: Scleroderma can cause secondary Raynaud's phenomenon, but the patient lacks other symptoms of systemic sclerosis such as skin thickening and systemic involvement.

 

Option C. Secondary Raynaud's: Secondary Raynaud's is associated with other systemic diseases, which the patient does not have.

 

Option D. Cold sores: Cold sores are typically caused by the herpes simplex virus and do not present with the described vasospastic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is brought to the ER after sustaining a fall from a height. His X-ray was done which showed a fractured neck of the femur and was operated on for the same. On post-operative Day 2, he experienced a sharp severe burning pain over the right half of his back. On general physical examination, the lesion is seen which is shown below. The affected region is tender to touch with erythematous rash. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed to this patient? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Valacyclovir

 

The dermatomal distribution of grouped erythematous papules and vesicles along with a sharp, burning pain is suggestive of Herpes Zoster caused by reactivation of Varicella Zoster Virus infection.

 

  • Tab. Acyclovir 800 mg can be given 5 times a day for 7 to 10 days or Tab. Valacyclovir 1g can be given three times a day for 7 days if the patient presents within 72 hours of onset of rash.

  • The most common complication is post herpetic neuralgia. Amitriptyline can be used in the treatment of post herpetic neuralgia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amitriptyline: It is a tricyclic antidepressant which inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and nor-epinephrine. It is used in post-herpetic neuralgia, which is a known and common complication of Herpes Zoster.

 

Option B. Topical Steroids: Steroids are not indicated in herpes zoster as it may result in the flare up of the condition and may worsen the patient. It may also increase the risk of secondary bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Mupirocin: It is an antibacterial agent which is used topically in the nasal carriers of the S. aureus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute Herpes Zoster, prompt treatment with Valacyclovir is recommended to manage the viral infection effectively and reduce the risk of complications such as postherpetic neuralgia. Early intervention with an appropriate antiviral is key to improving outcomes in patients with shingles.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of UTI. His mother says that he urinates frequently but has a poor urinary stream along with dribbling of urine. On examination, he has a palpable bladder. What investigation can be used to find out the underlying diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Micturating cystourethrography

 

The preferred investigation is MCU since the clinical situation points to the sole male condition known as posterior urethral valve.

 

Posterior Urethral Valve

 

  • PUV occurs in male child
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound,
  • On USG it demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder giving a key hole appearance.
