  • Investigation will involve a voiding cystogram, with the dilatation of the urethra above the valves demonstrable on a voiding cystogram.
  • The bladder is hypertrophied and often shows diverticula.
  • Typically, there is vesicoureteric reflux into dilated upper tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasonogram: Although ultrasonography can reveal hydronephrosis and bladder distension, it does not give as detailed information about the urethra as MCU. USG is helpful but not diagnostic for PUV.

 

Option C. Urine routine examination: A urine routine examination may reveal pyuria (pus cells in urine) or bacteriuria due to UTIs, but it does not help in diagnosing the underlying anatomical defect like PUV.

 

Option D. DMSA scan: A DMSA scan is used for assessing renal scarring and function, especially following recurrent UTIs, but it is not used to diagnose obstructive uropathy like PUV.

 

Educational Objective:


Micturating cystourethrography (MCU) is the investigation of choice for diagnosing posterior urethral valve (PUV) in a male child with recurrent UTIs and poor urinary stream.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull note on percussion. A chest X-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Klebsiella pneumonia

 

The clinical vignette suggests community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), with findings indicating a possible necrotizing pneumonia. Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common pathogen in chronic alcoholics and can lead to severe necrotizing pneumonia. The presentation of copious sputum production, often described as "currant jelly" sputum, and the tendency to affect the upper lobes, is characteristic of Klebsiella pneumoniae. The chest X-ray findings typically show a bulging fissure sign due to the significant amount of sputum production.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: S. pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and typically causes lobar pneumonia. However, it does not usually produce the necrotizing features and copious sputum associated with Klebsiella pneumoniae.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is more common in patients with structural lung disease (e.g., cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis) and in hospital-acquired pneumonia. It also acts as a colonizer in these patients.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) commonly affects immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS or post-transplant patients. It typically presents with interstitial infiltrates on the chest X-ray and is associated with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common cause of necrotizing pneumonia in chronic alcoholics, characterized by copious "currant jelly" sputum, upper lobe involvement, and significant sputum production leading to a bulging fissure sign on chest X-ray.

 

Ref: Harrison 21E/Pneumonia/Chapter 126/Table 126-1

questions.text: Identify the organism stained with India Ink stain? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus

 

Cryptococcus, specifically Cryptococcus neoformans, is an encapsulated yeast that can cause infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS. The India Ink stain is used in microbiology as a negative staining technique to visualize organisms with a capsule.

 

Characteristics of Cryptococcus:

 

  • Encapsulation: The India Ink stain highlights the thick polysaccharide capsule surrounding the yeast cells, appearing as clear halos around the darkly stained yeast cells.
  • Infection: Cryptococcal infection occurs primarily through inhalation of the yeast spores, which can disseminate to the central nervous system causing cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Specimens: Diagnostic specimens include serum, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and other body fluids.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • India Ink Stain: Used for examining CSF in suspected cases of cryptococcal meningitis, particularly in HIV-positive individuals. The thick capsule of Cryptococcus appears as a clear halo against the dark background.
  • Culture: CSF and blood cultures can be used for isolation of the organism.
  • Other Stains: Cryptococcus can also be identified using other stains like Gram stain (yeast phase) and specific fungal stains.

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line: Liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB) combined with flucytosine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia: Typically diagnosed using immunofluorescence staining or nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT), not India Ink stain.

 

Option B. Histoplasma: Diagnosed using stains like Giemsa or fungal culture, not India Ink.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Visualized using Lactophenol cotton blue or Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation, not India Ink.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The India Ink stain is a negative staining technique used to identify Cryptococcus neoformans by visualizing its characteristic thick capsule, especially in CSF samples of HIV-positive individuals.

 

Staining inks for additional microorganisms:

questions.text: A 79-year-old female suffered with heart disease and with cardiac atrophy. On H/E, perinuclear yellow brown deposits were seen. Which pigment is responsible for this? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lipofuscin

 

Lipofuscin is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates in the cells as a result of aging and wear and tear. It is commonly seen in elderly patients, particularly in those with atrophic or degenerative conditions such as cardiac atrophy. The presence of perinuclear yellow-brown deposits in the heart cells is indicative of lipofuscin accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is a brown pigment that results from the breakdown of hemoglobin and the storage of iron. It is associated with conditions such as hemosiderosis and hemochromatosis. It can be identified using Prussian blue stain, which reacts with iron to form ferric ferricyanide.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron deposits can appear brown or black and are typically associated with iron overload disorders and chronic hemorrhage. Iron itself is not a specific pigment but contributes to the formation of hemosiderin.

 

Option D. Zinc: Zinc is not typically associated with a specific pigment in histological examinations. Zinc deficiency can lead to conditions like acrodermatitis enteropathica, but it does not produce a distinctive pigment in tissue samples.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anesthesia is required for dental surgery? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Dental surgeries can be complex and vary in their requirements for anesthesia. Depending on the location, type, and extent of the procedure, a dentist or oral surgeon might employ one or a combination of the above methods to ensure the patient remains comfortable and pain-free during the procedure. Hence, all the listed techniques are relevant and can be required for different dental procedures.

 

Option A. Field block:

 

  • A field block involves the injection of a local anesthetic in a circumferential manner around the area of interest, but at a distance from the actual surgical site.

  • Usage in dental surgery: It's commonly used in dental procedures to provide anesthesia to a larger area of the mouth without directly injecting into the surgical site. For instance, when extracting a tooth or performing other oral surgeries, a field block can anesthetize the surrounding tissues, ensuring patient comfort.

     

Option B. Nerve block:

 

  • This technique targets specific nerves or nerve bundles, delivering local anesthetic directly to these sites to block the transmission of nerve impulses.
  • Usage in dental surgery: Dental nerve blocks are frequently used to achieve profound anesthesia for procedures involving the teeth, gums, or jaw. Examples include the inferior alveolar nerve block, which anesthetizes the lower jaw, or the maxillary nerve block for the upper jaw.

 

Option C. Infiltration anesthesia :

 

  • Infiltration anesthesia involves the direct injection of local anesthetic into the tissue at the site of the procedure.
  • Usage in dental surgery: This method is often used for minor dental procedures or in conjunction with other techniques. For instance, when filling a cavity, a dentist might use infiltration to numb just the specific tooth and surrounding gums.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Dental surgeries employ a combination of various anesthetic blocks including field block, nerve block and infiltration anesthesia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient underwent a sternal cyst excision. After 1 year he presents with the growth shown in the picture below. Which of the following is likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Keloid

 

The lesion is seen on sternum which is the typical location of a keloid. It appears to have outgrown the wound margins.

 

Keloid and Hypertrophic Scars

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell papilloma: Benign, pedunculated skin tumors.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic scar: Characterized by rapid growth then spontaneous resolution over time, limited to the original wound area.

 

Option C. Marjolin’s ulcer: Occurs in a burns scar, potentially leading to squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. It doesn’t have a neurovascular bundle (painless and benign).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by poorly-organized collagen, typically appear on pigmented skin with a family history, extend beyond the original wound, and do not self-resolve. They often recur even after treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On examination the cervical os is closed and uterine size is normal. Gestational sac is visible on ultrasound. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Threatened abortion

 

  • The given clinical features signify threatened abortion.
  • The patient complains of bleeding through a closed cervical os or a bloody vaginal discharge
  • The gestational sac is seen on ultrasound. Two thirds of these pregnancies continue beyond 28 weeks POG.

 

Types of Spontaneous Abortion (and ruling out other options)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inevitable abortion: Inevitable abortion is marked by heavy bleeding, moderate abdominal pain, and an open cervical os. The ultrasound may show products of conception low in the uterus.

 

Option C. Incomplete abortion: Incomplete abortion involves heavy bleeding, moderate abdominal pain, and an open cervical os. The ultrasound will typically show retained bits of the products of conception.

 

Option D. Complete abortion: Complete abortion is characterized by a history of heavy bleeding, moderate pain, a closed cervical os, and an empty uterus on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Threatened abortion is diagnosed when there is painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester with a closed cervical os, normal uterine size, and a visible gestational sac on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page No: 159 DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

questions.text: Identify the structure marked red in the below image? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lentiform nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the Lentiform nucleus.

 

 

It is composed of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. The lentiform nucleus, together with other basal ganglia structures, is primarily involved in motor control and regulation of movement. It plays a role in refining and modulating motor signals before they are transmitted to the motor cortex. Dysfunction in the lentiform nucleus can lead to movement disorders such as dystonia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is one of the major structures that make up the basal ganglia, which is a collection of nuclei found deep within the brain. It is a C-shaped structure that is part of the telencephalon. It  is involved in various functions, including motor control, cognitive processes, and emotional processing. It plays a role in coordinating voluntary movements, procedural learning, and forming habits. Dysfunction in the caudate nucleus can contribute to movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease.

 

Option B. The insula, also known as the insular cortex or the island of Reil, is a region of the cerebral cortex located deep within the lateral sulcus (a groove) of the brain. It is considered part of the telencephalon. It is involved in a wide range of functions, including emotion, consciousness, perception, and self-awareness. It plays a role in processing emotional and sensory information, as well as regulating autonomic functions like heart rate and blood pressure. The insula is also implicated in social cognition and empathy.

 

Option D. The basal ganglia is a complex network of nuclei located deep within the brain. It includes structures such as the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus. The basal ganglia plays a central role in motor control, cognitive functions, and emotional processing. It helps initiate and regulate voluntary movements, modulate muscle tone, and contribute to procedural learning and habit formation. Dysfunction in the basal ganglia can lead to a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

 

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus and lenticular nuclei (the putamen, globus pallidus externus, and internus), the subthalamic nucleus (STN), and the substantia nigra (SN)
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who is an agricultural worker presented with the lesion shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Collar stud abscess

 

Young male with lesion on the neck is likely suggestive of Collar stud abscess (out of the four options given).

 

Tuberculous lymphadenitis is popularly known as collar stud abscess, due to its proximity to the collar bone and its superficial resemblance to a collar stud.

 

The image shows minimal inflammation which is a classical feature of Tuberculosis (cold abscess).

 

Order of development of TB lymph nodes →

Tubercular lymphadenitis→ matted lymph nodes → formation of cold abscess → rupture through deep fascia comes beneath the skin → gets adherent to skin → Collar stud abscess

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic Hygroma is a congenital translucent neck swelling. It is a lymphatic malformation and doesn’t commonly present with signs of inflammation. They are usually noticeable in neonates.

 

 

Option C. Branchial cyst is typically seen on anterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle (upper part) while branchial fistula in lower part.

 

 

Option D. Thyroglossal cyst is a congenital cystic swelling that occurs due to remnant of thyroglossal duct. It most commonly arises in the subhyoid region and moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculous lymphadenitis, known as collar stud abscess, presents as a minimally inflamed lesion near the collar bone, resembling a collar stud.

questions.text: Where is lactate dehydrogenase primarily located within the cell? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoplasm

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is present in almost every tissue. The high concentration presents in muscle, liver and kidney. LDH also present in some quantity in RBC
  • LDH is an enzyme that is commonly used as a marker for cell damage or injury. When cells are damaged or undergo necrosis, the cytoplasmic contents, including LDH, can be released into the extracellular space. This can lead to an increase in LDH levels in the blood, which can be measured and used as a diagnostic marker for certain conditions.
  • It is involved in the conversion of lactate and pyruvate during anaerobic glycolysis. It plays a crucial role in energy production by catalyzing the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate in the cytoplasm of cells.
  • LDH is found in various tissues and organs throughout the body, and its cytoplasmic location allows for the efficient conversion of lactate and pyruvate, maintaining cellular energy balance under different physiological conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactate dehydrogenase is a cytoplasmic enzyme essential for anaerobic glycolysis, and its presence in the blood can indicate cellular damage or necrosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old animal handler came to the clinic with cough, chest pain for one week, and fatigue for a month. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydatid cyst

 

  • The chest x-ray findings are suggestive of a cystic lesion in the right lung with undulating membranes suggestive of a Waterlily sign.
  • The causative organism of hydatid disease is Echinococcus granulosus.

 

Echinococcus granulosus:

 

  • Definitive hosts: Dogs
  • Intermediate hosts: Sheep
  • Accidental /Dead end hosts: Humans
  • Most common organ - Liver
  • 2nd most common organ - Lungs
  • Echinococcus multilocularis can mimic malignancy (HCC) in the liver on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anthrax: Typically presents with a more acute illness, including severe respiratory distress, and is linked with direct contact with Bacillus anthracis from infected animals or their products, not typically presenting with cystic lung lesions.

 

Option C. Silicosis: A pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica particles, leading to nodular fibrotic changes in the lungs, not cystic lesions.

 

Option D. Byssinosis: Often called "brown lung," it is a lung disease resulting from inhalation of cotton dust, showing more diffuse fibrotic changes rather than distinct cystic formations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of exposure to animals and presenting with symptoms suggestive of a lung lesion, along with characteristic imaging findings of a cystic structure with a "Waterlily sign," hydatid cyst should be considered as a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drug inhibits the marked enzyme in vitamin K cycle? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dicumarol

 

Dicumarol is a member of the coumarin class of anticoagulants, which also includes warfarin. These drugs inhibit the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, a key enzyme in the vitamin K cycle. This inhibition leads to a decrease in the production of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X), thus exerting an anticoagulant effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and other clotting factors. It does not directly interact with the vitamin K cycle.

 

Option B. Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medication that inhibits the ADP receptor on platelet cell membranes, thereby reducing platelet aggregation and blood clot formation. It does not affect the vitamin K cycle.

 

Option D. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent that works by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which then breaks down fibrin clots. It does not act on the vitamin K cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vitamin K cycle is crucial for the synthesis and activation of clotting factors in the blood as shown in figure below:

 

 

Drugs like Dicumarol and warfarin, by inhibiting the enzyme epoxide reductase in this cycle, interferes with the production of clotting factors, thereby acts as an anticoagulant. This makes it useful in preventing and treating conditions involving abnormal blood clotting, such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A footballer got injured on the head while trying to direct the ball toward the goal. He loses consciousness transiently but continues to play the match after receiving first aid. During drinks break, he is found unconscious in the changing room and is rushed to the hospital. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) EDH

 

The given scenario is suggestive of moderate head injury, with presence of “Lucid interval”- suggestive of EDH.

 

Extradural hemorrhage:

 

Extradural hematoma (EDH), also known as an epidural hematoma, is a collection of blood that forms between the inner surface of the skull and outer layer of the dura, which is called the endosteal layer. They are usually associated with a history of head trauma and frequently associated skull fracture.

 

Bleeding occurs from - Middle meningeal artery.

 

Symptoms

 

  • Head injury or trauma followed by loss of consciousness, a period of alertness, then rapid deterioration back to unconsciousness. This is known as lucid interval, which is typical of EDH
  • Drowsiness or altered level of alertness.
  • Enlarged pupil in one eye.
  • Headache (severe)
  • Nausea or vomiting.

 

Treatment - BURR HOLE surgery to relieve pressure.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. SDH (Subdural Hematoma):

 

This bleeding is usually from veins that are torn by the force of a head injury. Symptoms might manifest slowly, over days or even weeks, and can include confusion, drowsiness, headache, and lethargy. Chronic subdural hematomas might present in the elderly following minor or even unrecognized trauma.

 

Option C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage):

 

This is typically due to a ruptured aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Classic symptoms include a sudden and severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap" headache), nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. There may be no history of trauma.

 

Option D. Intracerebral Hemorrhage:

 

  • Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) refers to spontaneous bleeding into the brain tissue itself. Depending on the location of the bleed, symptoms can range from sudden headache, weakness, numbness, decreased level of consciousness, to difficulty speaking or seeing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a "lucid interval" following head trauma is highly indicative of an Extradural Hematoma (EDH).

questions.text: A 40-year-old factory worker with tuberculosis is advised to rest for three months and seeks financial support during this period. Under the Employees’ State Insurance scheme, which benefit allows him to receive about 70% of his daily wages while he recovers? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sickness Benefit

 

The Sickness Benefit under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) scheme is tailored to support insured workers who cannot perform their duties due to medical reasons. This benefit provides approximately 70% of the average daily wages, ensuring financial support for up to 91 days or more if medically justified, crucial for someone like the worker described who is the primary breadwinner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medical Benefit: Offers medical services rather than wage compensation during sickness.

 

Option C. Disablement Benefit: Provides benefits for loss of earning capacity due to a work-related injury or disease, not applicable for general sickness.

 

Option D. Dependent’s Benefit: Allocated for dependents of a deceased insured worker, not suitable for a living employee seeking sickness-related support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Employees State Insurance (ESI)

 

 

It comes under the Ministry of Labour. It is not applicable for Defence, Mining and Railway.

 

People with a monthly wage of less than Rs.21000/month are eligible to get the benefits.

 

The benefits include the following:

 

  • Medical Care
  • Sickness benefit (70% wages for 91 days or 3 months)
    • If extended it becomes (80% of wages for 2 years)
    • Enhanced sickness benefit (100% of the wages for sterilization procedures – 7 days for males and 14 days for females)
  • Disablement benefit is 90% wages depending on temporary or permanent disability
  • Dependent’s benefit is also 90%
  • Under ESI Funeral expense 15,000 is also given

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urinary stream and frequent urination in small amounts and is on prazosin. He also mentions that he frequently feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamsulosin

 

The clinical features are suggestive of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia.

 

  • Prazosin, Terazosin, Doxazosin are non-selective α1 receptor blockers which can be used to treat the dynamic symptoms of obstruction due to BPH. But they also cause vasodilation and lowering of BP.

  • So, we can specifically use α1A Blocker like Tamsulosin and Silodosin which will treat the obstructive symptoms of BPH without causing postural hypotension. Tamsulosin is an alpha 1A/1D receptor agonist which confers it a higher selectivity towards the prostatic musculature. By relaxing the muscles, it relieves the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alfuzosin: While somewhat selective like Tamsulosin, Alfuzosin has a higher likelihood of causing hypotension than Tamsulosin and would not be the best choice for a patient already experiencing low blood pressure.

 

Option B. Terazosin: Similar to Prazosin in its non-selective alpha-blocking action, Terazosin would also be likely to exacerbate the patient’s symptoms of lightheadedness and hypotension.

 

Option D. Doxazosin: As a non-selective alpha-blocker, Doxazosin shares similar issues with Prazosin and Terazosin in lowering blood pressure, which is undesirable in this patient’s case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In treating BPH symptoms in patients who are sensitive to blood pressure changes, Tamsulosin is preferred due to its selectivity for alpha-1A receptors predominantly found in the prostate, thereby minimizing cardiovascular side effects while effectively managing urinary obstruction.

questions.text: Which type of joint is represented by the marked structure in given image of the pelvis?(FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary cartilaginous

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary Cartilaginous Joint (Symphysis):

 

Characteristics: Secondary cartilaginous joints are connected by fibrocartilage and provide limited movement and flexibility.

 

Examples: The most common example of a secondary cartilaginous joint is the intervertebral disc between adjacent vertebrae in the spine. The pubic symphysis, which connects the two pubic bones in the pelvis, is another example.

 

Function: Secondary cartilaginous joints offer stability and support to the structures they connect while allowing for limited flexibility and shock absorption.

 

Sacroiliac joint- plain synovial joint (2nd best answer is syndesmosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary Cartilaginous Joint (Synchondrosis):

 

Characteristics: In primary cartilaginous joints, the bones are connected by hyaline cartilage, which allows for very limited movement or no movement at all.

 

Examples: The most common example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate, which is the growth plate in growing long bones. It allows for bone growth until maturity when it ossifies and becomes a bony joint.

 

Function: Primary cartilaginous joints provide structural support and allow for longitudinal growth in developing bones.

 

Option B. Synovial Joint:

 

Characteristics: Synovial joints are the most common type of joint in the human body. They are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movements.

 

Examples: Examples of synovial joints include the knee joint, shoulder joint, hip joint, and many others.

 

Function: Synovial joints are highly mobile and allow for various types of movements, including flexion, extension, rotation, and more. They are essential for body movement and function.

 

Option C. Fibrous Joint (Synarthrosis):

 

Characteristics: Fibrous joints are connected by fibrous connective tissue and allow for minimal to no movement. They provide stability and support to adjacent bones.

 

Examples: Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull, which are immovable, and the syndesmosis found between the tibia and fibula in the lower leg, which allows for limited movement.

 

Function: Fibrous joints provide structural integrity and protect vital organs. In some cases, like the syndesmosis, they allow for a small amount of movement while maintaining stability.

questions.text: Among the listed drugs, which one is a monoclonal antibody used in cancer treatment? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rituximab

 

Rituximab is the correct choice as it is a monoclonal antibody specifically targeting CD20, a protein predominantly expressed on the surface of B cells. It is widely used in the treatment of various types of cancer, including Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, and Mantle Cell Lymphoma, among others. Rituximab works by binding to the CD20 antigen on B cells, leading to their destruction, which is beneficial in diseases characterized by excessive, malignant, or dysfunctional B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omalizumab: While it is indeed a monoclonal antibody, it is designed to bind to immunoglobulin E (IgE). Its primary use is in the management of severe asthma and not in cancer treatment.

 

Option B. Denosumab: This is another monoclonal antibody but it targets RANK ligand, a key factor in the formation and function of osteoclasts. Denosumab is primarily used in the treatment of osteoporosis and bone loss related to cancer, but it is not used directly to treat cancer cells.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: This is not a monoclonal antibody. Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and a chemotherapy agent used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and certain types of cancer, but through mechanisms unrelated to monoclonal antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omalizumab, Denosumab and Rituximab are all examples of monoclonal antibodies, but Rituximab is used in cancer treatment.

 

  • Denosumab – it is a RANK ligand inhibitor and is used in the treatment of osteoporosis.

  • Omalizumab – It is an anti-IgE monoclonal antibody which is used in the prophylaxis of asthma.

  • Rituximab – It is used as anti-CD-20 Monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of CLL, Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, Mantle cell lymphoma etc.

 

Methotrexate is not a monoclonal antibody, it is a DMARD used in treatment of autoimmune conditions like Rheumatoid arthritis etc.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note fixed, tender, retroverted uterus and tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament (cobblestone appearance) is seen in endometriosis. Also, the uterus is retroverted and fixed which is also classically seen in endometriosis
  • Endometriosis means endometrial deposits in sites outside the uterus
  • Endometriosis presents with symptoms which can be remembered as 5D’s
    • Dysmenorrhoea
    • Dyschezia
    • Dysfertility (infertility)
    • Dyspareunia
    • Dull aching abdominal pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PID: Presents lower abdominal pain + vaginal discharge and sometimes fever. On examination, there is classically tenderness present (adnexal/ uterine/ forniceal)

 

Option C. Pelvic TB: This has varied presentations but usually there will be menstrual abnormalities (initially menorrhagia followed by hypomenorrhea/ amenorrhea). There also causes infertility. Examination may be completely normal or there may be a tubo-ovarian (Adnexal) mass palpable.

 

Option D. Leiomyoma: Presents commonly with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhoea. On examination there is an enlarged uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis often presents with a fixed, retroverted uterus and tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments, accompanied by dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rickets

 

The radiological image above shows cupping and fraying of the metaphyses typically seen in case of rickets.

 

Rickets radiological characteristics:

 

 

  • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate)
  • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis)
  • Spawning at the metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends)
  • Widespread rarefaction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: This is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones and frequent fractures. While osteogenesis imperfecta can cause bone deformities, it does not exhibit the cupping, fraying, and widening of the metaphysis as seen in rickets. Additionally, features such as blue sclera are typically seen in osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency, which leads to defects in collagen synthesis. It presents with bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing, and radiologically with a "scorbutic rosary," but not the fraying and cupping of the metaphyses seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder that causes increased bone density (marble bone disease) due to defective osteoclast function. It does not show the characteristic findings of rickets (cupping, fraying, etc.) but instead presents with sclerotic bones and bone fragility.

 

Educational Objective:


Rickets is characterized by radiological findings such as cupping, fraying, and widening of the metaphyses due to defective bone mineralization from vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following disease shows the presence of deposition of Tau protein? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Alzheimer’s disease is characterized by the presence of Tau protein in the microtubular-associated protein in axons. This protein contributes to the formation of neurofibrillary tangles, a hallmark of Alzheimer’s pathology. Tau protein helps stabilize microtubules, but in Alzheimer's disease, abnormal phosphorylation of Tau causes it to detach from microtubules and form tangles inside neurons, disrupting the cell's transport system and leading to cell death.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CJD: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is associated with the accumulation of PrPsc protein in the neuronal cytoplasm. This abnormal prion protein leads to spongiform changes in the brain and rapid neurodegeneration, but it is not associated with Tau protein deposition.

 

Option B. Rabies: Rabies is characterized by the presence of Negri bodies in the cerebellum and Ammon’s horn of the hippocampus. These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons infected by the rabies virus, not related to Tau protein.

 

 

Option C. Parkinson’s disease: Parkinson’s disease is marked by the presence of Lewy bodies in the neuronal cytoplasm. These inclusions are primarily composed of alpha-synuclein, not Tau protein. Lewy bodies are found in the substantia nigra and other brain regions affected by Parkinson’s disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CJD- Prpsc protein in neuronal Cytoplasm
  • Rabies - Negri bodies in cerebellum and Ammon horn of hippocampus.
  • Parkinson’s disease -Lewy Bodies in neuronal cytoplasm
  • Alzheimer disease -Tau protein in microtubular associated protein in axons that contributes to neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: All of the following organisms can cause croup except? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rhinovirus

 

  • Rhinovirus is mainly known for causing the common cold. It typically affects the nasal passages and sinuses rather than the larynx and trachea and is not a typical cause of croup. While it can cause upper respiratory symptoms, these do not usually include the airway narrowing and inflammation characteristic of croup.
  • Croup, also known as acute laryngotracheobronchitis, is predominantly caused by viral infections that affect the upper airway, leading to symptoms such as a distinctive barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness. It is most commonly associated with parainfluenza viruses (especially types 1 and 2), and occasionally by other respiratory viruses like RSV.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A and B. Parainfluenza 1 and 2: These are the primary causes of croup. They infect the larynx and trachea, leading to swelling and the classic symptoms of croup.

 

Option D. RSV: While less common, RSV can also cause croup. It typically leads to bronchiolitis in infants but can affect the upper airway in a similar manner to parainfluenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup is a viral infection caused by parainfluenzae type 1, 2, and sometimes 3.

 

Rhinovirus causes common cold, Acute pharyngitis, Acute Viral Rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: What is the standard thickness of lead aprons used by radiology technicians to protect against scattered radiation during procedures? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 0.5 mm

 

Lead aprons of 0.5 mm of lead will reduce the intensity of scattered X-rays over 90 percent and should be worn by all workers regularly associated with X-ray procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 0.5 mm lead apron is the standard choice in radiology settings, offering effective protection against scattered radiation while allowing sufficient mobility for healthcare professionals during medical imaging procedures.

choices.text: Latissimus dorsi
Serratus anterior

questions.text: A patient developed the following deformity, after overhead weight-lifting exercises. Which of the following muscle is involved? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Serratus anterior

 

Explanation

 

The condition shown in the figure is the winged scapula. Dysfunction or weakness of the serratus anterior muscle can lead to a condition known as "winged scapula." This condition is characterized by the medial border of the scapula sticking out from the rib cage, rather than lying flat against it. It can result in pain, limited shoulder movement, and functional impairment.

 

  • Serratus anterior muscle (boxer’s muscle) receives innervation from long thoracic nerve, which when damaged results in paralysis of muscle, the phenomenon known as winged scapula.
  • Repetitive overhead movements presented with scapular dyskinesis (which is an abnormal scapulohumeral interaction during kinetic motion) and medial scapular winging caused by overhead weight-lifting exercises.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Lattissimus dorsi - Latissimus dorsi is supplied by the thoracodorsal nerve, from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, C6, 7 and 8. It is active in adduction, extension and especially in medial rotation of the humerus.

 

Option B) Trapezius - Innervated by the spinal part of the accessory nerve. Sensory (proprioceptive) branches are derived from the ventral rami of C3 and C4. Acting with levator scapulae, the upper fibres elevate the scapula and with it the point of the shoulder; acting with serratus anterior, trapezius rotates the scapula forward (upwards) so that the arm can be raised above the head; and acting with the rhomboids, it retracts the scapula, bracing back the shoulder. With the shoulder fixed, trapezius may bend the head and neck backwards and laterally.

 

Option D) Supraspinatus - Supraspinatus is innervated by the suprascapular nerve, C5 and 6. supraspinatus initiates abduction of the shoulder and assists deltoid in abduction. As part of the rotator cuff, supraspinatus helps to stabilize the head of the humerus in the glenoid fossa during movements of the glenohumeral joint.

 

Educational Objective

 

The serratus anterior muscle is crucial for keeping the scapula flat against the rib cage. Damage to the long thoracic nerve can lead to a winged scapula, a distinct protrusion of the scapula away from the ribcage, commonly exacerbated by overhead activities.

questions.text: What is the mode of insertion of this contraceptive? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hysteroscopic

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows an Essure coil, a type of contraceptive device used for permanent birth control.
  • The Essure device is inserted hysteroscopically, which means it is placed into the fallopian tubes through the vagina and uterus using a hysteroscope.
  • This method does not require incisions in the abdomen, making it a less invasive procedure compared to laparoscopic or abdominal methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal: This is not applicable as the Essure coil is not inserted through the abdomen.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic: While some contraceptive devices are placed laparoscopically, the Essure coil is specifically inserted hysteroscopically.

 

Option D. Oral: This is not applicable as the Essure coil is a physical device that is inserted into the fallopian tubes, not taken orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Essure coil is a contraceptive device that is inserted hysteroscopically to occlude the fallopian tubes for permanent birth control.

 

Ref: Page no 502, Textbook of Gynecology, DC Dutta, 6th edition

choices.text: Treatment with B12, folate supplements

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of fatigue, with smear showing macrocytosis. Evaluation showed normal B12 and Methylmalonate levels and elevated homocysteine levels. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folate therapy

 

The clinical vignette indicates a folate deficiency as the most likely cause of the macrocytosis and elevated homocysteine levels. Normal B12 and methylmalonate (MMA) levels rule out B12 deficiency, which is confirmed by the absence of elevated MMA, a marker that would be increased in B12 deficiency. Elevated homocysteine can be seen in both B12 and folate deficiencies, but the normal B12 levels make folate deficiency the more likely diagnosis here.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treatment with B12, folate supplements: Since B12 levels are normal, B12 supplementation is not necessary in this case.

 

Option C. Iron supplementation: Iron deficiency typically causes microcytic anemia, not macrocytosis, and therefore is not relevant to the management of folate deficiency.

 

Option D. Folate, B1 therapy: There is no indication of a B1 (thiamine) deficiency in the patient's presentation or laboratory results. Therefore, B1 supplementation is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with macrocytosis, normal B12 and MMA levels, and elevated homocysteine levels, folate deficiency is the most likely diagnosis, and folate therapy is the appropriate management.

questions.text: In a rural district of Madhya Pradesh, a medical officer learns about the ASHA program during an orientation. He's interested in knowing how many people in rural settings does one ASHA worker typically support. What is the standard population size catered to by a single ASHA worker? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2 per 1000

 

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

 

ASHA worker is a women of 25-45 years of age group, who has an educational qualification of 10th pass, and caters 2 per 1000 (New Norm). She must have undergone an induction training of 23 days at PHC, a bridge between village & ANM and selected by village panchayat.  

 

Functions of the ASHA:

 

  • Home visits
  • Health education and awareness
  • Family planning
  • Depot holder of ORS, DDKs, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms etc.
  • Treatment of minor ailments
  • Integral part of Village Health Sanitization and Nutrition Committee (VHSN)

 

Impact indicator of ASHA - IMR (Main), TB cases, :Leprosy cases and PEM rates

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suggested Norms for Health Personnel

questions.text: When reviewing the effectiveness of a diagnostic test, a healthcare analyst examines how the prevalence of a disease influences certain test metrics. Which metric is most affected by changes in the disease's prevalence? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positive predictive value

 

Positive Predictive Value (PPV) directly correlates with disease prevalence, as depicted in the graph. PPV indicates the likelihood that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease, which increases as the actual number of disease cases in the population rises.

 

 PPV α Prevalence

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity: This measures how effectively a test identifies positive cases and does not vary with disease prevalence.

 

Option B. Specificity: This assesses how effectively a test identifies negative cases, also independent of prevalence.

 

Option D. Accuracy: Though it considers both true positives and true negatives, it is not specifically highlighted as being as directly affected by prevalence as PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Sensitivity = a/a + b
  • Specificity = c/c + d
  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) = a/a + c
  • Negative Predictive value = d/d + b
  • Positive Predictive Value is dependent on:
    • Sensitivity
    • Specificity
    • Prevalence

questions.text: Which murmur is depicted in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mid systolic

 

The image given above is of a Mid systolic murmur, since the Crescendo- Decrescendo Pattern of turbulence is seen. A mid-systolic murmur is a type of heart murmur that occurs during the middle of the ventricular systole i.e. early/ active ejection phase. It is also known as a systolic ejection murmur.

 

Mid-systolic murmurs are typically heard best at the second intercostal space i.e over the region for aortic or pulmonary valve area. The murmur is usually described as a harsh or vibratory sound that starts after the first heart sound (S1) and ends before the second heart sound (S2). The most common cause of Mid-systolic murmurs is Aortic stenosis. Other conditions Pulmonary stenosis bicuspid aortic valves, or a dilated aortic root Pulmonary stenosis, pulmonary hypertension, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or a dilated pulmonary trunk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. End diastolic: Incorrect as end diastolic murmurs begin at or just before S2 and extend to S1.

 

Option B. Pan systolic: Incorrect because pan systolic murmurs extend uniformly from S1 to S2 without the crescendo-decrescendo pattern.

 

Option D. Mid diastolic: Incorrect as mid diastolic murmurs occur after S2 and before S1, typically without the sharp crescendo-decrescendo seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mid systolic murmurs are characterized by a crescendo-decrescendo pattern occurring between the first and second heart sounds. They are most commonly associated with conditions that impair the flow through the major valves during systole, such as aortic or pulmonary stenosis.

choices.text: BUN/Cr >40:1, Urine Na <40, FeNa <1, urine osmolarity >500
BUN:Cr >40:1, Urinary Na <20, FeNa <1, Urine osm >250
BUN:Cr >20:1, Urinary Na <20, FeNa <1, Urine Osm >250
BUN:Cr >20:1, Urinary Na <20, FeNa <1, Urine Osm >500

questions.text: Patient developed loose stools 6 hours after consuming fried rice. He had 20 episodes of watery stools per day with gradual reduction of urinary frequency. What lab values are consistent with this patient's physiology? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BUN: Cr >20:1 Urinary Na <20 FeNa <1 Urine Osm >500

 

The patient's symptoms suggest significant dehydration due to severe gastrointestinal fluid loss, leading to a prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). In this scenario, the body activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) to conserve water and sodium, resulting in concentrated urine.

 

Lab values consistent with prerenal AKI:

 

  • BUN/Cr >20:1: Indicates prerenal azotemia. In dehydration, urea reabsorption increases disproportionately compared to creatinine.
  • Urinary Na <20: The kidneys conserve sodium to maintain volume.
  • FeNa <1%: Fractional excretion of sodium is low due to sodium retention.
  • Urine Osm >500: Urine is concentrated due to water reabsorption.

 

Patient has dehydration suggested by Gi loss, fall in urine output. Dehydration leads to RAAS activation to conserve water, Hence Na, BUN, are reabsorbed in the PCT, DCT (BUN/Cr >20;1) which causes reduced urinary sodium (U.Na <20) and Concentrated urine due to reabsorption of Na, water.

 

Prerenal AKI: aka Hemodynamic AKI

 

Blood/Fluid loss

 

Third spacing

 

Reduced Blood volume (Shock, sepsis, cardiac dysfunction)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A primigravida presents with labour pain and on per vaginal examination her cervix is 7 cm dilated and fully effaced. What stage of labour is she in? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase of maximum slope

 

 

 

The patient is in the active stage of labour, in the phase of maximum slope.

 

  • There are two phases in the initial stage of labour: Latent phase and the active phase.
  • The active phase consists of the following:
    1. Acceleration phase where cervical dilation progresses from 3 to 4 cm.
    2. The period of greatest slope of dilatation (4-9 cm).
    3. The stage of 9-10 cm dilatation deceleration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phase of maximum slope in labor is characterized by rapid cervical dilation, typically occurring between 4-9 cm.

 

Ref: William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, pg- 433, 442-43

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina and is shown as below. Identify the cause of this presentation: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

  • A history of cyclical abdominal pain, primary amenorrhea and a bulging bluish vaginal membrane suggest cryptomenorrhea caused by an imperforate hymen.
  • A pelvic ultrasound is the diagnostic modality of choice.
  • Treatment includes a cruciate incision on the hymen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: This will present as cryptomenorrhea (amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain) but on local exam, no bulge will be seen as the hematocolpos will be higher up. Best diagnosed with MRI

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: This will present as a hematometra. On local exam, there will be a blind vagina or a vaginal dimple.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: This will also present with hematometra, The vaginal will be normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Imperforate hymen causes primary amenorrhea and cyclical abdominal pain, diagnosed by the presence of a bulging bluish vaginal membrane on examination and confirmed by pelvic ultrasound. Treatment involves a cruciate incision on the hymen.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babcock forceps

 

Babcock Forceps are ratcheted, finger ring, and non-perforating forceps and are widely used to grasp delicate tissues during surgical procedures.

 

E.g.: - to hold appendix in appendectomy

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Babcock Forceps are non-perforating forceps used to grasp delicate tissues such as the intestines and fallopian tubes during surgical procedures.

questions.text: A man presented to the hospital with symptoms of nausea, vomiting and fever. He was diagnosed with appendicitis and posted for emergency appendectomy. Identify the incidental finding found intra-operatively and shown in the figure below. (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meckel’s diverticulum

 

  • It is the most common congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

It results from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct leading to the formation of a true diverticulum of the small intestine.

 

  • Symptoms: Meckel’s diverticulum is often asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it might lead to abdominal pain, bleeding, or intestinal obstruction.
  • Relevance to the described condition: The patient's presentation might mimic that of appendicitis, and the intra-operative finding described would fit with Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intussusception:

 

Intussusception occurs when a part of the intestine (usually the small intestine) telescopes into the adjacent bowel.

 

  • Symptoms: Intussusception commonly presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain, a lump in the abdomen, and "currant jelly" stools due to the presence of mucus and blood.
  • Relevance to the described condition: It does not fit the description or the likely shown figure based on the given answer. Additionally, intussusception is more common in infants and young children.

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction:

 

  • Symptoms: Symptoms include abdominal pain, vomiting, bloating, and not being able to pass gas or stools.
  • Relevance to the described condition: While nausea and vomiting can be seen in cases of intestinal obstruction, the presented figure likely does not fit the typical appearance of an obstruction.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis:

 

  • Description: Diverticulitis is inflammation or infection of small pouches called diverticula that develop along the walls of the sigmoid colon.
  • Symptoms: The most common symptom is abdominal pain, especially on the left side. The pain may be crampy and come and go, or it can be constant and severe. Fever and chills, bloating, gas, diarrhea or constipation, nausea, and loss of appetite are other potential symptoms.
  • Relevance to the described condition: Diverticulitis typically involves the large intestine (especially the sigmoid colon) rather than the small intestine where Meckel’s diverticulum is found.

 

Given the context, the most appropriate answer would be C. Meckel’s diverticulum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a common congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract, often found incidentally during surgeries like appendectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following fluid is avoided in Intracranial Head Injury? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5% dextrose

 

In cases of intracranial head injury, managing intracranial pressure (ICP) and preventing cerebral edema are crucial. Hypotonic solutions like 5% dextrose are avoided in patients with head injuries because they can decrease the osmolarity of the plasma. This leads to an increased risk of cerebral edema and raised intracranial pressure (ICP), which can worsen the patient's condition. When 5% dextrose is administered, it quickly gets metabolized into free water, which then enters cells, including brain cells, leading to cellular swelling and exacerbating cerebral edema. This can be detrimental in head injury patients where maintaining normal ICP is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. NS (Normal Saline):
    • Normal saline is isotonic and safe for use in patients with head injuries. It helps maintain adequate intravascular volume without contributing to cerebral edema.
  • Option B. RL (Ringer's Lactate):
    • Ringer's Lactate is another isotonic solution that is considered safe for head injury patients. It helps in maintaining intravascular volume and is commonly used in trauma settings.
  • Option D. Hypertonic solution:
    • Hypertonic saline solutions can be beneficial in head injury patients as they help reduce cerebral edema by drawing water out of brain tissue into the vascular space. This helps lower intracranial pressure and is useful in managing head injury cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypotonic solutions like 5% dextrose should be avoided in patients with intracranial head injuries to prevent exacerbating cerebral edema and increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Total-body folate in the adult is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ∼10 mg

Total-body folate in the adult is ∼10 mg, with the liver containing the largest store. Daily adult requirements are ∼100 μg, and so stores are sufficient for only 3–4 months in normal adults, and severe folate deficiency may develop rapidly.

 

Harrison’s 21st edition page no 767

questions.text: Training is given to an ANM worker. Now you have to check her ability to do immunization. You are the medical officer. She is having cotton, lunch box and syringe-needle after immunization of a child. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cotton swab in Yellow bag

Explanation: Soiled waste like cotton, cloth etc., goes in yellow bag

The yellow bin receives human/animal wastes, lab wastes, cytotoxic drugs, expired drugs, cotton swabs, soiled linen, blood bag etc.

The red container receives rubber tubes, IV tubes, syringes, urine bags etc.

The blue container receives glassware, orthopedic implants, pacemakers etc.

The white container is a puncture proof container that receives sharps likes needles etc.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Sample Registration system includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. E. All of the above

Explanation: sample registration system: It is a dual registration system, where data on Crude Birth Rate(CBR), Crude Death Rate(CDR), Natural Growth Rate, Infant Mortality Rate(IMR) and Maternal Mortality Ratio are collected every 6 months at national and state level.

questions.text: In a study assessing hypertension management techniques, 200 patients are divided into two groups: one receiving medication and the other undergoing lifestyle changes. After three months, blood pressure levels are compared. Which statistical test is most suitable for evaluating the differences in average blood pressure between these two independent groups? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Unpaired Student’s T test

 

The Unpaired Student’s T test is ideal for analyzing differences in mean values between two independent groups, such as those in this study—one group using medications and the other adopting lifestyle modifications. This test helps determine if the observed differences in blood pressure levels between the two groups are statistically significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired Student’s T test: Incorrect for this scenario, as it is used for comparing two sets of data from the same participants over time, not different groups.

 

Option C. Fischer test: This is a statistical test used primarily for categorical data in contingency tables, not suitable for comparing mean blood pressure levels.

 

Option D. Chi-Square test: Used to compare categorical variables, making it inappropriate for the analysis of mean blood pressure levels.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Radical neck dissection

questions.text: A patient who suffered from a stroke and requires long term mechanical ventilation undergoes a procedure to create a secure opening in his airway as shown in the picture below. Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tracheostomy

The image given in the question shows the procedure of tracheostomy.

Tracheotomy or tracheostomy, is a surgical airway management procedure which consists of making an incision on the anterior aspect of the neck and opening a direct airway through an incision in the trachea.

Indications for tracheostomy:

  1. Emergency airway access
  2. Airway access for prolonged mechanical ventilation
  3. Functional or mechanical upper airway obstruction
  4. Decreased/incompetent clearance of tracheobronchial secretions

questions.text: A 1-year-old child, 17 kg child presents with watery diarrhea since 2 days. He is very fatigued and unable to feed. He is admitted to the hospital for the same.  What is the amount of maintenance fluid required in 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1350 ml

Maintenance fluid id given as per Holliday Segar formula.

  • 100 ml/kg for the 1st 10 kg of weight. 50 ml/kg for the 2nd 10 kg of weight. 20 ml/kg for the remaining weight.
  • So, for a 17 kg child maintenance fluid is ----- (10 x 100) + (7 x 50) = 1000 + 350 = 1350 ml

questions.text: A baby born yesterday has not yet passed meconium. The mother is very concerned and she approaches the pediatrician. The doctor reassures her and tells her to report to him if the baby has not passed meconium till _____ hours after birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 48 hours

Maximum time to wait for meconium to be passed in a newborn – 48 hours

And for urine to be passed – 24 hours

Conditions causing delay in passage of meconium:

  • Hirschsprung disease (Aganglionsis)
  • Imperforate anus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Meconium ileus [cystic fibrosis]
  • Small left colon syndrome [Associated with Infant of diabetic mothers]

choices.text: Superficial migratory thrombophlebitis
Deep vein thrombosis

questions.text: A 63-year-old with restricted ambulation and prolonged bed rest due to a recent hip injury presented with severe pain in right leg below the knee. On examination there is severe discoloration of calf on the right leg with significant swelling as shown in the image. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deep vein thrombosis

  • Virchow triad: endothelial injury, stasis, hypercoagulable state
  • Most common site is calf vein
  • Most common symptom →pain, swelling in calf region
  • Most common sign → calf tenderness
  • Homan’s sign →increased resistance to dorsiflexion of foot
  • Moses sign→ pain on application of pressure on calf region
  • Pratt sign→ pain on squeezing of calf region
  • Investigation: D-Dimer
  • IOC: Duplex USG scan

choices.text: Cortical venous thrombosis
Sub arachnoid hemorrhage

questions.text: A cricket player was hit on the head with the cricket ball and was fine and then collapsed suddenly. He woke up to play the match brilliantly but was later found unconscious in the dressing room. Which of the following is correct about this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural hemorrhage

Extradural hemorrhage:

Extradural hematoma (EDH), also known as an epidural hematoma, is a collection of blood that forms between the inner surface of the skull and outer layer of the dura, which is called the endosteal layer. They are usually associated with a history of head trauma and frequently associated skull fracture.

Bleeding occurs from - Middle meningeal artery.

Symptoms

  • Confusion.
  • Dizziness.
  • Drowsiness or altered level of alertness.
  • Enlarged pupil in one eye.
  • Headache (severe)
  • Head injury or trauma followed by loss of consciousness, a period of alertness, then rapid deterioration back to unconsciousness.
  • Nausea or vomiting.

questions.text: The Image shows below origin from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B cells

Reed–Sternberg cells (also known as lacunar histiocytes for certain types) are distinctive, giant cells Found with light microscopy in biopsies from individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma. They are usually derived from B Lymphocytes, classically considered crippled germinal center B cells.

NK cell: - A type of immune cell that has granules (small particles) with enzymes that can kill tumor cells or cells infected with a virus.

questions.text: After which phase of clinical trials, a new drug is introduced in the market?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phase 3

Phase 1 is done in healthy human volunteers to assess the safety and toxicity of the drug

Phase 2 is conducted in a moderate number of patients to know about the optimal dosing, treatment efficacy and adverse effects.

Phase 3 is conducted in a large number of patients to compare the new treatment with the current standard of care.

Phase 4 is also called as Post-Marketing Surveillance and is the longest phase of a trial

• Phase 3 is RCT

• Maximum failure is reported from phase 2

• Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of a drug is assessed in Phase 1

questions.text: A lactating woman came to OPD 6 weeks after delivery for check-up and to get advice for the Contraception, which of the following is not advised?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Combined OCP

The Combined OCP suppresses lactation due to its estrogen component. So it is contraindicated in a lactating mother. IUCD can be inserted after 6 weeks of delivery. Also Norplant and Mini pills containing Progesterone preparation do not have any effect on breast milk production and can thus be safely used in this case.

choices.text: OCP from 1st day of next cycle

questions.text: A low socio-economic female worker who is 22 years-old presents within 8 hours of sexual assault on the 13th day of cycle and asked for emergency contraception. What will be the best advice for the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. LNG 1.5 milligram

Levonorgestrel 1.5mg as a single dose taken within 72 hrs of unprotected intercourse/sexual assault can be used as an emergency contraceptive.

Misoprostol and Mifepristone are not recommended as methods of emergency contraception. They can be used for medical termination of pregnancy.

OCP from the 1st day of next cycle is not applicable in this case as by that time she might already become pregnant.

questions.text: Contraindication of the device from the following image includes?

choices.text: Deep vein thrombosis

questions.text: A bed ridden patient developed fever and pedal edema. On examination there is calf tenderness which is aggravated on squeezing the calf. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep vein thrombosis

Deep vein thrombosis:

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a type of venous thrombosis involving the formation of a blood clot in a deep vein, most commonly in the legs or pelvis
  • Symptoms can include pain, swelling, redness, and enlarged veins in the affected area
  • Most common site is calf vein.
    • Homan’s sign →increased resistance to dorsiflexion of foot
    • Moses’ sign→ pain on application of pressure on calf region
    • Pratt sign→ pain on squeezing of calf region
    • Investigation: Duplex scan of calf

Management – Start on anticoagulant drugs

choices.text: Klippel Feil Syndrome
Dislocation of scapula

questions.text: Identify the congenital syndrome shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Klippel Feil Syndrome

Klippel Feil syndrome:

Klippel–Feil syndrome (KFS), also known as cervical vertebral fusion syndrome, is a rare congenital condition characterized by the abnormal fusion of any two of the seven bones in the neck (cervical vertebrae)

Associated abnormalities of Klippel Feil syndrome:

  • Scoliosis (sideways curvature of the spine)
  • Spina bifida
  • Problems with the kidneys and the ribs
  • Cleft palate
  • Dental problems (delayed dentition, cavities, missing teeth)
  • Respiratory problems
  • Heart defects
  • Short stature
  • Duane syndrome
  • Srb's anomaly
  • Sprengel's deformity

questions.text: Identify the comorbidity this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diabetes

The characteristic clinical sign is a positive “prayer” sign which describes the inability to flatten the hands together as while praying.

It is seen in diabetic patients due to limited joint mobility (also known as Cheiroarthropathy)

choices.text: Factor VIII deficiency

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy falls down and hurts his knee. He presents with hemarthrosis as shown in the image below. Deficiency of which coagulation factor can lead to hemarthrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Factor VIII deficiency

The boy is suffering from Hemophilia. Features of hemophilia -

  • Spontaneous Bleeding
  • Easy Bruisability
  • Painful, swollen joints due to bleeding within them (hemarthrosis)
  • Bleeding gums

There are two main types of Haemophilia: Haemophilia A, which occurs due to low amounts of clotting factor VIII, and Haemophilia B, which occurs due to low levels of clotting factor IX.

Hemophilia is an X linked recessive disorder.

M/C joint affected: ANKLE

Characteristic lab feature: Increased APTT

choices.text: Left sided ICD insertion
Right sided ICD insertion

questions.text: This is the Xray of a patient post central line insertion now presenting with respiratory distress. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left sided ICD insertion

This patient has a pneumothorax likely due to central line insertion.

Features of pneumothorax on Xray:

  • A linear shadow of visceral pleura with lack of lung markings peripheral to the shadow may be observed, indicating collapsed lung.
  • An ipsilateral lung edge may be seen parallel to the chest wall.
  • Trachea will shift towards the opposing side.

Management of pneumothorax – Intercostal drain insertion.
